browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
Hundred percent agree. The Scottish government and Nicolas sturgeon could make a stand...set up a Scottish inquiry which would force the hand of rudd. Sturgeon is a great politician....she will become an outstanding politician when she makes the truly brave decision that will stand up for ordinary working people who have been wronged by tory injustice and actions in history that were way beyond reasonable and possibly legal||"For several years, Neil Findlay, the Labour MSP for Lothian, has been pressing the Scottish government to initiate an inquiry into the conduct of the Scottish police during the miners’ strike "
What a pity that his own party was in power in Scotland and the UK and sat on their hands for years. And now he wants the SNP to sort it out ???? Findlay is a right wing unionist to the core and his attempts to blame the SNP for something his own party had opportunities to sort out are a disgrace.||The conduct of the police raises questions about the extent to which a UK government, acting without the consent of parliament or the people, can suddenly suspend the normal checks and balances on the forces of law and order. 
I agree with you here - but in what world can the devolved Scottish government order an inquiry into the actions of the Thatcher government acting without the consent of the UK parliament? How could they compel witnesses for a start? 
There should be an inquiry I am fully supportive of that but you are shooting at the wrong target.||The decision by Amber Rudd not to hold an Inquiry was a disgrace. The fact she never even asked to see South Yorkshire's own files on the incident reveals the Tory disdain for truth, justice and democracy. They were using the police across England Scotland and Wales as an arm of the government, determined to crush 'the enemy within'. Senior tories from the Thatcher era welcomed the refusal to hold an Inquiry. What a surprise. Papers from the era are embargoed for 80 years. Nothing to see here - move along. This was a political decision to prevent not just Tory embarrassment but also the possibility of huge compensation settlements and to prevent an insight into how Thatcher really worked with the collusion of people who should have known better. The SNP Scottish Government can use their powers to hold an Inquiry into what went on in Scotland and shame the Tories (if such a thing is possible) into doing similar south of the border.||Sacrificed hundreds of thousands? And as for keeping the lights on - they were paid to do a job.
text:
Only those whose lives have been disfigured by gross injustice will know that the shame and hurt are not diminished by time. That is why mature, enlightened and liberal democracies will sometimes reach out to groups who have been wronged in another age. It also sends out a message to those who would still cling to medievalism. The pursuit to restore justice denied can never be time-barred – unless you are a miner in the UK.

More than 30 years after the miners’ strike in 1984-85, thousands are still waiting for justice for their treatment. Governments north and south of the border have resisted all entreaties because each knows that to accede would be to invite proper scrutiny of the vindictive and sinister behaviour of the police. During the 12 months of the dispute, police forces were deployed in the manner of a private army by a government of the hard-right that used every means at its disposal to destroy the miners and their communities.
title: If Scotland is fairer, what about justice for miners?

comments:
Southgate seems a decent bloke, however, he won't get much out of this bunch like a great deal of those before him. Sure they'll waltz through their group, look decent here and there perhaps even resemble something like a cohesive unit but ultimately it will just be them flattering to deceive.
The fact that Rooney is still being played tells me all I need to know, also players like Cahill are long in the tooth. He's been badly exposed at Chelsea and despite the fact his deficiencies will be covered up in the back three they're currently utilising he will be found wanting on the international stage.||Scotland are utter pants, yet could have beaten England last night with better finishing and a decent pair of centre halves. Of the two teams, given the vast disparity in apparent player values, apart from the score which played better last night? 
Southgate seems a nice enough guy, and a better coach for England than Sam Twattardyce. Whether he'll be allowed to muddle on through being average by the English press is another thing entirely.||Scrap international football altogether.
Gareth 'Face like a Dragon or a Goblin, I'm really not sure' Southgate is a terrible choice for a terrible team. He's barely older than half the players and was a highly average player himself, how he could manage to leverage any respect from the Beats-wearing, Balenciaga-donning fuckwit narcissists and Wayne Rooney is anybody's guess.
Scrap international football altogether.||Good on Garett, love the three piece suit and two poppy combo. He could have had a poppy themed tie and all.||It's England it will all end up shit
text:
It was a victory that in many ways embodies the early days of the England reign of the man who has accidentally landed in the hot seat. Well meaning but hesitant. Full of good intentions but, as yet, far from wholly convincing. A curate’s egg that contained flashes of promise but plenty of familiar failings and nagging questions. Enough of the former to likely land Gareth Southgate a contract through to Euro 2020 but still too many of the latter to inspire much confidence.

As England’s players, eight of whom also started on that fateful night in Nice when Iceland struck the latest and among the most crushing of blows to the nation’s footballing psyche, gingerly and hesitantly continued their rehabilitation in the World Cup qualifier against Scotland at Wembley on Friday night, Southgate also sought to find his feet as an international manager. Both tottered like a baby giraffe at times but ultimately found some slivers of optimism. There are always slivers.
title: Gareth Southgate set for England job but the work has only just begun |Owen Gibson

As England’s players, eight of whom also started on that fateful night in Nice when Iceland struck the latest and among the most crushing of blows to the nation’s footballing psyche, gingerly and hesitantly continued their rehabilitation in the World Cup qualifier against Scotland at Wembley on Friday night, Southgate also sought to find his feet as an international manager. Both tottered like a baby giraffe at times but ultimately found some slivers of optimism. There are always slivers.
title: Gareth Southgate set for England job but the work has only just begun |Owen Gibson

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/49.0.2623.112 Safari/537.36
comments:
Southgate seems a decent bloke, however, he won't get much out of this bunch like a great deal of those before him. Sure they'll waltz through their group, look decent here and there perhaps even resemble something like a cohesive unit but ultimately it will just be them flattering to deceive.
The fact that Rooney is still being played tells me all I need to know, also players like Cahill are long in the tooth. He's been badly exposed at Chelsea and despite the fact his deficiencies will be covered up in the back three they're currently utilising he will be found wanting on the international stage.||Scotland are utter pants, yet could have beaten England last night with better finishing and a decent pair of centre halves. Of the two teams, given the vast disparity in apparent player values, apart from the score which played better last night? 
Southgate seems a nice enough guy, and a better coach for England than Sam Twattardyce. Whether he'll be allowed to muddle on through being average by the English press is another thing entirely.||Scrap international football altogether.
Gareth 'Face like a Dragon or a Goblin, I'm really not sure' Southgate is a terrible choice for a terrible team. He's barely older than half the players and was a highly average player himself, how he could manage to leverage any respect from the Beats-wearing, Balenciaga-donning fuckwit narcissists and Wayne Rooney is anybody's guess.
Scrap international football altogether.||Good on Garett, love the three piece suit and two poppy combo. He could have had a poppy themed tie and all.||It's England it will all end up shit
text:
It was a victory that in many ways embodies the early days of the England reign of the man who has accidentally landed in the hot seat. Well meaning but hesitant. Full of good intentions but, as yet, far from wholly convincing. A curate’s egg that contained flashes of promise but plenty of familiar failings and nagging questions. Enough of the former to likely land Gareth Southgate a contract through to Euro 2020 but still too many of the latter to inspire much confidence.

As England’s players, eight of whom also started on that fateful night in Nice when Iceland struck the latest and among the most crushing of blows to the nation’s footballing psyche, gingerly and hesitantly continued their rehabilitation in the World Cup qualifier against Scotland at Wembley on Friday night, Southgate also sought to find his feet as an international manager. Both tottered like a baby giraffe at times but ultimately found some slivers of optimism. There are always slivers.
title: Gareth Southgate set for England job but the work has only just begun |Owen Gibson

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
The problem was hillary clinton.||Maybe the alternative was worse for women.....||Women probably voted for Trump because they hadn't read the Guardian. Or perhaps because they had.||Jeepers.||'Yet everyone exists in a climate where men who seek power are real men but women who seek power are innately distrustful and fake.'
Erm...no.
text:
Susan Sarandon told us why she would not vote for Hillary Clinton: “I don’t vote with my vagina.” Nor, it seems, do many women. The howl of pain that accompanied the post-election analysis has often centred on that one disturbing statistic: 53% of white women voted for a man who calls women pigs, has a string of sexual assault claims still outstanding, who will happily turn back women’s rights to contraception and abortion if it suits him. Women beware women.

How could they? It had been widely predicted that it would be women who stopped Trump, who proved he was unacceptable. The majority of black women and a large number of Hispanic women did indeed vote for Clinton. The problem was white women. The phrase that is bandied about is that this is all the fault of “white feminism”. Trump’s victory absolutely exposed and exploited racism, there is no doubt about that. There are two choices here, then: to condemn everyone who voted for Trump as despicable racist scum or to understand why this has happened. Understanding is not the same as “normalising” Trump, but I know condemnation is, at this point, more emotionally satisfying.
title: Why did women vote for Trump? Because misogyny is not a male-only attribute

comments:
It will be decided by the high tempo at which England can play. So that won't happen until Care comes on.||Line outs will definatley be interesting. If England are planning a kicking game they my find that putting the ball in touch doesn't work as well for them as it has done with the huge players South Africa are fielding, can't help think that this may be part of the reason for the SA selection as England line out has been quite strong under EJ.Got my fingers crossed for an England win, and thinking about how deep our depth of players go for the following matches, simply as this game has the potential of being quite brutal up front.||The English pack will be nullified in open play by the Saffas, and therefore the English will struggle to win the game. England aren't a side that wins many matches if their forwards aren't dominant; their backline isn't strong enough in attack.
The thrashing of the Boks by the ABs has absolutely no bearing on this match, because the backline play of the ABs is a quantum leap ahead of England's.||Who else sees Joe Launchbury being nibbled in that photo?||Big big team fielded by SA, with an extra second row to stop the Vunipolas. England will look to play it wide and get south Africa moving a lot. Hope Billy V can keep up the pace.
Are south Africa playing France? That promises to be boring. Who can get more weight into the ruck? 80 minutes of maul and crash bang.
text:
Ten years, 12 matches and one try that never was have passed under the bridge since England last beat South Africa but if reports of the Springboks’ decline have not been exaggerated, there has never been a better chance to put that right.

Described as bullies by Eddie Jones but of late cumbersome and unable to live with the speed and emphasis on attack that the best sides in the world can boast, South Africa have arrived in Britain brow-beaten.
title: Where England’s showdown with South Africa at Twickenham will be decided

comments: Problem being that it's interchangeable with the control left.||Alt-Reich||The problem is not calling some, but labelling all, as Nazis.||Unfortunately the seduction of the bile spewed by the alt right is attractive to a large segment of the US. The denial I've seen is inexplicable. It's deeply worrying.||Just to be on the safe side I shall shout "nazi" when I'm not sure. or indeed when I haven't seen one.
text:
What does it take to call a Nazi a Nazi? In the interminable fortnight since the election of Donald Trump, the US press has been floundering in a gyre of panic over the internal taxonomy of racists.

For months, many (myself included) indulged Trump’s base in their euphemism of choice, the “alt-right”, an attempt to rebrand warmed-over Reconstruction-era white supremacy as a cool, new (and harmless!) internet fad. Despite the fact that Breitbart News (described by former honcho turned Trump adviser Stephen Bannon as “the platform for the alt-right”) had, at one point, a news tag labeled “black crime”, and was a driver of the racist conspiracy theory that Barack Obama was a secret Kenyan Muslim, the press contorted itself into labyrinthine knots to avoid applying the word “racist” to Bannon or Trump in any committed way. (In our post-meaning world, being called a racist is nearly as grievous as being a racist.)
title: White nationalists? Alt-right? If you see a Nazi, say Nazi

comments: Problem being that it's interchangeable with the control left.||Alt-Reich||The problem is not calling some, but labelling all, as Nazis.||Unfortunately the seduction of the bile spewed by the alt right is attractive to a large segment of the US. The denial I've seen is inexplicable. It's deeply worrying.||Just to be on the safe side I shall shout "nazi" when I'm not sure. or indeed when I haven't seen one.
text:
What does it take to call a Nazi a Nazi? In the interminable fortnight since the election of Donald Trump, the US press has been floundering in a gyre of panic over the internal taxonomy of racists.

For months, many (myself included) indulged Trump’s base in their euphemism of choice, the “alt-right”, an attempt to rebrand warmed-over Reconstruction-era white supremacy as a cool, new (and harmless!) internet fad. Despite the fact that Breitbart News (described by former honcho turned Trump adviser Stephen Bannon as “the platform for the alt-right”) had, at one point, a news tag labeled “black crime”, and was a driver of the racist conspiracy theory that Barack Obama was a secret Kenyan Muslim, the press contorted itself into labyrinthine knots to avoid applying the word “racist” to Bannon or Trump in any committed way. (In our post-meaning world, being called a racist is nearly as grievous as being a racist.)
title: White nationalists? Alt-right? If you see a Nazi, say Nazi

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
There is nothing liberal about dismissing the concerns of millions of voters on both sides of the Atlantic as irrational anger.||How you win matters.Brexit and Donald Trump are a bad advert for democracy.Words have meaning no matter what brexiters or Trump supporterswant you to believe.
And selling simplistic slogans to the electorate is damaging as well.For example Trump promises to repeal ObamaCare which help 20 million poor American but never explained what he will replace it with unless he wants people to die.The same simplistic slogan of Brexit . Never explained what Leave means or lie about it.||Most of the liberals I've encountered in these past month are ant-democratic. I mean... Farron calls himself a liberal...||"Hold on to liberal values" - or hold on to neoliberal values (government of the people, by the rich, for the corporations)?||I note that Mrs May was the tenth foreign leader that Trump telephoned after his election. It is unclear to me whether that represents this country's importance to him or whether someone had given him her telephone number with no 10 (Downing Street) written beside it and he just misunderstood.
text:
Contrary to the self-aggrandising boasts of Nigel Farage, Britain’s vote to leave the European Union did not beget the result of the US presidential election. There are analogous dynamics driving support for Brexit and for Donald Trump, just as there are comparable weaknesses in the remain proposition and Hillary Clinton’s candidacy. But the relationship is more metaphorical than causal. That, in any case, is the sense in which American commentary has appropriated the term Brexit – shorthand for the punishment administered by angry voters to what they perceive as a corrupt, metropolitan establishment.

But Brexit is not a metaphor in the UK, it is government policy. The election of Mr Trump does very little to make its passage smoother. It adds new layers of diplomatic complexity and economic uncertainty. The existence of an eager trade partner in the US was axiomatic to the case for quitting the EU. When Barack Obama publicly warned Britain that its seat at various tables in Brussels was integral to the country’s strategic power in the world, he was dismissed by Boris Johnson as a meddlesome stooge of pro-European interests with spiteful motive informed by his part-African heritage.
title: The Guardian view on the UK and Trump: hold on to liberal values

comments:
After 15 years of independence
You mean 27 years of independence.||If they want US protection that's not exactly going the right way about it...||sadly, they have every 'realist' reason to be scared as small states elsewhere have, with the rise again of despotic nationalistic populists in powerful states and a return to seemingly old great power geo-politics.||The damage Trump could do to the finely balance world order (and it's resulting stability in all areas without serious religious/sectarian stress) is inestimable. He is a reality TV entertainer in control of the most powerful nuclear equipped military in the world.||There is literally a zero chance of Russia invading Lithuania. Zero. They have nothing, they have a very small Russian minority that is actually treated as citizens (unlike Latvia and Estonia). The real problem for Lithuania is depopulation and pressure from Brussels to accept thousands of ME migrants.
So why the hysteria? Why the obscene pictures that remind one of the "Pussy Riot revolution"?
text:
Donald Trump appeared overnight on a wall in the Lithuanian capital this spring – larger than lifesize and locked in a kiss with Russian president Vladimir Putin.

The mural was meant as satire, a nod to the unexpected mutual appreciation between two macho demagogues on opposite sides of the world, and a wink at the long shadow of Soviet history that still hangs over the region.
title: As global axis of power shifts, a cold wind blows through the Baltic states

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
She's great. Inventive, melodic, challenging and uplifting.||Yes she is quirky, lovely ...and antisemitism is disgusting.||Very interesting. I have a friend who says he's only Jewish because of anti-Semitism. He's an atheist & not into the cultural practices at all. His explanation is that "If I think I'm Jewish, then I'm Jewish. If the rabbi thinks I'm Jewish, then I'm Jewish. And if the Nazis think I'm Jewish, then I'm definitely Jewish, regardless of what anybody else has to say about it."
Race, you see, is an artificial construct, invented in the minds of racists and given material reality by their practice of racism. It doesn't have to be logical - it just has to have sufficient coherence so that racists can usually tell the difference between the "race" they hate and the people they don't - preferably by looking at them.
So, yes, I can definitely understand how Ms Spektor comes to her position. If we ever see the day when anti-Semitism disappears from the face of the Earth, she might be able to forget about being Jewish. I know my friend would love to.||Talented songwriter. I like the line it feels like a kind of ancestral land where I’m in love with a culture that doesn’t really exist||Anyone with half a brain would be annoyed by being called 'adorkable'. She's wonderful in every way and I find it incomprehensible most of the population haven't even heard of her.
text:
It used to upset Regina Spektor to be called quirky. “Kooky!” “Adorkable!” She rolls her eyes. We’re having a pasta lunch in London, and between bites Spektor quickly runs through her ancestral history, her politics, her family, writing songs, the Arab-Israeli conflict and concepts of home. It’s a little like watching a TED talk by a Sesame Street character. Not that she’s childish, more that the balance of deep thought and cartoonish delivery is disconcerting, seductive – her eyes widen into great lakes, she hmms and squeaks as she talks about her journey to this peculiar stardom.

“I used to think calling me ‘quirky’ was a clever way of keeping down anything creative and adventurous. There are things people say that are condescending to difference. But if a guy is the way I am he’s a visionary. He doesn’t let anyone into the studio? He’s so strong! But her? She’s a paranoid control freak, a micromanager who doesn’t trust anybody. Emotional rather than passionate. She…” She gestures with a fork: “She is crazy! But coming from Soviet Russia, from Jewish people who have been oppressed, I feel like I’m in such a lucky place. It’s OK if people think funny things. They always have, about women, about race. I wouldn’t want to make that the narrative. That’s not my story.”
title: Regina Spektor: ‘The only reason I’m Jewish is antisemitism’

comments:
She's great. Inventive, melodic, challenging and uplifting.||Yes she is quirky, lovely ...and antisemitism is disgusting.||Very interesting. I have a friend who says he's only Jewish because of anti-Semitism. He's an atheist & not into the cultural practices at all. His explanation is that "If I think I'm Jewish, then I'm Jewish. If the rabbi thinks I'm Jewish, then I'm Jewish. And if the Nazis think I'm Jewish, then I'm definitely Jewish, regardless of what anybody else has to say about it."
Race, you see, is an artificial construct, invented in the minds of racists and given material reality by their practice of racism. It doesn't have to be logical - it just has to have sufficient coherence so that racists can usually tell the difference between the "race" they hate and the people they don't - preferably by looking at them.
So, yes, I can definitely understand how Ms Spektor comes to her position. If we ever see the day when anti-Semitism disappears from the face of the Earth, she might be able to forget about being Jewish. I know my friend would love to.||Talented songwriter. I like the line it feels like a kind of ancestral land where I’m in love with a culture that doesn’t really exist||Anyone with half a brain would be annoyed by being called 'adorkable'. She's wonderful in every way and I find it incomprehensible most of the population haven't even heard of her.
text:
It used to upset Regina Spektor to be called quirky. “Kooky!” “Adorkable!” She rolls her eyes. We’re having a pasta lunch in London, and between bites Spektor quickly runs through her ancestral history, her politics, her family, writing songs, the Arab-Israeli conflict and concepts of home. It’s a little like watching a TED talk by a Sesame Street character. Not that she’s childish, more that the balance of deep thought and cartoonish delivery is disconcerting, seductive – her eyes widen into great lakes, she hmms and squeaks as she talks about her journey to this peculiar stardom.

“I used to think calling me ‘quirky’ was a clever way of keeping down anything creative and adventurous. There are things people say that are condescending to difference. But if a guy is the way I am he’s a visionary. He doesn’t let anyone into the studio? He’s so strong! But her? She’s a paranoid control freak, a micromanager who doesn’t trust anybody. Emotional rather than passionate. She…” She gestures with a fork: “She is crazy! But coming from Soviet Russia, from Jewish people who have been oppressed, I feel like I’m in such a lucky place. It’s OK if people think funny things. They always have, about women, about race. I wouldn’t want to make that the narrative. That’s not my story.”
title: Regina Spektor: ‘The only reason I’m Jewish is antisemitism’

Race, you see, is an artificial construct, invented in the minds of racists and given material reality by their practice of racism. It doesn't have to be logical - it just has to have sufficient coherence so that racists can usually tell the difference between the "race" they hate and the people they don't - preferably by looking at them.
So, yes, I can definitely understand how Ms Spektor comes to her position. If we ever see the day when anti-Semitism disappears from the face of the Earth, she might be able to forget about being Jewish. I know my friend would love to.||Talented songwriter. She's wonderful in every way and I find it incomprehensible most of the population haven't even heard of her.

comments:
Woah. The victory of Trump in a democratic election is a threat to democratic values? That really is Orwell 1984 logic.||What if it were America that did not want to be in NATO, or the Five Eyes, or ANZUS, or NAFTA, or CAFTA, or TTIP, or TPP, or TISA, or the military alliances with Japan and South Korea? What if it were America that did not want to run the EU by proxy through Germany and Britain, that did not want to run the EU at all, that did not even particularly want there to be an EU at all? No one had ever thought of any of that. They may have to think about it all very, very soon.
Speaking very broadly, there are two globalisations, the one centred on America, and the one comprised of everywhere that is not part of the first one. For various reasons, some countries are ambivalent between the two. In Europe west of old Soviet frontier, the most notable example of that is France. The Presidential Election result in Bulgaria in the last few days was also striking, as was the one inside the former USSR, in Moldova. The proponents of the first globalisation have a plan for, say, Russia to swap sides. They know what they would do if it did. But that has not happened. Instead, it is America that has become one of the countries that played both sides of the street. No one has the faintest idea what to do about that.||If you want to know why the discredited and useless political elite is in trouble, just read this garbage from Merkel and Obama, who believe that losing a few elections is the end of the world.... And not a word about how we can resurrect the industries that we need in order to deliver proper jobs to our people in the west.||No poll in the Netherlands predicts more then 20% of the votes for Wilders. How is that a triumph?||Obama was an empty suit who has done nothing but weaken the West.
As for Merkel, she may go down in history as the woman who single-handedly ruined Europe. 
Good riddance to both.
text:
Democracy is “hard work” and must not be taken for granted, said Barack Obama during his farewell visit to Europe last week. How right he is. The challenges confronting western democracies as 2016 draws to a ragged close are of a breadth and intensity not seen since the early 1980s, when Leonid Brezhnev’s Soviet Union was expanding its nuclear arsenal and suppressing Solidarity in Poland. Today, Russia under Vladimir Putin is again building bombs and meddling in neighbours’ affairs. But he is not the only or even the biggest problem. Much of the danger to democracy comes from within.

Angela Merkel, Germany’s long-serving chancellor, and Obama struggled with this issue during meetings in Berlin that included walk-on parts for the leaders of France, Britain, Italy and Spain. The (Republican) elephant in the room was Donald Trump. Nobody mentioned him by name. But the threat to democratic values and the transatlantic alliance that sustains them implicit in his victory was the subject of a pointed article written by Obama and Merkel, and published in a German weekly.
title: The Observer view on the worldwide threat to liberal democracy

comments:
Can I add that there are now a few online free kits which for uncomplicated younger people make sense (rather than nothing!) we must get round to a proper one soon as we now hit inherence tax and kids no longer need a legal guardian (written in my diy will). 
If nothing else get a piece of a4 paper, write down your wishes, sign, date, and get an unrelated person who is not a beneficiary to witness. Its not perfect, but better than nothing.||I'm a funeral director and amazed at how few people have a proper will. The chaos that can be left is horrendous. I've lost count of the times I've seen previously close relationships turn into spiteful, bitter and cruel fights over money and property. There is rarely loyalty when money is involved. Don't ever presume that your family has the wish or ability to interpret your wishes fairly; make a clear, fair and unambiguous will with a qualified professional.||My partner and I have just finalised our wills. We're not married and we're told were we to get married it would invalidate this will. So I was really interested to read about inserting “in contemplation of marriage”means a will is still valid after you marry. Our solicitor didn't mention this at all - which is disappointing.||As the article alludes to, the easiest (and best) way of leaving everything to a spouse is to not leave a will. If your spouse pre-deceases you, the best way to split your estate equally between your kids is to not leave a will. 
Wills are great when you have complicated family structures or want to leave specific thing to specific people/charities, but by no means essential. In fact they can complicate matters.||My wife and myself had previous marriages, we have between us six children, none from this marriage we are also domiciled in Scotland with different laws to the rest of the UK. Very few relationships are as simple as your recommendations seem to imply.
text:
Almost half of adults have not yet made a will, according to research carried out for The Observer by Co-op Legal Services. It found that just 53% had put down in writing what they wanted to happen in the event of their death.

It’s not a job anyone relishes, but if you die without leaving a will, you could leave costs and complications for your loved ones to deal with, alongside a great deal of heartache.
title: Writing a will isn’t a job you’ll relish, but it is a matter of life and death

comments:
EU needs to lift its whopping tariffs on Chinese solar panels so people can import long-term renewable energy supply systems; rooftop solar and home battery storage should be the norms.
http://www.solar-trade.org.uk/why-eu-tariffs-on-chinese-solar-panels-need-to-end/
One of the few positive aspects of Brexit is that it allows Britain to escape that tariff structure, which damages the entire transition to renewable energy. Not that the Cameron-Qatar axis likes the idea of Britain being able to eliminate imports of Middle Eastern gas.||It's Corbyn's fault.||Ah, but isn't it reassuring to know that free market capitalism has ensured the most efficient system is in place to deliver the cheapest... er... the best... um... the sort of... er... well, that's what Nigel Farage and the Daily Mail say, anyway.||If only we still owned the energy sector. Instead of it being a cash cow for a few overseas investors we could have used the profits - at least £5 billion a year - to plan and diversify and localise our energy production. 
That's at least a hundred billion for insulation, solar, river, lagoon, water and tidal along with wind to ensure a 24 hour supply for all without oil, gas or coal or nuclear. 
And still we hand these useless Cowboys tens of billions a year to do what? Just put prices up because they haven't any options to make things cheaper, more efficient. Because that would affect profits. L
The stupidity of the Tories just gets bigger every day.||This would explain why Gridwatch is showing the French sucking in much more UK power recently than has normally been the case.
text:
Householders are being warned to brace themselves for a rise in their electricity bills as a series of freak events conspires to send wholesale prices rocketing.

Safety concerns at France’s nuclear power plants operated by the energy company EDF have led to many reactors being temporarily shut down. There have been similar suspensions in Belgium. In addition, a lack of rain in Norway and Sweden – whose hydro plants generate large amounts of electricity for their European neighbours – has limited both countries’ energy production.
title: Energy supply cuts may send fuel bills soaring

comments:
This is the type of Indignista feedback loop that so many people I know are tired of.
No one really cares about some painting that a talk-show host bought. In the Real World, where people have Real Problems, the fact that OP does not like some painting by an unknown, bought by a deliberatly confrontational political talking head rates signficantly lower than a broken shoelace.
I am sure Mr. Hannity will dedicate time on his show in his equally indignanat response to this column, allowing OP to write another column in even more indignant response.
I accept that some people like this sort of rousing of the media rabble. But, I strongly suspect that most don't.
Come on, Guardian. You want me to pay for your quality journalism? I am inclined to, but I need to see more of it, and less ideological click-baiting.||I will never be able to unsee this abomination. I am minded to sue this bastard.||The painting's called "The forgotten man", but where are the women?||They couldn't give a f**k about you forgotten man. The ones that do care about you and your British counterpart, Sanders & Corbyn, wont be allowed power. 
Establishment including some democrats would rather have Trump than Sanders.Establishment including PLP/Progress would rather have Tories than Corbyn.||Squint and it could be a Courbet.
text:
Obama’s 2008 campaign had Shepard Fairey’s “Hope” poster; if there’s a defining image for Donald Trump’s presidential moment, it could well be The Forgotten Man, an oil painting by Utah-based artist Jon McNaughton. The detailed image takes some unpicking: In front of a twilit White House, with the American flag at half-mast, all the past presidents of the US are gathered. In the left foreground is a Caucasian man in contemporary dress, sat on a bench, his gaze cast downwards, “distraught and hopeless as he contemplates his future,” as the artist puts it. Closest to him stand (presumably) Abraham Lincoln, Ronald Reagan, Thomas Jefferson and George Washington, who hold out their hands to him as they look beseechingly to the figure on the right: Barack Obama. Obama stands aloof, arms folded, looking away, surrounded by an applauding gaggle including Bill Clinton and Franklin Roosevelt. Founding father James Madison beckons towards Obama’s feet in a “What are you doing?” gesture. Under Obama’s right foot is the US Constitution.

The Forgotten Man, by Jon McNaughton. Photograph: Jon McNaughton

It won’t win any prizes for either artistic merit or subtlety, but McNaughton’s painting has come to national prominence. Donald Trump even obliquely referenced it in his victory speech last week, stating that “the forgotten men and women of our country will no longer be forgotten”. Later that night, Fox News anchor Sean Hannity, a stalwart supporter of both Trump and McNaughton, pulled up a full-screen image of The Forgotten Man on his show. “He’s the one that has been left out,” Hannity explained. “The people of Wisconsin, Ohio, Iowa, the people of Michigan, Pennsylvania and all across this country, they saw this election for what it was: massive government failure … a precipitous decline in this country, and men and women, our fellow citizens forgotten, like that guy on the bench. That’s what this is about.” A few days later, according to McNaughton, Hannity purchased the painting. He plans to present it to Trump to hang in the White House.
title: The Forgotten Man: a fitting oil painting for Trump's America

Obama stands aloof, arms folded, looking away, surrounded by an applauding gaggle including Bill Clinton and Franklin Roosevelt. Founding father James Madison beckons towards Obama’s feet in a “What are you doing?” gesture. Under Obama’s right foot is the US Constitution.

The Forgotten Man, by Jon McNaughton. Photograph: Jon McNaughton

It won’t win any prizes for either artistic merit or subtlety, but McNaughton’s painting has come to national prominence. Donald Trump even obliquely referenced it in his victory speech last week, stating that “the forgotten men and women of our country will no longer be forgotten”. Later that night, Fox News anchor Sean Hannity, a stalwart supporter of both Trump and McNaughton, pulled up a full-screen image of The Forgotten Man on his show. “He’s the one that has been left out,” Hannity explained. “The people of Wisconsin, Ohio, Iowa, the people of Michigan, Pennsylvania and all across this country, they saw this election for what it was: massive government failure … a precipitous decline in this country, and men and women, our fellow citizens forgotten, like that guy on the bench. That’s what this is about.” A few days later, according to McNaughton, Hannity purchased the painting. He plans to present it to Trump to hang in the White House.
title: The Forgotten Man: a fitting oil painting for Trump's America

comments:
This is the type of Indignista feedback loop that so many people I know are tired of.
No one really cares about some painting that a talk-show host bought. In the Real World, where people have Real Problems, the fact that OP does not like some painting by an unknown, bought by a deliberatly confrontational political talking head rates signficantly lower than a broken shoelace.
I am sure Mr. Hannity will dedicate time on his show in his equally indignanat response to this column, allowing OP to write another column in even more indignant response.
I accept that some people like this sort of rousing of the media rabble. But, I strongly suspect that most don't.
Come on, Guardian. You want me to pay for your quality journalism? I am inclined to, but I need to see more of it, and less ideological click-baiting.||I will never be able to unsee this abomination. I am minded to sue this bastard.||The painting's called "The forgotten man", but where are the women?||They couldn't give a f**k about you forgotten man. browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
Human Rights Act? By May? Who still doesn't care who Britain sells weapons to? Who has yet to say anything about the EU migrants in the UK? Who accepts EU migrants to be seen as a bargaining chip? Is this the leader who will fight for the Human Rights Act? Sorry not my cup of tea||The Human Rights Act not only saved Gary McKinnon but it also gave the Hillsborough families justice after years of State cover up.
Kick this ladder away, and yet more rights of the disenfranchised majority will be removed from them whilst the State wallows in its riches and legal immunities.
It is vital that the HRA is preserved||Why do we insist on making these one-sided deals with the USA?||The Human Rights Act deserves to be deported.
It has been little more than a gravy train for left wing lawyers, especially Parliamentary ones, to pursue their political aims at vast taxpayer expense.
Had it been the Human Rights and Responsibilities Act, we might have done a bit better.
Another example of a format that rewards elites, and their pet projects such as Equality, handsomely by discriminating against and punishing ordinary people. 
Good riddance.||I would argue that the extradition treaties with the US are counter to human rights. Unfortunately, it seems that the human rights aspect can only be raised with regard to specific cases. (Of course, these may set a precedent, but they have not so far.) It is a failing of our democracies that these treaties can be signed and applied without parliamentary oversight as they do affect the rights of citizens.
The European Arrest Warrant system should also be drastically reformed. The Swedish case against Assange is legally flimsy at best, yet the English courts are prevented from looking at the case itself.
text:
In the early part of this century I gained unauthorised access to government computer systems in the US, in a successful attempt to find evidence of official knowledge of the UFO phenomenon. What followed was a decade-long nightmare. I slipped further and further into depression as the years wore on, having to take Prozac and regularly see a therapist. The emotional wear and tear on my family was one of the worst parts, watching them fight and mostly lose for 10 years.

Related: The Tories are using the army to take a shot at human rights | Conor Gearty
title: Theresa May saved my life – now she’s the only hope for the Human Rights Act

Gueye the only Everton player who looks like he understands what it takes to win a game of football.
text:
As a desperate game entered its final minute Swansea City were on the verge of their first victory under Bob Bradley. After 90, they were on the floor emotionally and literally as Seamus Coleman’s late equaliser steered them to the bottom of the Premier League. “Clearly the road ahead is long and hard,” rued their American coach. “But it is one we can definitely handle.”

The league table, a sequence of 11 Premier League fixtures without a win and the blow to morale dealt by Everton’s salvage operation suggests otherwise.
title: Seamus Coleman breaks Swansea hearts with late equaliser for Everton

Massive rebuilding job needed and I for one am not expecting much improvement this season on the Roberto years.||Ronald Koeman is clueless, arrogant and an unsettling disaster for Everton.||That's exactly the response I was looking for post Chelsea. Gueye the only Everton player who looks like he understands what it takes to win a game of football.
text:
As a desperate game entered its final minute Swansea City were on the verge of their first victory under Bob Bradley. After 90, they were on the floor emotionally and literally as Seamus Coleman’s late equaliser steered them to the bottom of the Premier League. “Clearly the road ahead is long and hard,” rued their American coach. “But it is one we can definitely handle.”

The league table, a sequence of 11 Premier League fixtures without a win and the blow to morale dealt by Everton’s salvage operation suggests otherwise.
title: Seamus Coleman breaks Swansea hearts with late equaliser for Everton

comments:
I was in NI on the 12 July. I watched in disbelief as they set fire to literally thousands of tyres in built up areas. What a strange place.
Sturgeon is a gem||The elephant in the room... who is going to say it?
Okay I will. Unionism - staunch, stubborn, backwards, Unionism. That's the problem in Northern Ireland. Old sectarians still fighting the war and fantasising about the good old days when the fenions knew their place. 
How is Northern Ireland ever going to move on, on anything including abortion, gay rights, and paramilitaries, when you have religious sectarianism embedded in stormont? The minister for education recently removed all references to the Irish language from the website after control went from sinn fein to the DUP. That's the level of pathetic we are taking about.
And, let's be honest, the unionists are still in charge. So until that changes expect little changes in Northern Ireland.||The list of decisions, beliefs, personnel, actions, "ideas", history which shames Stormont is hardly limited to its views on abortion. I'm ashamed they're part of the UK, ashamed that people who call themselves "Loyalist" think they are loyal to any kind of ideal that the rest of us grew out of 70 years ago.||The strange thing about gnus situation is, it's a portion of the Protestant Ulster Scotts (who claim such strong links to Britain via Scotland) who are against abortion in Northern Ireland, whilst the Catholics (who are traditionally against abortion due to the Vatican's stance on it) are in favour of bringing in a law allowing abortion in the six counties! So with the Scottish Parliament led by the (non-denominational) SNP offering to supply abortions free to women from NI, where exactly does that leave the loyalists loyalty? In tatters by the looks of it. And thus another pebble fell out of the wall that holds the Union together. Scotland with a re-joined Ireland will leave the UK and join Europe proper, fair thee well little England, and close the door behind you on your way out.||I think from now on we should accept that anything that 'enrages' the likes of the DUP is probably a Very Good Thing, and Sturgeon's proposal is just that.

. Independent polling published recently by Amnesty International showed that seven in 10 people want to see Northern Ireland’s harsh abortion laws changed, while more than half want to see abortion decriminalised altogether.

While hard right Unionists stay in government that's still a dream though it is clear that the Northern Irish establishment is fighting against the majority.
text:
Scotland and Northern Ireland are separated by just a few short miles of sea. But when it comes to access to abortion, they are divided by more than 150 years of history. While Scots women are able to access abortions on the same basis as their counterparts in England and Wales, Northern Irish women still face a near-total ban on the termination of pregnancy.

In 2014-15, only 16 women were able to have lawful abortions in Northern Ireland. By contrast, 833 Ulster women travelled to England or Wales and paid for terminations at private clinics. And despite being full and equal taxpayers, Northern Ireland-resident women have been barred from accessing free abortions in NHS hospitals in England, Wales and Scotland.
title: Scotland’s offer to give abortions to Northern Irish women shames Stormont

comments:
Oxford and Cambridge graduates (from whom 86% of high court judges are drawn)
I think I've spotted something else "embedded in the system."||Don't think racism is embedded in the system - just read the papers daily and see who are convicted.||Ought a judge be offering this opinion in such a public conversation?||What is much better in Britain is the law that gives equal rights to all. Other that the story is sad. The way police handle blacks and Indian/Pakistanis needs improvement. But things have got better in the last 40 years, when racism was open. I tried for a job in Oxford Street store for a salesman and was told straight: These jobs are for our own boys. That does not happen any more. Some say only the words have changed and the attitude is just as bad.||What i see in that picture is 4 Met officers, all of them white when a third of the adult population of London is non white, at least one of the officers ought to be non white.
text:
Britain often claims to possess the finest justice system in the world, with a “colour blind” approach to the law. Unfortunately, this isn’t true: justice is neither colour blind, nor is it equal.

Historically, the justice system has been used to legitimise slavery, and then colonialism, from Elizabethan England onwards. In Kenya, between 1951 and 1954, during the Mau Mau uprising, more than 1,090 Kenyans were executed by the British colonial judiciary, backed by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. This appalling figure represents the most liberal use of the death penalty in British legal history and is double the number of those executed by the French during the war of liberation in Algeria 10 years later.
title: As a judge, I can see the racism embedded in the system

I tried for a job in Oxford Street store for a salesman and was told straight: These jobs are for our own boys. That does not happen any more. Some say only the words have changed and the attitude is just as bad.||What i see in that picture is 4 Met officers, all of them white when a third of the adult population of London is non white, at least one of the officers ought to be non white.
text:
Britain often claims to possess the finest justice system in the world, with a “colour blind” approach to the law. Unfortunately, this isn’t true: justice is neither colour blind, nor is it equal.

Historically, the justice system has been used to legitimise slavery, and then colonialism, from Elizabethan England onwards. In Kenya, between 1951 and 1954, during the Mau Mau uprising, more than 1,090 Kenyans were executed by the British colonial judiciary, backed by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office. This appalling figure represents the most liberal use of the death penalty in British legal history and is double the number of those executed by the French during the war of liberation in Algeria 10 years later.
title: As a judge, I can see the racism embedded in the system

comments:
Vancarloads 'Men of The Year'
Myself (of course)Nigel FarageBoris JohnsonBurnley F.C.Sean Dyche (as manager of)Donald TrumpTyson Fury||As always Nigel will be in it for what is best for Nigel. The idea he will act in the interest of anyone other than himself is risible. The people who should be worried are the British and especially the British government. Trump really does not take the UK seriously. Maybe Nigel is jsut asking about getting a game show in the US.||Worst game of rock, paper, scissors ever.||At least Doonesbury has some great new material to work with.||You keep giving these two idiots too much coverage time. Massaging their narcissistic ego's and personalities by constantly writing about them is a mistake.
text:
You wonder how it’s possible to find the humour in the news at a time when the western world is starting to pivot towards an awkward dystopia and after a week when hostility and hate are no longer simmering just below the surface but are suddenly emboldened by Donald Trump’s election victory.

The sketch show Saturday Night Live gave up on comedy entirely, sitting Kate McKinnon as Hillary Clinton at a piano, performing a version of Leonard Cohen’s Hallelujah. Rarely has the traditional “Live from New York, it’s Saturday night!” intro been delivered with such raw hurt and defiance. It was powerful. It was deeply emotional. But it wasn’t funny.
title: At any other time, this Trump-Farage picture would be funny

comments:
Not just our duty, may just be fair to call them our 'reparations'!||Perhaps Hilary Benn ought to give a rousing speech in the commons advocating for it.||There is no beating about the bush. Nothing in the history of this benighted region, no brutal king, no imperial satrap, no Ba’athist rogue, initiated anything as horrific as what came in the train of George W Bush’s 2003 invasion of Iraq.
The Mongol invasion was supposedly quite unpleasant.||It should be rebuilt, but drop all the sanctimonious religious humbuggery about 'sin' and 'atonement'. It should be rebuilt because it was beautiful and the barbarians cannot be allowed to win.||Also, rebuild Bablyon.. just to get that prophecy running!!
text:
The destruction of the Assyrian city of Nimrud is a catastrophe for Iraq and for our shared cultural history. Peoples come and go, drifting in the mists of time. These relics were the rocks of ages. The bulldozing by Islamic State of Nineveh, the flattening of Hatra, the demolition in Raqqa and now the destruction of Nimrud wipe from the map what were the great precursor cities of the European era.

There is no beating about the bush. Nothing in the history of this benighted region, no brutal king, no imperial satrap, no Ba’athist rogue, initiated anything as horrific as what came in the train of George W Bush’s 2003 invasion of Iraq. By deliberately destroying order and government in Baghdad and sowing chaos, the American and British invaders created a hell on Earth. There is no truer maxim than that a lifetime of tyranny is better than a week of anarchy.
title: Rebuilding Nimrud will help atone for the sins of the west

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
Any chance of drafting Japan into the 6 nations? Please.||Japan brilliant, Wales boring, slow and predictable much as Eddie Butler's 'commentary'. The bloke is bias as you like and his whining over the Japanese kicker, jesus h, what a sad, pathetic old man, the BBC should get shot of him, he's a relic of the worst kind, just like that other RU 'old boy'. The few additional seconds the kicker took was easily overlooked when you compare how their handling and excellent tactics were compared to the Welsh, they looked all over the shop and couldn't figure out that Japan weren't going to commit numbers to the ruck so had plenty to defend.The Welsh wouldn't have won but for that terrible forward pass decision in the first half when it looked likeJapan were on for a 100m try. If they don't book their ideas up they're going to be wooden spoon winners come the 6 nations!||Well played Japan. They are heading the right direction and are enjoyable to watch.
Cuthbert had a bit of a shocker.||I still bet Gatland will pick 11/15 Welsh players for the Lions.||First off - if i have to here Jiffy and Butler announcing everything a welshman does as 'brilliant' once more i'll scream. Halfpenny catches a ball 'brilliant catch' - no it's just a catch, thats what he's supposed to do! Really enjoyed them annoucing Liam Williams as a great high ball catcher and I don't think he caught one.
Second, are there no better wings in Wales than Alex Cuthbert? Seriously?
text:
Lacking control, confidence and at times the slightest clue, Wales stumbled over the line thanks to a last-gasp drop goal from Sam Davies against an inspired Japan side who came agonisingly close to another giant-killing on their return to British soil.

But for Davies’s late intervention Wales were staring down the barrel of a draw against Japan – thoroughly deserved by their exhilarating visitors who produced the kind of speed and accuracy that felled the Springboks last September and of which Rob Howley’s side can only dream.
title: Wales are run close by inspired Japan before late Sam Davies drop goal

comments:
This man has done a far better job than the damn conservatives.||" Jacob Rees-Mogg, who was bizarrely touted as a potential replacement for Carney"
Jesus! If that happens I know I'm trapped in a bizarre alien gameshow||Mr Carney was the only grown-up left in the room when the referendum went in a different direction from the one the Cameron administration had planned and expected.
While the Tories indulged in infighting, and are left with a leader who was last woman standing, Labour descended into irrelevance. We are left with a government that for all the appearance of "unity" is deeply divided behind closed doors, and the leader of the opposition is not regarded as a potential alternative to the mediocre team currently in power.
Had he announced that he was walking away in 2018, given the sniping from the likes of odd-balls such as Rees Mogg, who could have blamed him? The compromise where he stays until the country is expected to leave the EU is therefore a relief.
Who will the chancellor appoint to succeed Mr Carney? Given all the sniping from the usual suspects, that could prove "interesting."||If Rees-Mogg is not just another pompous narcissist, he will ask Mark Carney some pertinent questions, such as
"Do you still believe that Quantitative Easing has any legitimacy, when its biggest practitioner, the USA, seems to only have perpetuated the inequality in the economic system that has lifted Donald Trump to victory?" 
and following Carney's predictably self-righteous reply,
"If you are so convinced, consider this. If there were a choice of the independent Bank of England distributing £100 billion through its QE programme, OR the Government injecting £100 billion directly into the NHS, which would you prefer the public to enjoy?"
and when Carney announces he would like to see both the fiscal and monetary stimulii occurring simultaneously
"You wish us to believe that the monetary stimulus is still useful and necessary alongside the fiscal stimulus? If the only achievement of the monetary stimulus is to drive down borrowing costs, whether to the Treasury or the Private Sector, do you at least accept that they have failed to re-structure the economic systems which currently favour the asset-owning wealthy over the majority?"||Worker and consumer representatives on Boards?Those big pink things have just got landing slots at the new Heathrow airport.So, the proposal will be put forward, if the Boards vote in favour and if the shareholders vote in favour and if there is not an R in the month and if ......
text:
It feels like a long time since economy-watchers were gripped by the saga about how long Mark Carney would stay at the Bank of England. In fact it was only two weeks ago that the governor agreed to extend his term by a year to 2019 after an apparent attempt by various Conservatives to drive him out as soon as possible.

His critics were emboldened by Theresa May’s criticism of recent monetary policy in her conference speech, but in the end May needed Carney – and his decision came across as if he’d granted the prime minister another year of his time.
title: Carney back to face the Conservatives

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; SM-G900W8 Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.85 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
Many of the problems that you outline, in what is always a stressful time, are ones of administration and nothing more.
How about ..... you find a lump, and you go, without waiting for an appointment to have your mammogram. 10 minutes after your mammogram a doctor sees you and tells you the initial results, face to face. You have already given him your previous mammogram x-rays, because comparison with previous x-rays will show whether or not there are changes that are significant. You see, YOU had your previous mamograms. If all is clear, you'll get your latest ones too.
Perhaps you need a blood test. The doctor gives you a prescription for an enormous number of tests to be done, or just one or two. You take the prescription, without an appointment, and have the blood tests done, and YOU pick up the results perhaps a few hours, or at most 30 hours later. You could show them to your doctor, but all the results come with your figures, the "normal" range of results, and your results from last time. So if one figure reads "6%" is that good or bad ..... Let's look - the "normal range" is 3% to 9%, so you're bang in the middle, and last time you were 5.9% Perhaps there's one that looks abnormal? In that case, visit the doc, or phone him up. But YOU keep your results. They can't get lost in a vast array of people's results. YOUR x-rays can't get muddled with someone else's ankle x-rays, because YOU have them!
What am I describing - life as it has been since we moved to the French system. My wife's mammogram x-rays sit at an arm's length from where I write this. Our blood test results are in a file six feet away.
WHY should we pay the NHS, and particularly a||If you keep your own results it is easier. You can do this even within the NHS - I have copies of x-rays (at £*** a shot well worth it). The same is available for scans. More more for NHS to provide but a good source of income I imagine. There is one thing people here don't do which is vital - learn to ASK.||Of course, desperately underfunded. But also suffering from a sea of over management and narrow remit and you depict that very well.||Both times my father was diagnosed with cancer (lung and prostrate) he was treated incredibly quickly. Everyone was very impressed, because my experience with the NHS has been nothing but shit. The swiftness of everything was mindblowing.
That said - we are largely in control of our risk to different types of cancers. DIET plays a huge role. Wholefood plant based diet is the way to go....||Targets are important: the more we spend on cancer, the less we spend on disabling pain...
text:
I have a nice, flat stomach. However many chips I eat, I still have a nice, flat stomach. I’d like to say it’s flat because I do a lot of sit-ups. But I don’t. I have a nice, flat stomach because, six years ago, a surgeon chopped a great big chunk of it off. He put the flesh, and some blood vessels, in the space where another surgeon had just removed my breast. I lost a bulge and gained a breast, or something that looks very like a breast. I also gained a life.

Related: The gap between funds and delivery is a chasm in the NHS: something has to give | Chris Hopson
title: Targets matter – because a day with cancer worries feels like a year

You could show them to your doctor, but all the results come with your figures, the "normal" range of results, and your results from last time. So if one figure reads "6%" is that good or bad ..... Let's look - the "normal range" is 3% to 9%, so you're bang in the middle, and last time you were 5.9% Perhaps there's one that looks abnormal? In that case, visit the doc, or phone him up. But YOU keep your results. They can't get lost in a vast array of people's results. YOUR x-rays can't get muddled with someone else's ankle x-rays, because YOU have them!
What am I describing - life as it has been since we moved to the French system. My wife's mammogram x-rays sit at an arm's length from where I write this. Our blood test results are in a file six feet away.
WHY should we pay the NHS, and particularly a||If you keep your own results it is easier. You can do this even within the NHS - I have copies of x-rays (at £*** a shot well worth it). The same is available for scans. More more for NHS to provide but a good source of income I imagine. There is one thing people here don't do which is vital - learn to ASK.||Of course, desperately underfunded. But also suffering from a sea of over management and narrow remit and you depict that very well.||Both times my father was diagnosed with cancer (lung and prostrate) he was treated incredibly quickly. Everyone was very impressed, because my experience with the NHS has been nothing but shit. The swiftness of everything was mindblowing.
That said - we are largely in control of our risk to different types of cancers. DIET plays a huge role. Wholefood plant based diet is the way to go....||Targets are important: the more we spend on cancer, the less we spend on disabling pain...
text:
I have a nice, flat stomach. However many chips I eat, I still have a nice, flat stomach. I’d like to say it’s flat because I do a lot of sit-ups. But I don’t. I have a nice, flat stomach because, six years ago, a surgeon chopped a great big chunk of it off. He put the flesh, and some blood vessels, in the space where another surgeon had just removed my breast. I lost a bulge and gained a breast, or something that looks very like a breast. I also gained a life.

Related: The gap between funds and delivery is a chasm in the NHS: something has to give | Chris Hopson
title: Targets matter – because a day with cancer worries feels like a year

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
I liked his music, but the lyrics could be homophobic: 'anal sex...shove it up the hole in your culture'.||2016: the year that keeps on taking...||Damn you 2016. Is it possible to hate a year? This year has been a fearful harvest of the best.||Oh, the sisters of mercy, they are not departed or goneThey were waiting for me when I thought that I just can't go onAnd they brought me their comfort and later they brought me this song...
If your life is a leaf that the seasons tear off and condemnThey will bind you with love that is graceful and green as a stem...
...I hope you run into them soonDon't turn on the light, you can read their address by the moonAnd you won't make me jealous if I hear that they sweetened your nightWe weren't lovers like that and besides, it would still be all right.
Thank you, Leonard and Robert. RIP.||Leonard Cohen had the unique ability to preserve and enhance the poetry in his chosen words by creating melodies that became inseparable from them, fused with his unforgettable voice that seemed to come from eternity. He and his poetry will grow brighter as time passes.
text:
Leonard Cohen once called himself “a ninth-rate practitioner in a great tradition” but he’ll be remembered as more than that. His best lines will remain, subtle and tough like a poacher’s snares to pull tight the knot of pleasure and apprehension around readers who stumble into them long after his obituaries are forgotten. That is something of what it means to be part of a tradition: to strike up new conversations even when you’re dead. Memory and poetry are closely entwined. Poems live in memory or not at all and, while they do, they help to shape the people who remember them.

This has been a year, indeed a week, that will be grimly remembered for decades, but it is also a year in which we remember many horrors of the past. The slaughter at the Bataclan nightclub in Paris was exactly a year ago. A concert by Sting will commemorate this and at the same time try to change its meaning and show that music can’t be permanently silenced with gunfire.
title: The Guardian view on Leonard Cohen: art lasts; life doesn’t

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
Fly Emirates Red 2 Fly Emirates Blue 2 
But it's fair to say PSG were the better side in both games.
Will Arsenal get through the Round of Arsenal tho?||The good news? Arsenal don't know how to lose. Through brilliance (at times), grit (some), and luck (a lot of it), they have not lost since the opening of the domestic season when half their players were on holiday or injured.
The bad news? We're getting Barcelona or Real Madrid in the next round.||Given the possible opponents (Including Bayern, Dortmund and Real...maybe even Juve), is second place really better than finishing first?
We're gonna draw Barca again, aren't we?||Oh Arsenal. So close, yet so far again. While not at full strength, it’s no excuse for letting a lead slip, and especially not a soft one from a corner. Same old, same old. Mediocre performance overall, and it may cost them, the draw is hard whether you’re top or 2nd, but it is still easier to be seeded. 
PSG were quite good, but Cavani doesn’t shake off that ‘big chance bottler’ tag despite scoring, he’s like a Southampton striker! They don’t seem as strong as previous years but will still present a big challenge to any team they meet.||Nobody should take away from a brilliantly intense match played out between two sides fighting for top group but does it matter if Arsenal finish top of the group? Bayern, Real Madrid or Sevilla could face Arsenal in the R16 as second place or Dortmund, Juventus, Barcelona or Atletico should Arsenal slip up at Basel and finish second.
It's almost inevitable that Arsenal shall limp out in the first knockout tie next year.
text:
The sense of deflation which grumbled around the majority of supporters left in this arena at the final whistle told its own story. Arsenal have passed up an opportunity to win Group A and given that Paris Saint-Germain may not grant them a second chance, will approach the weeks ahead with a familiar sense of dread as to what awaits in the new year. The last round of fixtures may yet conjure a reprieve but that seems unlikely. The initiative is undoubtedly with the French club.

It seems inconceivable that PSG, now top of Group A and bolstered by a better head-to-head record with the Gunners, could fail to see off Ludogorets at Parc des Princes on the night Arsenal complete their group campaign with a far trickier game at Basel. Finishing second could condemn Arsène Wenger’s side to a daunting collision with any of Barcelona, Juventus or Atlético Madrid in the first knockout round. “At the moment we are second, but it’s not over,” offered Wenger, optimistically. “But if we do finish there, you can’t guess whether that’s good or bad. You have to wait for the draw.” In truth, Arsenal have learned through bitter experience what a failure to secure first place tends to produce.
title: PSG and Lucas draw Arsenal’s sting to seize initiative in Group A

Finishing second could condemn Arsène Wenger’s side to a daunting collision with any of Barcelona, Juventus or Atlético Madrid in the first knockout round. “At the moment we are second, but it’s not over,” offered Wenger, optimistically. “But if we do finish there, you can’t guess whether that’s good or bad. You have to wait for the draw.” In truth, Arsenal have learned through bitter experience what a failure to secure first place tends to produce.
title: PSG and Lucas draw Arsenal’s sting to seize initiative in Group A

comments:
Hamilton will win, Rosberg will come second. It's all very predictable.
Hopefully the new rules next year will inject some more excitement. Interlagos served as a reminder of how tremendous F1 can be , and sadly underlined how boring it has become.
Rosberg is going to be champion, and he's only had one competitor, who he has beaten only because luck has gone his way. It's not great sport, is it?||Has Rosberg got the balls to drive into Hamilton at the first corner+take them both out of the race?||Realistically the Mercedes should be able to use their advantage for one last time on Yas Marina's long straights and exits from slow corners (the heart of where the dominating has sat). So don't see Red Bull getting too involved unless one or both Mercedes run into trouble or mistakes.
Due to next year's changes, this could be Rosberg's and Hamilton's last 'easy' chance for the title for a couple of years at least, if not their entire careers.||only way for Hamilton to win is a rosberg DNF....need Lewis to sidle up to max and whisper "nico said you're a lady boy who can't overtake...."||Channel 4’s F1 commentator Ben Edwards is hoping that Hamilton does not just blame mechanical failures if he loses out.
Are you suggesting that TV audiences be sold a different story? If Hamilton hadn't had a bad run of luck with mechanical failures he would be champion wouldn't he?
text:
In Abu Dhabi this weekend Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg will – metaphorically at least – touch gloves like a couple of heavyweights as the bell chimes for the final round. The Mercedes duo’s slugfest for the Formula One world championship has endured for eight months and 20 rounds and the Yas Marina Circuit has got what it paid for: the decider.

Rosberg, with a 12-point lead, is the clear favourite to win his first title, for he has only to finish in the top three. It is the fifth time in eight years, since Hamilton snatched his first championship from the grasp of the home favourite, Felipe Massa, in São Paulo, that the title race has gone to the wire. Last year Hamilton got home in Austin with three races to spare but we were here in Abu Dhabi two years ago, the year of the double points fiasco, when Hamilton was required to finish in the top two – instead of the leading six – to take the championship; he won.
title: F1 title race goes to the wire in Abu Dhabi but will Red Bulls have a final say?

Who to blame? GBBO.||Post prexit you will neither have the original Italian one nor the new French kind ;)||They were always the easiest but special gift of choice to bring back from their little shop in Paris,little transportable French treats which were oohed and aahed over. Then suddenly you could buy them everywhere. Still easy, but special? Not so much.||Seems like most of the author's issues with macarons can be solved by simply not buying ones flavoured in a way she doesn't like. Chocolate macarons are delicious!||I think you need to read this article...
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/nov/20/nostalgia-political-poison-strictly-bake-off
text:
In the crazy days before Christmas, I have sometimes, in extremis, swung into Ladurée on Piccadilly, and handed over stupid cash in exchange for small, pistachio-green parcels of multi-coloured macarons. The shop, conveniently situated (for me) right by the number 38 bus stop at one end of the Burlington Arcade, resembles a tiny, golden cave, and something about it – the feeling, perhaps, that you have stepped into the realm of fairies and hobbits, which in a way, of course, you have – encourages the harried shopper to drop her guard. Yes, you know that Ladurée is all over the place now, a chain like any other (it belongs to the same group of businesses as the bakery Paul). Yes, you know, too, that macarons can be picked up at Sainsbury’s and Marks & Spencer’s these days. But still – quelle disastre – the finger goes out, pointing at those seductive shades you believe will look prettiest lined up in the box.

When did we fall for macarons? And why? In my childhood, I knew only of macaroons: little domes of almond or coconut, bound with egg white and perched on a disc of rice paper, that were so easy to make, your mum was inclined to depart the kitchen, possibly in search of a gin, as you set to work with the mixing bowl. They were, even then, an old-fashioned treat, and a bit comical for that; not for nothing did Victoria Wood and Julie Walters send them up in Acorn Antiques. But at school fetes and Brownie bring-and-buys, they were always the second thing to go (the first were the endless trays of chocolate cornflake crispies).
title: Why the macaron is a pastel menace

In my childhood, I knew only of macaroons: little domes of almond or coconut, bound with egg white and perched on a disc of rice paper, that were so easy to make, your mum was inclined to depart the kitchen, possibly in search of a gin, as you set to work with the mixing bowl. They were, even then, an old-fashioned treat, and a bit comical for that; not for nothing did Victoria Wood and Julie Walters send them up in Acorn Antiques. But at school fetes and Brownie bring-and-buys, they were always the second thing to go (the first were the endless trays of chocolate cornflake crispies).

text:
In the crazy days before Christmas, I have sometimes, in extremis, swung into Ladurée on Piccadilly, and handed over stupid cash in exchange for small, pistachio-green parcels of multi-coloured macarons. The shop, conveniently situated (for me) right by the number 38 bus stop at one end of the Burlington Arcade, resembles a tiny, golden cave, and something about it – the feeling, perhaps, that you have stepped into the realm of fairies and hobbits, which in a way, of course, you have – encourages the harried shopper to drop her guard. Yes, you know that Ladurée is all over the place now, a chain like any other (it belongs to the same group of businesses as the bakery Paul). Yes, you know, too, that macarons can be picked up at Sainsbury’s and Marks & Spencer’s these days. But still – quelle disastre – the finger goes out, pointing at those seductive shades you believe will look prettiest lined up in the box.

They were, even then, an old-fashioned treat, and a bit comical for that; not for nothing did Victoria Wood and Julie Walters send them up in Acorn Antiques. But at school fetes and Brownie bring-and-buys, they were always the second thing to go (the first were the endless trays of chocolate cornflake crispies).
