comments:
Hello, Quaker Social Action here. Thank you, Dawn for shining a light on this issue. We are incredibly proud of our three Down to Earth colleagues who work tirelessly to help people across the country like Eva.
Anyone on a low income struggling with funeral costs can contact our free practical support service, Down to Earth.
Thank you to all of our supporters who make this work possible.||This is what happens when capitalism gets out of control. But people (the media owners) seem to want more capitalism and less socialism. So get used to this sort of thing. Why blame a funeral director for getting rich from other people's misery more than you'd blame a bank manager, NHS service provider CEO, etc.||As I've just posted on twitter, I've worked in social security for over 20 years and after a while, you think you've seen and heard it all. Yet, the case highlighted has really shook me and made me feel sick to the stomach. I've taken a case year's ago to argue as to whether a coffin was a "necessary expense" for a funeral. The commissioner (as was then) allowed the appeal and said that even though it wasn't a legal necessity, it was clearly something that most people expected as part of a decent burial. DWP response? Change the regulations immediately to exclude the cost of a coffin. We now seem to have entered an even darker realm here. Good on the Quakers for trying to help raise the profile and provide assistance.||Can someone tell me if the good quaker people were not there what is the position ?||Fake UK, Fake Humanity - the 5th richest state in the World.
text:
Any death is hard, but the unnatural experience of burying your own child is particularly traumatic. When 17-year-old Eva went into labour at 22 weeks she was worried. Her daughter was born, but didn’t take a breath before dying. This small fact, in an already hellish situation, became crucial later on. Eva worked 16 hours a week in a local shop in east London, but paying the capital’s exorbitant rents as well as earning little meant she was unable to afford the funeral costs. She applied for financial help from the Social Fund – state funding to help people on low incomes with one-off or occasional expenses such as funeral payments – but was informed by an adviser that Department for Work & Pensions (DWP) rules meant that as her daughter had not reached 24 weeks gestation, or taken a breath, she was classified as “medical waste” in bureaucratic terms.

Related: Avoid the funeral sting: how to die for less than £1,000
title: ‘Parents have to borrow from loan sharks to pay for their child’s funeral’

comments:
Got my tickets. Really looking forward to the game! Hopefully, a belter.||Afternoon all. 
Hope you all enjoy; was a privilege to speak to the great man on Tuesday. Hard to believe it's the last time we'll see him in the flesh on these shores: makes you feel a bit sad really. But still, for one last time JT..||Really looking forward to seeing him play one lat time over here. Doesn't seem that long since he destroyed us at Elland Rd back in 2009. Being doing it ever since of course.||Like all great players in any sport JT makes what looks difficult or impossible for everyday players look simple, but to me his greatest asset seems to be the person he is both on and off the pitch, in this modern world where sports achievements generally blown up out of all proportion this guy just gets on with life in a low key sort of way, he seems incredibly proud of his heritage. Thanks JT for the pleasure and the pain.||He had the ball on a string against the Rhinos earlier on in the year. The way he creates space for others, whether it by be a slight change of angle, delay of a pass, or taking the pace out the move so slightly or adding a little bit.....those little variations he adds to a play which make a class above everyone else.
Fantastic player, and by the sounds of it, top bloke too. Tip of the hat to you Jonathan Thurston.
text:
The disappointment surrounding England’s failure to reach the Four Nations final is fresh in the memory but as one of the sport’s greatest players prepares for his final appearance in the UK on Sunday there is at least an opportunity to enjoy watching a master at work rather than be tormented by his talents all over again.

Johnathan Thurston’s time in England has been garlanded with success: a Four Nations winner twice in this country, a World Cup victory in 2013, victory in this year’s World Club Challenge with North Queensland, and now he lines up in the Four Nations final against New Zealand.
title: Australia’s Johnathan Thurston prepares for emotional farewell to England

The disappointment surrounding England’s failure to reach the Four Nations final is fresh in the memory but as one of the sport’s greatest players prepares for his final appearance in the UK on Sunday there is at least an opportunity to enjoy watching a master at work rather than be tormented by his talents all over again.

Johnathan Thurston’s time in England has been garlanded with success: a Four Nations winner twice in this country, a World Cup victory in 2013, victory in this year’s World Club Challenge with North Queensland, and now he lines up in the Four Nations final against New Zealand.
title: Australia’s Johnathan Thurston prepares for emotional farewell to England

comments: Zadie Smith has also written nine fiction books one of which was Chaining my mind, which is worth reading. She represents modern England. She had a British father and a Jamaican mother. She is a great writer.||20% of modern England, perhaps?||If the book is good, this review doesn't do it justice.||I suspect it isn't very good. Barely plausible brushes with celebrity, a schmaltzy wish-fulfilment narrative custom-made for Hollywood , tedious diatribes about the 'shifting identity' of women (yawn) and Zadie Smith's trademark tiresome I'm-cooler-than-you eclectic cultural referencing. It's glorified chick lit, if the quotes are anything to go by. Hasn't anyone else noticed that she's an average writer who hasn't actually written a great novel since White Teeth? (OK, N-W did have its moments). She's actually a better journalist than a novelist - her recent piece comparing dancers was great. It's her connections in the left-wing journalism world that get her these glowing reviews, not the writing.||Might be is finest book but Zadie Smith remains an average writer with little talent.
text:
Swing Time is Zadie Smith’s fifth novel and for my money her finest. A “best friend bildungsroman” in the Elena Ferrante mould, the novel tells the story of two girls growing up on the wrong side of town. Residents of neighbouring housing estates in London, the pair meet at a community dance class, one (the unnamed narrator) clever and self-doubting, the other (Tracey) confident and self-destructive. As with the Italian bestseller, the talented friend is the tortured one – prematurely sexual, rebellious at school, ungoverned at home – while the less gifted is an able student, determined to make it out of the neighbourhood. It gives little away to say that she does, becoming an assistant to a pop star called Aimee. It is by Aimee’s side that she travels the world, jetting from winters to summers.

For its plot alone, Swing Time makes for truly marvellous reading. The narrator’s journey, from gritty estate to glittering globe and back again, is the juicy stuff of which film adaptations are made. And the music! If one were to make a playlist of the references, one would have a greatest hits of black music: from Gambian drummers to Cab Calloway to Michael Jackson to Rakim. What makes Swing Time so extraordinary are the layers on which it operates; beneath its virtuosic plotting lies the keenest social commentary.
title: Swing Time by Zadie Smith review – a classic story of betterment

comments:
We consider risk when we pay thousands of dollars extra for a car with air bags because the outcome of a very unlikely high speed collision is severe.
We do the same with fire insurance for our homes.
This rational approach to risk is completely missing when it comes to the environment.
And the thing is with global warming, not only is the outcome severe in the extreme, but the likelihood is very, very high that highly damaging impacts will occur.
According to the article Tail Risk vs. Alarmism, by Dr. Kerry Emanuel, the Cecil and Ida Green professor of atmospheric science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he has been on the faculty since 1981, we are on track to triple pre-industrial levels of atmospheric CO2 this century.
According to the IPCC graph supplied in the article that would give us a 5 percent chance of exceeding 6.75 degrees C above pre-industrial levels.
As Emanuel says in the article below:

http://climatechangenationalforum.org/tail-risk-vs-alarmism/||Seems likely that the tipping point has passed. We are also at the beginning of a mass extinction event.There was NEVER enough urgency, or cohesion, about addressing the issues of pollution, over population and climate instability, and the clock long since reached midnight.If Mr Trump holds to his views on this subject, it will be the latest tragic mistake in a very long line.||A reality TV celebrity declaring war on the earths' natural systems, the biosphere and all its' inhabitants..........will we all just sit back, watch and wait?||There has to be a way to stop Trump reneging on the pledges made by the US in Paris, to stop his denial of the problem and to force him to implement the necessary solutions. Otherwise we're all screwed. Period.
I know there will be many scientists, liberal politicians and environmental activists in the US protesting against the Trump plan. They are likely to be subjected to demonization and misinformation campaigns and it won't be enough - Trump & the GOP will do nothing unless some of the big corporations and the majority of American public opinion is against them. International governments may make protestations about US policy, but ultimately will do nothing, that's why it has to come from a grass roots movement.
Maybe there needs to be a campaign that calls for people to boycott goods and services provided by US companies in the UK; hopefully the campaign would spread to other countries. Boycotting all American companies would not be practical but there could be a small number targeted initially, such as Coca Cola, Pepsi, McDonald, Starbucks, KFC. This could become more encompassing as time went on until Trump gives in and changes tack.If the campaign took off and enough people were involved then Trump would be faced with enormous pressure at home from the big corporations and hopefully from public opinion when the American people realise how strong the feelings are in other countries about Trumps proposals.
Here in the UK, as with many countries we are not doing what we need to be doing to fully realise the targets we agreed to in Paris, but Trump is the only leader who says he is going to reject Paris and go full steam in the opposite direction; that, plus the size of the US and it's already high consumption levels and the effect that will have on the planet. In addition rather than other countries getting together to do more on climate, the US stance could give others an excuse to also renege. 
Also, if the campaign was successful it would put climate change in the spotlight and hopefully move it higher up the political agenda, and then the governments of those of us outside the US might feel pressured to do more.||Delegates have gathered in Marrakech
sounds like a lot of carbon being emanated with flights, cars and hotels
text:
Reaching a global agreement on climate change took more than 20 years of tortuous negotiations. Signed just under a year ago, the insufficient but workable Paris agreement at last constructed a legally binding framework for the principle of cutting carbon emissions. It was to be the foundation of a sustained ratcheting up of ambition that would hold global warming below 2C. Last Tuesday night, as one by one from east coast to west the United States went Republican red, that progress was wiped out.

Donald Trump is the first self-declared climate denier to lead of one of the world’s biggest emitters. Even President George W Bush, though he surrounded himself with sceptics, did not publicly disavow climate science. He even managed a few helpful moves. But Mr Trump has pledged to unpick the Paris agreement. In Marrakech, where delegates are meeting for the first time since Paris, they are putting a brave face on proceedings. But they know the outlook is bleaker than it has been since the collapse of the Copenhagen talks in 2009.
title: The Guardian view on climate change: Trump spells disaster

According to the article Tail Risk vs. Alarmism, by Dr. Kerry Emanuel, the Cecil and Ida Green professor of atmospheric science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he has been on the faculty since 1981, we are on track to triple pre-industrial levels of atmospheric CO2 this century.
According to the IPCC graph supplied in the article that would give us a 5 percent chance of exceeding 6.75 degrees C above pre-industrial levels.
As Emanuel says in the article below:

http://climatechangenationalforum.org/tail-risk-vs-alarmism/||Seems likely that the tipping point has passed. We are also at the beginning of a mass extinction event.There was NEVER enough urgency, or cohesion, about addressing the issues of pollution, over population and climate instability, and the clock long since reached midnight.If Mr Trump holds to his views on this subject, it will be the latest tragic mistake in a very long line.||A reality TV celebrity declaring war on the earths' natural systems, the biosphere and all its' inhabitants..........will we all just sit back, watch and wait?||There has to be a way to stop Trump reneging on the pledges made by the US in Paris, to stop his denial of the problem and to force him to implement the necessary solutions. Otherwise we're all screwed. Period.
I know there will be many scientists, liberal politicians and environmental activists in the US protesting against the Trump plan. They are likely to be subjected to demonization and misinformation campaigns and it won't be enough - Trump & the GOP will do nothing unless some of the big corporations and the majority of American public opinion is against them. International governments may make protestations about US policy, but ultimately will do nothing, that's why it has to come from a grass roots movement.
Maybe there needs to be a campaign that calls for people to boycott goods and services provided by US companies in the UK; hopefully the campaign would spread to other countries. Boycotting all American companies would not be practical but there could be a small number targeted initially, such as Coca Cola, Pepsi, McDonald, Starbucks, KFC. This could become more encompassing as time went on until Trump gives in and changes tack.If the campaign took off and enough people were involved then Trump would be faced with enormous pressure at home from the big corporations and hopefully from public opinion when the American people realise how strong the feelings are in other countries about Trumps proposals.
Here in the UK, as with many countries we are not doing what we need to be doing to fully realise the targets we agreed to in Paris, but Trump is the only leader who says he is going to reject Paris and go full steam in the opposite direction; that, plus the size of the US and it's already high consumption levels and the effect that will have on the planet. In addition rather than other countries getting together to do more on climate, the US stance could give others an excuse to also renege. 
Also, if the campaign was successful it would put climate change in the spotlight and hopefully move it higher up the political agenda, and then the governments of those of us outside the US might feel pressured to do more.||Delegates have gathered in Marrakech
sounds like a lot of carbon being emanated with flights, cars and hotels
text:
Reaching a global agreement on climate change took more than 20 years of tortuous negotiations. Signed just under a year ago, the insufficient but workable Paris agreement at last constructed a legally binding framework for the principle of cutting carbon emissions. It was to be the foundation of a sustained ratcheting up of ambition that would hold global warming below 2C. Last Tuesday night, as one by one from east coast to west the United States went Republican red, that progress was wiped out.

Donald Trump is the first self-declared climate denier to lead of one of the world’s biggest emitters. Even President George W Bush, though he surrounded himself with sceptics, did not publicly disavow climate science. He even managed a few helpful moves. But Mr Trump has pledged to unpick the Paris agreement. In Marrakech, where delegates are meeting for the first time since Paris, they are putting a brave face on proceedings. But they know the outlook is bleaker than it has been since the collapse of the Copenhagen talks in 2009.
title: The Guardian view on climate change: Trump spells disaster

comments:
Bernie Sanders, meanwhile, is becoming the de facto leader of the American opposition, warning that he would be Trump’s “worst nightmare” if he turned his supporters’ anger on minorities. 
The most interesting thing was Sanders' insistence he'd work with Trump if he persevered with those aspects of his stated economic policy which were far to the left of the Obama/Clinton wing of the Democrats.||Resist him by ceasing to push the ‘victim group’ view of the world. It’s divisive and counter-productive – this is not opinion, but now proven fact. The view of the world as divided into competing identities has both fed Trump and given his support base a language in which to express themselves.||Trump and Brexit. 2016 ladies and gentleman. Broken society.||America voted for a black president twice. 
They haven't all joined the Klan in the last four years.||Another way to resist Trump would be for progressives to formulate a view on mass immigration and integration that doesn’t amount to ‘immigration controls are racist’.
text:
Donald Trump lost the popular vote: the second Republican candidate to do so yet still take the presidency in 16 years. He will be the most unpopular presidential candidate to take office since records began. He has a track record of opposing democratic norms, inciting violence against protesters and threatening to imprison his main opponent. His intolerance of political and media dissent is well documented; he now has the means to do something about it. His ghostwriter has called him a “sociopath” whose presidency risks “the end of civilisation”. He is appointing extremists to the White House: in a call for vigilance to the American people, Republican strategist John Weaver declared that “the racist, fascist extreme right is represented footsteps from the Oval Office”. His campaign exploited and incited hatred against Muslims, Mexican immigrants and women. Racists chose to celebrate his victory by launching hate crimes against American minorities. As John Oliver puts it, Trump being president “is not normal”, and his rule should never be normalised. His opponents should refuse to accept the legitimacy of this president and – like Republicans have done before – refuse to co-operate and begin a nonviolent war of political attrition.

John Oliver on Donald Trump: ‘A Klan-backed misogynist internet troll’

Hang on a minute: who am I as a Briton to interfere in the internal affairs of a foreign country? The problem is the entire world is now subject to the writ of the leader of the last superpower. We are all, to a degree, under his dominion. The American people have a struggle on their hands, not just to preserve their democracy and republic, but to fight for the rest of us, too. There is a long tradition of marching in solidarity with people in foreign countries standing against their own rulers.
title: A win for Trump was a win for bigotry. Here’s how we resist him

The view of the world as divided into competing identities has both fed Trump and given his support base a language in which to express themselves.||Trump and Brexit. 2016 ladies and gentleman. Broken society.||America voted for a black president twice. 
They haven't all joined the Klan in the last four years.||Another way to resist Trump would be for progressives to formulate a view on mass immigration and integration that doesn’t amount to ‘immigration controls are racist’.
text:
Donald Trump lost the popular vote: the second Republican candidate to do so yet still take the presidency in 16 years. He will be the most unpopular presidential candidate to take office since records began. He has a track record of opposing democratic norms, inciting violence against protesters and threatening to imprison his main opponent. His intolerance of political and media dissent is well documented; he now has the means to do something about it. His ghostwriter has called him a “sociopath” whose presidency risks “the end of civilisation”. He is appointing extremists to the White House: in a call for vigilance to the American people, Republican strategist John Weaver declared that “the racist, fascist extreme right is represented footsteps from the Oval Office”. His campaign exploited and incited hatred against Muslims, Mexican immigrants and women. Racists chose to celebrate his victory by launching hate crimes against American minorities. As John Oliver puts it, Trump being president “is not normal”, and his rule should never be normalised. His opponents should refuse to accept the legitimacy of this president and – like Republicans have done before – refuse to co-operate and begin a nonviolent war of political attrition.

John Oliver on Donald Trump: ‘A Klan-backed misogynist internet troll’

Hang on a minute: who am I as a Briton to interfere in the internal affairs of a foreign country? The problem is the entire world is now subject to the writ of the leader of the last superpower. We are all, to a degree, under his dominion. The American people have a struggle on their hands, not just to preserve their democracy and republic, but to fight for the rest of us, too. There is a long tradition of marching in solidarity with people in foreign countries standing against their own rulers.
title: A win for Trump was a win for bigotry. Here’s how we resist him

comments:
I wish.||Ian Jack always writes beautifully, IMO, but even by his standards that is brilliantly put.||This is quite untrue. Reciprocal arrangements exist where emergency situations are dealt with by the nearest emergency services. Patients are taken to the nearest casualty department.||Odd that Dumfries and Galloway is full of Gaelic names, then, intit.

He’s far keener on a historical country of his own invention – what he calls the Middleland, described by his son as “an upland landscape, whose core is the Lake District hills, the Pennines, the Cheviots and the Scottish Borders … a land naturally unified by geography and culture for 2,000 years, but repeatedly divided by political frontiers”.

An entirely imaginary construct, perhaps created to impress his constituents.
Rory Stewart is often bang on the money when talking about foreign affairs and is way too brainy to be a politician and a Tory. But it has to be remembered here that he's a staunch British Nationalist and ran his own somewhat eccentric campaigns during the IndyRef business.||A girlfriend restrains the angry 18-year-old. Father and son walk back to the house. “My father, and the land, seemed different. No longer were they courtly, dignified, nestled deep within the traditions of Scotland; instead, in this young Scot’s eyes, they were, apparently, despicable.”
No better comment on this than from Andy Wightman's The Poor had no Lawyers. A miner meets the Laird and, after discussion of how the latter came to own the land ( and the pheasants the miner had caught) offered to fight him for it.  No doubt the book is enjoyable and well-written but the privileged Rory Stewart does not speak of Scotland today. I hope he's aware of that but doubt he has little contact withScots outside his Tory elite bubble.
text:
It sometimes seemed to his son that Brian Stewart, once the second most powerful figure in the British intelligence services, was protesting his Scottishness too much. There had always been an enthusiasm for country dancing. In Kuala Lumpur, in between keeping an eye on the natives, he’d taught five-year-old Rory how to hop the steps of the Highland sword dance. Now, white-haired and rather frail, he wore tartan trews every day and spread a tartan blanket on his bed; he had lurcher called Torquil; next to the whisky on his desk lay oatcakes and a Gaelic dictionary; he ate porridge every morning and haggis twice a week.

Hail Caledonia! But also: Rule Britannia! Scotland was a hobby, but Britain was a state. Glenalmond, Oxford, the Black Watch, the Malayan Civil Service, MI6: that was more or less the précis of his life. He believed in the union and the empire and the force of arms. Before he was wounded in Normandy on 1 July 1944, he and his anti-tank platoon had destroyed a dozen Panzers. Four decades later, walking through the streets of Hong Kong with his young son, he suddenly swung around to lay a man flat with his fist, sensing (his son doesn’t say with what justice) that he was about to be attacked.
title: The Marches by Rory Stewart review – farewell to an imperial class

Surely that's a bit dangerous too?||i would like to see an article explaining the british mania for banning||All those Cilit Bang adverts would be remarkably improved by the sight of Barry Scott being slowly fed into an industrial thresher.
No health and safety conscious, but would be a great salve for my mental health.
text:
The Advertising Standards Authority has banned the new Heinz Beanz advert – in which a succession of people tap out an Ed Sheeran-ish tune on empty cans – on the basis that children might mimic the commercial and cut off their fingers on a jagged scrap of metal. However, it is by no means the only “dangerous” ad. Here are some well-known ads that would no longer make it past health and safety.

John Lewis, 2016

A dog bounces on a trampoline, as happy as can be. However, several animal welfare campaigners have condemned the ad, pointing out the range of injuries and stress that trampolines can cause animals.
title: Heinz means bans, but what other classic ads need a health and safety rethink?

comments:
Blind trust is not always a good thing; informed decisions are owned by the decision makers, be they the patient or the patient's family. 
A recent case in Australia is moot. A Dr went against the National guidance as he thought it was wrong. We may never know what the effect of this was for 100's of patients. Surely discussing treatment options is surely a good thing. 
Other than this a balanced and informative article. Thanks for doing a difficult and emotional job helping others in desperate times.||"People would not dream of showing YouTube videos to the garage when they take their car in for repairs, but have no qualms about presenting their doctor with articles printed off the internet. "
Sad but true. These days, everyone is an "expert". Throw the multitude of ludicrous "big pharma" conspiracies into the mix, and it really all gets rather tragic. Pseudoscience and woo have evolved from silly fringe lurkers to the mainstream. For anyone with an ounce of intelligence, it's extraordinarily frustrating; I can't even begin to imagine how infuriating it must be for those who actually work in the medical field.||Yet you're nowhere to be seen on the CCU when Doctors like my Wife are dealing with the devastating impact of your OTT intrusive interventions/treatments. 
Sometimes she feels that the ego of the Oncologists gets in the way of what is really best for the patients welfare. 
Massive surgeries followed by intense chemotherapy and radiotherapy might well extend the life of an 80yr old person by three months (a common situation in my Wife's hospital) but you're guaranteeing that three months will be hell and there is a good chance that they will die on a crowded CCU ward. 
Oncologists need to reign in the gung-ho war of attrition approach and step back and look at the whole patient not just the cancer.||OK here is a mischievious thought.
Climate deniers diagnosed with cancer should be asked why they will take the word of their oncologist on the best treatment for their disease but not the word of scientists when it comes to global warming. If they are not able to give a satisfactory answer they should be sent to the nearest homeopath.
Jake G||Thanks - an engaging and informative piece. One thought about the few deaths that I have witnessed from cancer. At the very end, in the final day or even last hours when the patient is struggling and nothing is being given by mouth - can't the law be changed to help me (when it is me) on my way in the same way as a dearly loved pet. I think most people want it but the obstacle is the religious lobby and politicians who fear they can only lose votes by supporting end of life euthanasia. Hastening the patient cross the bridge merely by denying liquids and starving is not enough, in fact seems barbaric. If prior consent has been given why not spare us the fight for breath and that awful rattle. Thanks for the wonderful work you all do.

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments: I was glad to see Sperlonga here, it really is a little gem and it's worth spending a few hours. However I would say that there are other places that are worth a visit from rome and that renting a car will ensure you don't miss out on all the beautiful places that, unfortunately, you cannot reach by public transport (which is still somewhat lacking - in reality it will take almost two hours to reach the town of sperlonga from Rome): San Felice Circeo is one of them - it's the promontory you can see in the distance on the picture. Also, going further south from Sperlonga the next town is Gaeta, which is in itself a nice little medieval borough, but if you're driving you'll enjoy the amazing coastal road (via flacca) and can stop at some truly stunning beaches in between those two towns.Another day trip worth taking, this time north of Rome, is the spas of Saturnia, with its pubilc pools of warm waters in a beautiful Tuscany setting: https://goo.gl/images/99eZTK||Sitting and eating on the Spanish steps will get you a fine these days. Not always, obviously, but a few unsuspecting tourists have been caught out recently.||My top tip to avoid the crowds and have a walk in a beautiful park is to take Metro A to Porta Furba and go to Parco Torre di Fiscale to see the aqueducts. Breath taking and usually empty during the week.||Love Rome, but there seems to be an article on it every month! Can we have some on other beautiful cities?||best 8 days of my recent life.. we rented an apartment on Via dei Giubbonari for a week, a few blocks from the Piazza della Rotonda on one side and the Tiber on the other.. heavenly food, lovely people: Rome was overwhelming and the country, top of the list..!
text:
Park it … like a local

Apart from a visit to the museum and gallery in Villa Borghese, tourists don’t tend to flock to any of Rome’s wonderful parks. Of these, Villa Pamphili, the largest public park in Rome, is probably the most beautiful and well-kept, with its wide open vistas and wonderful views of towering pines. Go there for a walk – or a jog – and get a sense of where Romans escape to. Start or end your walk at Vivi Bistrot for a cappuccino or a glass of wine and just soak in Rome’s natural beauty.
• villapamphili.it

Take a cookery class Students at Mamà – Laboratori di Cucina

Food is obviously a huge part of Italian life and culture. I suggest taking in a cooking class that is attended by Italians looking to perfect some classics, including a cacio e pepe that will make your friends at home envious (hint: use enough water). I really enjoyed a visit to Mamà – Laboratori di Cucina near the Salaria. Classes are taught in Italian, so it helps to speak some or bring a friend who does. But even if you don’t you’re bound to learn something just watching and playing along. And there’s prosecco to drink while you’re doing it. Lots of it.
• mamalaboratori.com
title: 10 top tips from our Rome correspondent

However I would say that there are other places that are worth a visit from rome and that renting a car will ensure you don't miss out on all the beautiful places that, unfortunately, you cannot reach by public transport (which is still somewhat lacking - in reality it will take almost two hours to reach the town of sperlonga from Rome): San Felice Circeo is one of them - it's the promontory you can see in the distance on the picture. Also, going further south from Sperlonga the next town is Gaeta, which is in itself a nice little medieval borough, but if you're driving you'll enjoy the amazing coastal road (via flacca) and can stop at some truly stunning beaches in between those two towns.Another day trip worth taking, this time north of Rome, is the spas of Saturnia, with its pubilc pools of warm waters in a beautiful Tuscany setting: https://goo.gl/images/99eZTK||Sitting and eating on the Spanish steps will get you a fine these days. Not always, obviously, but a few unsuspecting tourists have been caught out recently.||My top tip to avoid the crowds and have a walk in a beautiful park is to take Metro A to Porta Furba and go to Parco Torre di Fiscale to see the aqueducts. Breath taking and usually empty during the week.||Love Rome, but there seems to be an article on it every month! Can we have some on other beautiful cities?||best 8 days of my recent life.. we rented an apartment on Via dei Giubbonari for a week, a few blocks from the Piazza della Rotonda on one side and the Tiber on the other.. heavenly food, lovely people: Rome was overwhelming and the country, top of the list..!
text:
Park it … like a local

Apart from a visit to the museum and gallery in Villa Borghese, tourists don’t tend to flock to any of Rome’s wonderful parks. Of these, Villa Pamphili, the largest public park in Rome, is probably the most beautiful and well-kept, with its wide open vistas and wonderful views of towering pines. Go there for a walk – or a jog – and get a sense of where Romans escape to. Start or end your walk at Vivi Bistrot for a cappuccino or a glass of wine and just soak in Rome’s natural beauty.
• villapamphili.it

Take a cookery class Students at Mamà – Laboratori di Cucina

Food is obviously a huge part of Italian life and culture. I suggest taking in a cooking class that is attended by Italians looking to perfect some classics, including a cacio e pepe that will make your friends at home envious (hint: use enough water). I really enjoyed a visit to Mamà – Laboratori di Cucina near the Salaria. Classes are taught in Italian, so it helps to speak some or bring a friend who does. But even if you don’t you’re bound to learn something just watching and playing along. And there’s prosecco to drink while you’re doing it. Lots of it.
• mamalaboratori.com
title: 10 top tips from our Rome correspondent

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
This is only going to get more weird and disturbing isn't it? Bloody hell.||You cant have a Blind Trust if your children are involved in running it.||As biting as ever. Well done!||Ivanka is the new Lucrezia Borgia||"America’s most dysfunctional family have already begun blurring the lines between politics and business" Began? I never believed in a separation of the two to begin with. 
I do not believe in the divine right doctrine. Lots of people seem to believe that politics is somehow sacred, that it shouldn't be tainted by the profane influence of money. That is complete bollocks, politics has no right to claim to be sacred. There is no separation of politics and business, the two serve and influence each other, and cannot be separated. 
We live in an era when sex can be legally sold, when the drug trade is getting legalized, when becoming a mercenary is a legitimate career choice. Why do people still hold the delusion that somehow politics is sacred and beyond the influence of money? To many like me, and to Donald Trump, politics is merely means to an end, there is nothing sacred about it. At the end of the day, politics has to grovel at the feet of capitalism just like religion and morality.
text:
Has ground been broken on Melania Trump’s auto-parodic anti-bullying initiative yet? Only I can’t help feeling the second lady could kick things off with a case close to home. “Dear Me. I believe my husband is gaslighting me. It’s more subtle than the lamps dimming without explanation. I mean, he’s spent years saying the only thing stopping him from coming on to his hot daughter is the fact they’re related. Then yesterday I went into the gold drawing room and found Ivanka sitting in for the meeting with the Japanese prime minister …”

Related: Nigel Farage’s perfect job: aide to Trump, the groper-in-chief | Marina Hyde
title: Ivanka Trump is a shoo-in for the Iron Throne

comments:
Yeah but when all's said and done, hahahaha United, how do you like them apples eh?||Wenger > Mourinho.||Perhaps, as I saw suggested by others after the game, the problems lie with who didn't play for Arsenal in that game. Swap Jenkinson, Elneny and Sanchez out for the absent Bellerin, Cazorla and Welbeck and suddenly you have a different set of players ready to go - a far more competent right back, the marshal of the pitch, and a fitter, more energetic forward than the jaded Sanchez. That would have raised Arsenal's game - their problem, to me at least, seemed to be the lethargy that swamped their offensive movement - making it very easy for United to crush any attacks and hold the ball for the majority of the game. We saw that when Arsenal had a genuine attack United looked weaker, and conceded - the quality Arsenal clearly have was too much. Good squad rotation and ensuring the players that start are fit and quality is what was absent today I feel - Wenger placed too much faith in the likes of Ramsey, Jenkinson and the unfit Sanchez to perform.
Having said that, give them tougher opposition than United and they'd have lost by more, so perhaps there are questions that need to be asked of Arsenal when they are missing Cazorla. He's the biggest absence IMO - you lose the effectiveness of your DMs and the forwards ahead of him by severing their greatest connection. And by default, the back line get weaker - hence why Koscielny looked the only fully functioning CB today. Take Cech out and you'd have seen United ahead far earlier than when they were.||Well, Mourinho should have let the game flow, for United were pinging the ball with purpose until Mata went off. Mou's "shoring up the result" tactics cost him - he missed Fellaini in such situations.
Strange from Wenger though, right until those substitutions.||I didn't see any kind of "tug" for the penalty shout, an arm across, definitely, but no tug.
text:
There was a good moment at the final whistle here. Arsène Wenger and José Mourinho shook hands brusquely on the Old Trafford touchline, turned to walk off, then realised with a shared prickle of awkwardness they were heading the same way, the world’s most awkward shared hundred metre stroll ahead of them. Wenger did the decent thing, taking a couple of paces then stopping and pretending to fiddle with his coat. It was deftly done and no doubt a sensible move, the thick black cloud above Mourinho’s head almost visible as he stalked off at the end of a 1-1 draw from which Manchester United really should have taken three points.

Arsenal were lucky here. There is no disgrace in being outplayed for periods at Old Trafford, not least when United click, as they did here, with Paul Pogba all indolent craft, Juan Mata buzzing and Marcus Rashford providing speed up front. The more positive spin is that Arsenal got a point while playing poorly. It was, though, hard to avoid the impression this was a point snatched in part out of their own muddle, a performance that never thrummed up through the gears, and a chance to go out and actually beat one of their major rivals was once again passed up.
title: Arsène Wenger and Arsenal rescued from muddle of own making

comments:
Yeah but when all's said and done, hahahaha United, how do you like them apples eh?||Wenger > Mourinho.||Perhaps, as I saw suggested by others after the game, the problems lie with who didn't play for Arsenal in that game. Swap Jenkinson, Elneny and Sanchez out for the absent Bellerin, Cazorla and Welbeck and suddenly you have a different set of players ready to go - a far more competent right back, the marshal of the pitch, and a fitter, more energetic forward than the jaded Sanchez. That would have raised Arsenal's game - their problem, to me at least, seemed to be the lethargy that swamped their offensive movement - making it very easy for United to crush any attacks and hold the ball for the majority of the game. We saw that when Arsenal had a genuine attack United looked weaker, and conceded - the quality Arsenal clearly have was too much. Good squad rotation and ensuring the players that start are fit and quality is what was absent today I feel - Wenger placed too much faith in the likes of Ramsey, Jenkinson and the unfit Sanchez to perform.
Having said that, give them tougher opposition than United and they'd have lost by more, so perhaps there are questions that need to be asked of Arsenal when they are missing Cazorla. He's the biggest absence IMO - you lose the effectiveness of your DMs and the forwards ahead of him by severing their greatest connection. And by default, the back line get weaker - hence why Koscielny looked the only fully functioning CB today. Take Cech out and you'd have seen United ahead far earlier than when they were.||Well, Mourinho should have let the game flow, for United were pinging the ball with purpose until Mata went off. Mou's "shoring up the result" tactics cost him - he missed Fellaini in such situations.
Strange from Wenger though, right until those substitutions.||I didn't see any kind of "tug" for the penalty shout, an arm across, definitely, but no tug.
text:
There was a good moment at the final whistle here. Arsène Wenger and José Mourinho shook hands brusquely on the Old Trafford touchline, turned to walk off, then realised with a shared prickle of awkwardness they were heading the same way, the world’s most awkward shared hundred metre stroll ahead of them. Wenger did the decent thing, taking a couple of paces then stopping and pretending to fiddle with his coat. It was deftly done and no doubt a sensible move, the thick black cloud above Mourinho’s head almost visible as he stalked off at the end of a 1-1 draw from which Manchester United really should have taken three points.

Arsenal were lucky here. There is no disgrace in being outplayed for periods at Old Trafford, not least when United click, as they did here, with Paul Pogba all indolent craft, Juan Mata buzzing and Marcus Rashford providing speed up front. The more positive spin is that Arsenal got a point while playing poorly. It was, though, hard to avoid the impression this was a point snatched in part out of their own muddle, a performance that never thrummed up through the gears, and a chance to go out and actually beat one of their major rivals was once again passed up.
title: Arsène Wenger and Arsenal rescued from muddle of own making

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36

text:
Donald Trump is looking at quick ways of withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement in defiance of widening international backing for the plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions, Reuters has reported.

Since the US president-elect was chosen, governments ranging from China to small island states have reaffirmed support for the 2015 Paris agreement at 200-nation climate talks running until 18 November in Marrakesh, Morocco.
title: Trump seeking quickest way to quit Paris climate agreement, says report

Is Cyrille really shaking hands, or has he just done the old "offer the hand then do the thumb on nose waggly fingers" thing?||look at Cyrille Regis in the photo...... is he pulling his hand away, putting his hand to his nose at Cantello and waving his fingers, or about to hand-slap him........?||Crooks and Regis? 
Good luck catching up with them...||Great piece. These players come off as thoughtful and sensitive. Just goes to show what sports can do when it's done right.||looks like Cyrille's giving Len the old 'make-as-if-to-shake-hands-but then-cock-a-snook'. (Is there a word for it?)
text:
After 11 years in the first team and about 15 years after he moved down from Manchester to join West Bromwich Albion’s youth system, Len Cantello was granted a testimonial season in 1978-79. It ended with a game at The Hawthorns that is still talked about nearly four decades later, perhaps getting more attention now than it did at the time. It is the focus of a BBC documentary, to be screened on Sunday.

The continued interest has come as a considerable surprise to the former midfielder himself, now retired and living in Manchester, who recalls nothing particularly exceptional about his big afternoon. “I’d played in a few testimonials, and it was either you played against a local team – so for me it would be the Villa, Birmingham or Wolves – or you played an all-star XI,” he says. “It was just a case of sitting round with a committee and coming up with some ideas for what was the best way to do the game.
title: The West Brom testimonial when black players took on a team of white players

text:
Positivity Radio is a suite of online stations created by Noel Edmonds, each catering to music that matches your mood (or very narrow band of interest). There’s a station dedicated to Bristol, one for helping plants grow and, inevitably, one for pure Noel Edmonds. Is this the future of curated playlists? After listening for an entire day, maybe not…

12:20pm My first destination is Positively Noel, a radio station about Noel Edmonds. He’s telling a meandering anecdote about butterflies and spirit orbs.
title: Cat therapy and seagull sounds: inside Noel Edmonds' bizarre radio empire

text:
Positivity Radio is a suite of online stations created by Noel Edmonds, each catering to music that matches your mood (or very narrow band of interest). There’s a station dedicated to Bristol, one for helping plants grow and, inevitably, one for pure Noel Edmonds. Is this the future of curated playlists? After listening for an entire day, maybe not…

12:20pm My first destination is Positively Noel, a radio station about Noel Edmonds. He’s telling a meandering anecdote about butterflies and spirit orbs.
title: Cat therapy and seagull sounds: inside Noel Edmonds' bizarre radio empire

comments:
Yes it is. Read Thomas Piketty's Capitol in the 21st Century. Either take his advice or stock up on canned goods and a hunting rifle.||But no mention of the misery caused to those who were encouraged to take out mortgages that they couldn't possibly repay.
People suffer when rapacious financial institutions put them in their cross hairs and of course the rest of the population (us) pay to bail out the banks.
Dangerous drivers are punished, but dangerous financiers almost always keep their short term financial gains - the mortgages were not sold by robots and higher up the pyramid their seniors either knew what was going on or were negligent. Worst case, the financiers face premature retirement and years spent enjoying their money, best case they stay on to sort out their own mess. This analysis points to a solution.||happened before,...it will happen again, everything seems to be in place, waiting for a spark,..||There will almost certainly be a big 'financial crisis' soon. We must be punished for Brexit and Trump. Our audacity is intolerable and unacceptable.||Deutsche Bank for example is for all intents and purposes insolvent. It's just a matter of time.
text:
In the Oscar-winning The Big Short, Steve Carell plays the angry Wall Street outsider who predicts (and hugely profits from) the great financial crash of 2007-08. He sees sub-prime mortgages rated triple-A but which, in reality, are junk – and bets billions against the banks holding them. In real life he is Steve Eisman, he is still on Wall Street, and he is still shorting stocks he thinks are going to plummet. And while he’s tight-lipped about which ones (unless you have $1m to spare for him to manage) it is evident he has one major target in mind: continental Europe’s banks – and Italy’s are probably the worst.

Why Italy? Because, he says, the banks there are stuffed with “non-performing loans” (NPLs). That’s jargon for loans handed out to companies and households where the borrower has fallen behind with repayments, or is barely paying at all. But the Italian banks have not written off these loans as duds, he says. Instead, billions upon billions are still on the books, written down as worth about 45% to 50% of their original value.
title: The Big Short: is the next financial crisis on its way?

comments:
Interesting. Good stuff. Like the cut of his jib. Will try and check the book out.||No, it's how you reach a lot of people and get them to effect change.
And if liberal people consider themselves above all that mucky engagement with others, then don't complain when shameless conservatives take advantage of the free ride and dominate the narrative online.||The internet is the near end of a very, very long process of self-indoctrination and repression which begun with the advent of civilisation. The solution is far more intimate, radical and wild than is suggested here.||So a novel. A work of fiction, has to be heavily redacted so it doesn't fall foul of UK defamation law. How sad.||The internet is simply a starting point in that it is a source of information, albeit frequently unreliable or misleading. Anyone with a serious interest in a particular subject will follow up by checking out sources and probably end up resorting to serious publications.
 Beyond this the damage inflicted on the fabric of society is almost incalculable. The same thing happened with television and both mediums were captured early on by business interests and the resultant monetization of virtually everything has distorted and mangled the real promise inherent in both, exceptions such as David Attenborough's productions notwithstanding. So-called social media such as Twitter and Facebook are simply kinetc assemblages of utter drivel, albeit extremely profitable for their shareholders The end result is a society at large with an ever diminishing attention span, where public discourse has degenerated into cheap cliches and soundbites. It's worth reflecting that in terms of global league tables, the position of UK's educational system is somewhere between 14 and 16 depending on who one believes. Whilst in large part this is due to cynical political posturing, the ever growing influence of the internet and it's simplifications and distractions ensures that the UK's children will continue to be the losers.
text:
When the novel I Hate the Internet came out in the US earlier this year, it had every likelihood of sinking without trace. It was self-published, it was by a young unknown – Jarett Kobek – and its main selling point was naked, gleeful contempt for the devices and technology platforms that are an essential part of all our daily lives. “Nothing says individuality like 500 million consumer electronics built by slaves,” he says at one point. “Welcome to hell.” Hell, for Kobek, a 38-year-old American of Turkish heritage, became daily life in San Francisco, where the novel is set. Along with many of the city’s artists and writers, he found himself driven out by the forces of gentrification, moved to Los Angeles, where he’s now based, set up his own small press, and wrote this book – a scorching satire of how a few hypercapitalist companies in Silicon Valley have come to dominate everything. I Hate the Internet didn’t sink without trace. It found a readership thirsty for its funny, acerbic edge, got a rave review in the New York Times, went to the top of the bestseller charts in Germany and has now been published here by Serpent’s Tail.

So, do you actually hate the internet, Jarett?
Not particularly. There’s part of it that I find really contemptible. The title is offered like the sneer of a 15-year-old into Twitter, after they’ve just seen a meme of someone having sex with a chicken or something. I hate parts of it. I certainly think it’s been enormously detrimental to society.
title: Jarett Kobek: ‘The internet has been enormously detrimental to society’

It found a readership thirsty for its funny, acerbic edge, got a rave review in the New York Times, went to the top of the bestseller charts in Germany and has now been published here by Serpent’s Tail.

So, do you actually hate the internet, Jarett?
Not particularly. There’s part of it that I find really contemptible. The title is offered like the sneer of a 15-year-old into Twitter, after they’ve just seen a meme of someone having sex with a chicken or something. I hate parts of it. I certainly think it’s been enormously detrimental to society.
title: Jarett Kobek: ‘The internet has been enormously detrimental to society’

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/52.0.0.11700 Safari/537.36
comments:
Interesting. Good stuff. Like the cut of his jib. Will try and check the book out.||No, it's how you reach a lot of people and get them to effect change.
And if liberal people consider themselves above all that mucky engagement with others, then don't complain when shameless conservatives take advantage of the free ride and dominate the narrative online.||The internet is the near end of a very, very long process of self-indoctrination and repression which begun with the advent of civilisation. The solution is far more intimate, radical and wild than is suggested here.||So a novel. A work of fiction, has to be heavily redacted so it doesn't fall foul of UK defamation law. How sad.||The internet is simply a starting point in that it is a source of information, albeit frequently unreliable or misleading. Anyone with a serious interest in a particular subject will follow up by checking out sources and probably end up resorting to serious publications.
 Beyond this the damage inflicted on the fabric of society is almost incalculable. The same thing happened with television and both mediums were captured early on by business interests and the resultant monetization of virtually everything has distorted and mangled the real promise inherent in both, exceptions such as David Attenborough's productions notwithstanding. So-called social media such as Twitter and Facebook are simply kinetc assemblages of utter drivel, albeit extremely profitable for their shareholders The end result is a society at large with an ever diminishing attention span, where public discourse has degenerated into cheap cliches and soundbites. It's worth reflecting that in terms of global league tables, the position of UK's educational system is somewhere between 14 and 16 depending on who one believes. Whilst in large part this is due to cynical political posturing, the ever growing influence of the internet and it's simplifications and distractions ensures that the UK's children will continue to be the losers.
text:
When the novel I Hate the Internet came out in the US earlier this year, it had every likelihood of sinking without trace. It was self-published, it was by a young unknown – Jarett Kobek – and its main selling point was naked, gleeful contempt for the devices and technology platforms that are an essential part of all our daily lives. “Nothing says individuality like 500 million consumer electronics built by slaves,” he says at one point. “Welcome to hell.” Hell, for Kobek, a 38-year-old American of Turkish heritage, became daily life in San Francisco, where the novel is set. Along with many of the city’s artists and writers, he found himself driven out by the forces of gentrification, moved to Los Angeles, where he’s now based, set up his own small press, and wrote this book – a scorching satire of how a few hypercapitalist companies in Silicon Valley have come to dominate everything. I Hate the Internet didn’t sink without trace. It found a readership thirsty for its funny, acerbic edge, got a rave review in the New York Times, went to the top of the bestseller charts in Germany and has now been published here by Serpent’s Tail.

So, do you actually hate the internet, Jarett?
Not particularly. There’s part of it that I find really contemptible. The title is offered like the sneer of a 15-year-old into Twitter, after they’ve just seen a meme of someone having sex with a chicken or something. I hate parts of it. I certainly think it’s been enormously detrimental to society.
title: Jarett Kobek: ‘The internet has been enormously detrimental to society’

comments:
Self-control and rationality are the answer.||I'm still, 2 weeks on, in the incredulity stage. 
I genuinely didn't realise such a large proportion of America was so cretinously stupid||I think outrage is healthy. The normalisation process is insidious and it's just plain wrong to quietly accept this succession of bigots being appointed to senior positions. So far so bad.||the blind leading the blind.... wake up!||Not wishing to pour more fuel on the fire but after criticising Clinton for being crooked the morning news tells us that Trump has just paid out a large sum of money to people who sued him for discovering ( after paying big tuition fees ) that Trump university didn't do what it said it would do.
His legal team are also involved in rushing through dozens of other law-suits against him before he's sworn in as POTUS.
You don't even need to be a member of the liberal left to wonder how the hell Trump became president.
text:
Now the fun begins! And by “fun” I mean that period after an election when everyone can blame the losing candidate’s loss on whatever their favourite hobby horse may be. For some it might be neoliberalism, for others liberal feminists. Personally, my eyes are still turned towards a Republican party that built the foundations for Donald Trump’s racist platform; high-earning voters who decided his racism and misogyny were not as important as lower taxes; and lower-earning voters who felt that caring about industry was a good excuse to vote for a bigot who, only a few years ago, said the automobile industry should have been left “to go bankrupt”. But hey, I guess it’s all a matter of perspective.

Still, the fun can’t last for ever because we have important work to do, which in my case means learning to say the words “President Trump” without feeling like my heart is trying to heave itself out of my mouth. There is not enough alcohol in the world for this, so I’m turning to the five stages of grief. Will this help me come to an acceptance of – excuse me while I punch myself in the face – President Trump? Let’s find out.
title: Grief comes in five stages. But when it comes to Trump, I can’t get past anger

10 articles saying not much but keeping the clicks up.||Kruis and Itoje have been superb in the line out but they will be mostly missed for their work in the breakdown. Especially Itoje. Launchbury is the only player that comes even close to replicating Itoje's work rate and he's still easily second best.||To be fair I've seen Lawes have plenty of 7-8 out of 10 games. He's hardly Freddie Michalak on the mercurial index!||An article with 10 statements of the obvious. 1 a player needs to be at the top of his game. 
- Italy may be a bit nervous facing NZ
Etc etc||It is incredible to think that France could be in that position with the strength of the Pro 14.
text:
1) Lawes needs to be at top of his game for England

Second-guessing the complexities of Eddie Jones’s attacking strategy is often a bootless errand. Is Elliot Daly selected in the hope that George Ford and Owen Farrell can stretch the heavy South Africa forwards and unlock space for him or to add his booming left boot to what will be a heavy reliance on kicking? Or is Jonathan Joseph’s groin niggle simply not worth the risk?

What is clear, however, is England’s lineout has been nigh-on flawless since Jones took over, thanks in the main to George Kruis and Maro Itoje. England do not want for second-row depth but in the absence of the Saracens pair much rests on the shoulders of Northampton’s Courtney Lawes. He wins his 50th cap on Saturday but, unlike his second-row partner, Joe Launchbury, who is as steady as they come, Lawes has a habit of producing either excellent performances or average ones with little in between.
title: Rugby union: 10 things to look out for in autumn internationals

Are his babies children, or muscles?||Can you smelllllllllll what THE ROCK, is cooking!?!?!?!??!?!||When you consider the quality of the candidates from the American election just run - the Rock really doesn't sound so bad.||D-Lo Brown as his running mate?||With reference to The Rock vs Donald Trump, one brilliant Guardian commenter, a few days ago, coined the phrase:
Between The Rock and a hairpiece.
text:
Nothing feels more mentally restorative than contemplating a KANYE 2020 presidential run – or at least, it didn’t till the prospect of ROCK 2020 opened up.

Admittedly, it is likely that the wrestling-legend-turned-world’s-best-paid-movie-star would mount a White House bid using his extra-ring name, Dwayne Johnson. But he is at least jokingly toying with the idea, in a way that can only add to the gaiety of the nations. In the past, the Rock has described the notion of being president as “very alluring”.
title: After a hard place, a Rock – bring on the 2020 US elections!

Between The Rock and a hairpiece.
text:
Nothing feels more mentally restorative than contemplating a KANYE 2020 presidential run – or at least, it didn’t till the prospect of ROCK 2020 opened up.

Admittedly, it is likely that the wrestling-legend-turned-world’s-best-paid-movie-star would mount a White House bid using his extra-ring name, Dwayne Johnson. But he is at least jokingly toying with the idea, in a way that can only add to the gaiety of the nations. In the past, the Rock has described the notion of being president as “very alluring”.
title: After a hard place, a Rock – bring on the 2020 US elections!

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
That was mad. Totally stressful. Totally behind the sofa. 
I yo-yo’d between Andy has got this, no he is going to lose, and finally YES!
Wow.||Commiserations to Raonic supporters. That was such a close match.||Will he be ready for the true test of his number 1 status? I hope so; as deserved as his number 1 status is it won't really feel like he's cemented it unless he finally does the deed and beats Djokovic-- he hasn't faced him since Roland Garros and hasn't lost a single match since then. I hope he can do it.||Unbelievable. Just unbelievable.
You run out of superlatives to describe Andy Murray. He wasn't at his best today by any stretch but he still ground out the win. Hats off as well to Raonic who played out of his skin. His returning was superb. Don't think it will be too long until we see him holding a slam title.
As for tomorrow, we'll have to see what Andy has in the tank. It would be fitting to see a Murray Djokovic final with Murray prevailing. Would be the icing on the cake of his best ever season.
Here's hoping for a long one tonight to level the playing field!||What a match, some fantastic play by both but some awful errors, though something you'd expect from two tired players at the end of a long season. Murray is a shining example of giving your body and soul to a cause. Let's hope he has enough energy left to give tonight's victor a great match tomorrow. Either way he's done himself proud!
text:
If Andy Murray had played in a crown of thorns, hair shirt and bare feet on broken glass he could hardly have suffered more in victory than he did against Milos Raonic here.

The Scot arrived in London this week playing the best tennis of his career, unbeaten for more than three months, winner of four consecutive titles and ranked No1 in the world. After an hour of the first semi-final of the Barclay’s ATP World Tour Finals, he was misreading the simplest tenets of tennis as if they were a total mystery to him. Somehow he beat his opponent and won the struggle he was having with his own game, but it took him a record three hours and 38 minutes. He will surely be aching ahead of the final on Sunday.
title: Andy Murray suffers for his art in marathon win over Milos Raonic

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
Higher progressive taxes, proper and fair tax collection and stop the rip off that is privatisation.||Is lack of money the real issue or is it that an infantilized population needs to be taught to grow up and act like mature, responsible adults?
For health care to continue as a universal programme that means people have to do their bit to look after themselves. 
Every teen student should learn first aid and emergency preparedness.
Sex education is essential as is the study of anatomy and biology. Everyone must have an understanding of bodily functions and how to protect against disease.
Stop promoting alcohol, it is a cancer causing toxic poison that results in too much violence. Why isn't there a call to ban advertising of alcohol?
Stop forcing pregnant women to deliver disabled offspring. If life is not viable then accept that.
Let elderly people die - who got the bee in the bonnet that under no circumstance are oldpeople to die a natural death? What is the point of constantly reviving those in care homes?This isn't simply about assisted dying but stopping chronic care medication for dementia suffersis an an example of irrationality. 
Science will grow health care creativity and that will cost more $s.
For me - an old person - I do not want any doctor to come near me that is a religion believer,that can be good for my well being.||We pay enough tax. It's time those on the receiving side of it spent it properly. We have too many people taking far more out, than they ever pay in. It's no wonder there's no money for those who really need it. Private companies don't have a magic money tree, why should the public sector? Look at the salaries for those running our services, they're way above the PM and some at the NHS earn more than the US President! The front line has no chance.||There's an old saying that you get what you pay for.
Government habitually tells us we can have better services - like the 7-day NHS. But are there adequate resources to provide for the improvements. Usually not.
Squeezing money out of the social care system has been very short-sighted. It may have saved local authority money, but added extra cost to the NHS, as people who could leave hospital, but can't because of lack of home-care, cause bed-blocking.
However, politically it is difficult to propose raising taxes and getting elected even though better services is the aim. It says something about us as a nation, and it is not very complimentary. It's called the "me" society.||I have enough money to live comfortably. I'm not rich but comparatively well off. But my 11 year old has recurring bone pain. Could be nothing. Could be something easy to resolve. Could be something far more alarming. Getting a GP appt, even for a child, has been trying. I have spoken to a GP over the phone and they said they'll refer her. Will that be in the next 6 months, I wonder. Will it have to wait till it's an emergency. Has been a month already. I am fully aware and conscious that my situation is not remotely as bad as lots of others out there.. worried sick about something and just waiting. I categorically am happy to pay more tax towards a better service. It just seems so unlikely that's going to happen any time soon :(
text:
Philip Hammond may always have dreamed of becoming chancellor, but it is unlikely he imagined it would be in such difficult and uncertain times. The impact of the fall in the value of sterling is only the most obvious of the complexities he has to juggle as he prepares for his first set-piece moment, next week’s autumn statement. The clamour from public services for an emergency cash injection after six years of savage austerity has never been louder. Benefits, further education colleges, and perhaps most consequential, social care have all felt the pain as council spending was cut by £18bn – about a fifth – in the coalition years, and is now facing cuts of half as much again in this parliament.

Nominally, the NHS budget has been protected. But not even Conservative MPs on the Commons health committee believe the government’s headline claims. The impact of not enough money for hospitals and access to care are written for all to see in rising demand for A&E and missed waiting times, where – according to the Health Service Journal – all surgical specialties are now in breach of the 18-week target for the wait between referral and treatment. There are complex reasons underlying the figures, but the consequences of bed-blocking are one of the most important. In September, the last month for which data has been released, 192,000 days were lost by delayed transfer of care. Some NHS number-crunchers believe the real number of people in hospital who should be being cared for in the community is probably four times as many as represented by those figures.
title: The Guardian view on social care: higher taxes or worse services

There are complex reasons underlying the figures, but the consequences of bed-blocking are one of the most important. In September, the last month for which data has been released, 192,000 days were lost by delayed transfer of care. Some NHS number-crunchers believe the real number of people in hospital who should be being cared for in the community is probably four times as many as represented by those figures.
title: The Guardian view on social care: higher taxes or worse services

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 4.4.4; ADR6425LVW Build/IML74K) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.18 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
Higher progressive taxes, proper and fair tax collection and stop the rip off that is privatisation.||Is lack of money the real issue or is it that an infantilized population needs to be taught to grow up and act like mature, responsible adults?
For health care to continue as a universal programme that means people have to do their bit to look after themselves. 
Every teen student should learn first aid and emergency preparedness.
Sex education is essential as is the study of anatomy and biology. Everyone must have an understanding of bodily functions and how to protect against disease.
Stop promoting alcohol, it is a cancer causing toxic poison that results in too much violence. Why isn't there a call to ban advertising of alcohol?
Stop forcing pregnant women to deliver disabled offspring. If life is not viable then accept that.
Let elderly people die - who got the bee in the bonnet that under no circumstance are oldpeople to die a natural death? What is the point of constantly reviving those in care homes?This isn't simply about assisted dying but stopping chronic care medication for dementia suffersis an an example of irrationality. 
Science will grow health care creativity and that will cost more $s.
For me - an old person - I do not want any doctor to come near me that is a religion believer,that can be good for my well being.||We pay enough tax. It's time those on the receiving side of it spent it properly. We have too many people taking far more out, than they ever pay in. It's no wonder there's no money for those who really need it. Private companies don't have a magic money tree, why should the public sector? Look at the salaries for those running our services, they're way above the PM and some at the NHS earn more than the US President! The front line has no chance.||There's an old saying that you get what you pay for.
Government habitually tells us we can have better services - like the 7-day NHS. But are there adequate resources to provide for the improvements. Usually not.
Squeezing money out of the social care system has been very short-sighted. It may have saved local authority money, but added extra cost to the NHS, as people who could leave hospital, but can't because of lack of home-care, cause bed-blocking.
However, politically it is difficult to propose raising taxes and getting elected even though better services is the aim. It says something about us as a nation, and it is not very complimentary. It's called the "me" society.||I have enough money to live comfortably. I'm not rich but comparatively well off. But my 11 year old has recurring bone pain. Could be nothing. Could be something easy to resolve. Could be something far more alarming. Getting a GP appt, even for a child, has been trying. I have spoken to a GP over the phone and they said they'll refer her. Will that be in the next 6 months, I wonder. Will it have to wait till it's an emergency. Has been a month already. I am fully aware and conscious that my situation is not remotely as bad as lots of others out there.. worried sick about something and just waiting. I categorically am happy to pay more tax towards a better service. It just seems so unlikely that's going to happen any time soon :(
text:
Philip Hammond may always have dreamed of becoming chancellor, but it is unlikely he imagined it would be in such difficult and uncertain times. The impact of the fall in the value of sterling is only the most obvious of the complexities he has to juggle as he prepares for his first set-piece moment, next week’s autumn statement. The clamour from public services for an emergency cash injection after six years of savage austerity has never been louder. Benefits, further education colleges, and perhaps most consequential, social care have all felt the pain as council spending was cut by £18bn – about a fifth – in the coalition years, and is now facing cuts of half as much again in this parliament.

Nominally, the NHS budget has been protected. But not even Conservative MPs on the Commons health committee believe the government’s headline claims. The impact of not enough money for hospitals and access to care are written for all to see in rising demand for A&E and missed waiting times, where – according to the Health Service Journal – all surgical specialties are now in breach of the 18-week target for the wait between referral and treatment. There are complex reasons underlying the figures, but the consequences of bed-blocking are one of the most important. In September, the last month for which data has been released, 192,000 days were lost by delayed transfer of care. Some NHS number-crunchers believe the real number of people in hospital who should be being cared for in the community is probably four times as many as represented by those figures.
title: The Guardian view on social care: higher taxes or worse services

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; SM-G900W8 Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.85 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
And... out at the first knockout stage!||Ozil played tonight?||Mesut Özil is pretty much always Arsenal's best player. 
But right now Cazorla is an equally essential player. The sooner he's back the sooner the goals will flow again.||Strange rule really that has PSG top of the table after two draws with Arsenal and an inferior goal difference.
But, this season at least, finishing second may not guarantee a tough draw. Bayern are going to finish second. Real Madrid are second too at the moment. And Sevilla are another formidable second place team. It could be bad news for Leicester rather than Arsenal or Man City.
Arsenal have been off form a little in recent weeks. But still nobody is beating them. one defeat in thirty games in all competitions going back to last March. There's an obduracy there that will stand them in good stead.||I love Özil. I really do. But from up in the gods this evening, it was clear that Giroud's (quite laboured) work rate this evening that kept us in it. 
People moaning behind me that he's not effective enough, but the amount of work he does off the ball is rarely mentioned, and he made one or two really important challenges covering Özil's yards this evening. 
So credit where it's due for the wizard - and he genuinely is magic - but to not mention Giroud's defending from the front is a bit of a shame.
Anyways, up the Arsenal.
text:
As game-seizing moments go, Mesut Özil’s part in Arsenal’s defibrillation after a deathly first half against Paris Saint‑Germain was among the more quietly understated acts of on-field leadership. Arsenal needed it, though. They were outplayed by PSG for most of this 2-2 draw, overrun in midfield and flattered to escape with a point.

In avoiding defeat they were indebted to a moment of stirring incision against the head from Özil, who has often been accused of disappearing in these big games. “As soon as there is physicality involved, Özil disappears,” Raymond Domenech, always good for a line, had announced on French TV before kick‑off. And this is how Özil has been cast by some: a man for the small occasion, the blunt end, those moments where the going gets smooth.
title: Mesut Özil’s vision prevents Arsenal from drifting against PSG
