text:
Related: Solange: A Seat at the Table – a stately, sprawling celebration of black identity

TRACK OF THE WEEK
title: Cranes In The Sky: can Solange finally step out of big sister Beyoncé’s shadow?

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
Love this: “Please feel free to add to it or to knock it down”. That’s the Web We Want.
Some of the problems you list could yet cancel each other out – the multiple blows the EU is due to receive, when it’s already on the ropes, may render the Brexit specifics irrelevant. If the EU fractures, the other European states will have crossed over into our brave old-new world. That will make any negotiations much easier, as they won’t be constrained by the need to publicly buttress their post-national ideology. 
One issue I have with your analysis is not that it’s too depressing, but overly sunny. You still frame recent events as setbacks on the otherwise inevitable march of progress towards a more interconnected, liberal, tolerant, eco-friendly, post-national egalitarian utopia. In that sense, you follow the intellectual dead-end most recently occupied by Hillary Clinton, and your old mate Blair. The prophet of the 1990s wasn’t Fukuyama, but John Grey. History is cyclical, and we’re entering a period where the old 1990s certainties have collapsed, replaced by the older certainties of the 1950s. 
The choice for progressives is to either go down with the ship (which has a certain death-before-dishonour appeal), or rethink some first principles. A global re-distribution of wealth on a historical scale is not going to happen in the foreseeable, so that means the perpetual migrant crisis will require a less idealistic, more immediately available answer. The rich world has a choice of erecting fortress-like structures around itself, or accepting a steep decline of living standards combined with erasing old place-based identities. No one’s ready for that, so the fortress route looks inevitable.
After that, we confront the fact that there’s no bringing manufacturing back to the West, and no arresting or reversing the creep of automation. So high corporate taxes and Universal Basic Income seem like the way forward – by that point, the cost of disenfranchising people by the ten million, in the shape of populist revolts and instability, should outweigh the fear that high taxes will scare ‘wealth creators’ off to Asia. Plus they’ll be creating more wealth than ever, without their salary bills. 
This will further widen the massive gulf in living standards between the global rich and the rest, requiring an ever-stronger fortress, and a farewell to the dream of universal human rights. It was the right idea at the wrong time, and we can only hope that future generations of progressives have the luxury to pursue it.
I don’t know the future, obviously, but I reckon it will get worse before it gets better. And, unless we redefine the ‘liberal’ in ‘liberal progressives’, I sense that progressive voices won’t be shaping that fast-approaching future.||They're shutting themselves down. The political left certainly don't need any help from Donald Trump to become completely redundant. The political centre has moved to the right, and the white working class are now represented, not by the left wing, but by the right wing. That's not Donald Trump's fault - it's the left's, for being remarkably unappealing.||And this is why you must sign up to give a fiver to the Guardian every month!||Yep, makes sense. This worst is here now, not tomorow.||We're through the looking glass people...
text:
Please don’t read this unless you are feeling strong. This is a list of 13 major crises that, I believe, confront us. There may be more. Please feel free to add to it or to knock it down. I’m sorry to say that it’s not happy reading.

1. Donald Trump

The next occupant of the White House will be a man who appears to possess no capacity for restraint, balance or empathy, but a bottomless capacity for revenge and vindictiveness. He has been granted a clean sweep of power, with both houses and the supreme court in his pocket. He is surrounding himself with people whose judgment and knowledge of the world are, to say the least, limited. He will take charge of the world’s biggest nuclear and conventional arsenals, and the most extensive surveillance and security apparatus any state has ever developed.
title: The 13 impossible crises that humanity now faces

comments:
Player burn out - checkResidency query - checkEngland/New Zealand comparison - check. 
Full house!||Interested to see the lineup for the final 2 tests. Especially the make-up of the back row and the back three...||Winning all Jones's games has been fantastic, though while he is said to be building up his options by changing the team, does anyone else think Lancaster would have been accused of not knowing his best team.||" ....is a concern as is value for money for spectators ..."
Judging by the sell out crowds this weekend the spectators are loving it .||I don't think Jones' selections have been left-field. He's had a number of injuries to cope with, and he's blessed with some young backs who can cover multiple positions. The likes of Joseph, Daly and Slade all have the skills and pace to play pretty much anywhere outside half-back, and Daly and Slade in particular have been used in a variety of positions by their clubs. NZ have always had backs like this, it gives the coach a lot more options to get his best players on the pitch, and in how he uses his bench. Let's hope this becomes the norm for England.

comments: Wow. Sounds more like Rawlinson-esque Dare of the Hog ....||Please, we don't tip bartenders in the UK , Australia, NZ and many other places.In the US tipping is a form of outsourcing decent wages used by bar and restaurant owners, that is not in favour of the bartender or waiting staff.Please everyone pay a decent wage and don't force underpaid staff to rely on tips.||"Own your hangover"Sorry Guys but I don't want to wake up with that bottom of a birdcage mouth thank you.Simple 2 step solution after a night of indulgence:1. Large cup of hot water - drink it all! (breaks up the gases - and settles tummy)2. Dam good tongue scrape to remove all that alcohol(and food) debris hiding on the tongue - waiting to make merry havoc overnight !!I use Thames Water and an 'AMANO' Tongue Groomer in that order||that corpse reviver sounds the biz...||Jesus was a hipster.Opportunity missed.
text:
It’s (nearly) Christmas time, there’s no need to be afraid. Except, of course, there is. Forced festive fun is staggering towards us in its paper hat and comedy jumper, complete with flashing lights, reindeer noses and knowing irony. And then there’s the alcohol. Lots and lots of alcohol.

We do a lot of drinking during December. According to Public Health England (who you really don’t want to be stuck talking to at a party), Brits spend more than £2bn just on the booze we drink in our 165m December pub outings, never mind what we cart home from the shops. In many ways, this can be a good thing. In social situations, hooch can be a wonderful wingman – it’s a camaraderie catalyst, rounding off the edges of unease and making music sound better, conversations more absorbing and colleagues more compelling – even that odd guy with the ponytail.
title: The six rules of Christmas boozing

comments: I didn't know that The Walking Dead were registered to vote||I used a pair of ' webbed' gloves when canoeing to help with a roll if I lost the paddle and found them excellent for swimming. The fingers are joined with thin neoprene that resembles a ducks foot when fingers are apart.||What about all those An ti comunist sci fi moovies from the 50s and 60s hollywood ...||Well you certainly don't get that The Walking Dead isn't about zombies.||In my local botanical garden there are some wader birds with unwebbed feet. They have long, separate toes, with no webbing, and can swim just as fast as the ducks, which are bigger than them.
text:
I have only seen bits of The Walking Dead, that hugely popular American TV zombie drama which made a massive star of British actor Andrew Lincoln. But I am going off screen zombies generally: those shambling figures whose low-budget appearance makes them beloved of indie film-makers. Critics love to claim zombies represent undead consumerism. For me they are becoming a gurning cliche, and I wasn’t surprised to see the tiresome Jane Austen horror mashup Pride and Prejudice and Zombies has become 2016’s biggest box-office flop, losing $11.6m. And Forbes magazine this month carries the disturbing news that zombies played a part in the election of Donald Trump. It carries an interview with Jared Kusher, Trump’s super-smooth son-in-law, widely considered to be the incoming administration’s eminence grise. He masterminded the Trump campaign’s use of social media but also deployed traditional TV ads, targeting them much more carefully, identifying specific voter blocs. And when he wanted to hammer home his anti-immigration message, which TV show did Kushner choose? Well, it was … The Walking Dead. He apparently figured that people who thrill to the idea of battling sinister marauding monsters that look human, but aren’t really, will also be very sympathetic to building an enormous wall. Was he right? Was there a Walking Dead constituency for Trump? Maybe they’d better put some zombies in the White House for political balance.

May’s shtick: Jam for some ‘BBC news announcers are doing her PR for her by always slowing down on pronouncing this supposedly zeitgeisty catchphrase so that we can fully appreciate it, in all its piquant buzzphrasey-ness, and the fact that it spells jam!’ Photograph: Alamy

Like celebrities who pick their own nicknames (such as Paul “The Guv’nor” Ince), politicians who try popularising their own catchphrases can find themselves on stony ground. John Major’s “back to basics” coincided with a flurry of sex scandals. Tony Blair’s New Labour tried us with the deeply annoying “big conversation”, that all-inclusive national debate which was abandoned after 9/11. And David Cameron gave it a go with his sensitive, volunteer-based “big society”, but later did not wish to discuss all those volunteer-run food banks. Theresa May is having more luck with her Middle England non-scroungers who are “just about managing”. BBC news announcers are doing her PR for her by always slowing down on pronouncing this supposedly zeitgeisty catchphrase so that we can fully appreciate it, in all its piquant buzzphrasey-ness, and the fact that it spells jam! The mingling of condescension and self-pity in this phrase is almost unbearable. I am just about managing not to lose my breakfast.
title: It’s official – The Walking Dead helped elect Donald Trump

BBC news announcers are doing her PR for her by always slowing down on pronouncing this supposedly zeitgeisty catchphrase so that we can fully appreciate it, in all its piquant buzzphrasey-ness, and the fact that it spells jam! The mingling of condescension and self-pity in this phrase is almost unbearable. I am just about managing not to lose my breakfast.
title: It’s official – The Walking Dead helped elect Donald Trump

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments: I didn't know that The Walking Dead were registered to vote||I used a pair of ' webbed' gloves when canoeing to help with a roll if I lost the paddle and found them excellent for swimming. The fingers are joined with thin neoprene that resembles a ducks foot when fingers are apart.||What about all those An ti comunist sci fi moovies from the 50s and 60s hollywood ...||Well you certainly don't get that The Walking Dead isn't about zombies.||In my local botanical garden there are some wader birds with unwebbed feet. They have long, separate toes, with no webbing, and can swim just as fast as the ducks, which are bigger than them.
text:
I have only seen bits of The Walking Dead, that hugely popular American TV zombie drama which made a massive star of British actor Andrew Lincoln. But I am going off screen zombies generally: those shambling figures whose low-budget appearance makes them beloved of indie film-makers. Critics love to claim zombies represent undead consumerism. For me they are becoming a gurning cliche, and I wasn’t surprised to see the tiresome Jane Austen horror mashup Pride and Prejudice and Zombies has become 2016’s biggest box-office flop, losing $11.6m. And Forbes magazine this month carries the disturbing news that zombies played a part in the election of Donald Trump. It carries an interview with Jared Kusher, Trump’s super-smooth son-in-law, widely considered to be the incoming administration’s eminence grise. He masterminded the Trump campaign’s use of social media but also deployed traditional TV ads, targeting them much more carefully, identifying specific voter blocs. And when he wanted to hammer home his anti-immigration message, which TV show did Kushner choose? Well, it was … The Walking Dead. He apparently figured that people who thrill to the idea of battling sinister marauding monsters that look human, but aren’t really, will also be very sympathetic to building an enormous wall. Was he right? Was there a Walking Dead constituency for Trump? Maybe they’d better put some zombies in the White House for political balance.

May’s shtick: Jam for some ‘BBC news announcers are doing her PR for her by always slowing down on pronouncing this supposedly zeitgeisty catchphrase so that we can fully appreciate it, in all its piquant buzzphrasey-ness, and the fact that it spells jam!’ Photograph: Alamy

Like celebrities who pick their own nicknames (such as Paul “The Guv’nor” Ince), politicians who try popularising their own catchphrases can find themselves on stony ground. John Major’s “back to basics” coincided with a flurry of sex scandals. Tony Blair’s New Labour tried us with the deeply annoying “big conversation”, that all-inclusive national debate which was abandoned after 9/11. And David Cameron gave it a go with his sensitive, volunteer-based “big society”, but later did not wish to discuss all those volunteer-run food banks. Theresa May is having more luck with her Middle England non-scroungers who are “just about managing”. BBC news announcers are doing her PR for her by always slowing down on pronouncing this supposedly zeitgeisty catchphrase so that we can fully appreciate it, in all its piquant buzzphrasey-ness, and the fact that it spells jam! The mingling of condescension and self-pity in this phrase is almost unbearable. I am just about managing not to lose my breakfast.
title: It’s official – The Walking Dead helped elect Donald Trump

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
What a country. Why anyone wanted to bomb it. I will never know||We did all that at half the price. Vietnam is a great place to discover yourself. It can all be done before you go. Beautiful country!||Great, but what about the wildlife? Are they all poached?
You can have the most amazing sceneries but without an abundance of wildlife all you have is an Empty Forest.||Hole Lot of Love?I thought I was reading the Sun!||Vietnam has an issue outside of the cave. As of last June you no longer require a Vietnamese partner when owning a business. One of the highlights is the food, so hopefully doesn't become ruined with an influx of 7-11's, Starbucks etc. See the once great Thailand for details.
text:
Uy Jang Jong doesn’t look much like a caveman. Instead of a stocky, hairy figure in animal skins, he is slim and sharply coiffed, in hi-tech sportswear. But this smiley 27-year-old is one of the luminaries of Vietnamese, and therefore world, caving.

“I discovered that cave,” Uy says casually, indicating a photograph in a cafe in Phong Nha town. “Wow,” we say. “Is it named after you?” “Nah,” comes the reply. “The first one I found is called Uy cave, but I’ve discovered more since.”
title: Inside Vietnam's astonishing caves on a local tour

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments: Boom?||Bluff just like everyone else.||Watch Christopher Walken in 'The Dead Zone' for some hints.||I'm moving to Darwin.||Why is right wing, pro neoliberal Trump any more dangerous than right wing, pro neoliberal Obama or Clinton? The latter two are not exactly reticent in supporting wars and bombings are they? And as an aside, the last person to drop the nuclear bomb (twice)that killed and maimed thousands of civilians, was a"nice" and "cuddly" Democrat. I wonder if the "liberal" Guardian , at the time, roundly condemned him?
text:
Donald Trump has inchoate, inconsistent and sometimes ill-informed views on a raft of nuclear weapons issues: their role in national and international security; the nuclear threats posed by North Korea, Iran and others; the consequences of their use; the inevitability and desirability of nuclear proliferation; the necessity of spending $1tr over 30 years to modernise the US arsenal; and the importance of cutting deals with Russia and others to regulate their stockpiles.

He is as yet largely unformed in this critical arena, but some of his stated positions and views have the potential to wreak havoc on the international security order and put the country and the world in nuclear jeopardy.
title: Trump has his finger on the nuclear trigger: what will he choose to do?

comments:
Hmmm. The complimentary drinks were flowing at Twickenham today. 
Your ratings were bizarre as well. Launchbury 7/10? He was MOM||Congrats to England and commiserations to Sth Africa.Have I been up too long, or has this article got something of an unpleasant tone to it?||Wanted to enjoy this match. Found it quite flat. Nice to see that England are developing their attacking shape. Interested to see how it develops.||Ridiculously exaggerated description of the Lawes try. England showed real ambition to run it initially, Daly's kick was long and beautifully judged, the England chase was effective in harrying the Boks defence, Brown displayed tremendous footie skills to get within a yard of the line and it says something about the mobility of the English forwards that it was a second rower that touch down. Hardly Charlie Chaplin.||So strange that our Michael, so attentive to every detail of this especial warthog of a try failed to notice the pace and pressure that England generated to compel SA to concede this infamous score, which, incidentally, is worth the exact same number of points as the best Ireland or NZ produced last week.
text:
So, South Africa remained unbeaten against England for a week shy of 10 years, a run of 12 matches. It was an impressive record. It is something to cling to. And they will take anything just now.

This was a dispiriting prick of the balloon – and balloon-thick is South Africa’s confidence at the moment. Now they must add the 37 points conceded here to the 57 they shipped last time out a month ago to the All Blacks – at home in Durban. Lob in a host of other indignities over the last couple of years – to Argentina, Japan and Ireland, among others – and you begin to wonder how they managed that 10-year unbeaten run against England.
title: South Africa’s thin confidence popped by farcical Charlie Chaplin try for England

Found it quite flat. Nice to see that England are developing their attacking shape. Interested to see how it develops.||Ridiculously exaggerated description of the Lawes try. England showed real ambition to run it initially, Daly's kick was long and beautifully judged, the England chase was effective in harrying the Boks defence, Brown displayed tremendous footie skills to get within a yard of the line and it says something about the mobility of the English forwards that it was a second rower that touch down. Hardly Charlie Chaplin.||So strange that our Michael, so attentive to every detail of this especial warthog of a try failed to notice the pace and pressure that England generated to compel SA to concede this infamous score, which, incidentally, is worth the exact same number of points as the best Ireland or NZ produced last week.
text:
So, South Africa remained unbeaten against England for a week shy of 10 years, a run of 12 matches. It was an impressive record. It is something to cling to. And they will take anything just now.

This was a dispiriting prick of the balloon – and balloon-thick is South Africa’s confidence at the moment. Now they must add the 37 points conceded here to the 57 they shipped last time out a month ago to the All Blacks – at home in Durban. Lob in a host of other indignities over the last couple of years – to Argentina, Japan and Ireland, among others – and you begin to wonder how they managed that 10-year unbeaten run against England.
title: South Africa’s thin confidence popped by farcical Charlie Chaplin try for England

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
"she admits she was looking for “escape” and saw the islands as a “Never-Never Land”
Did i just read that?||My family lived on the Atlantic coast of Lewis since time immemorial and cousins still do. No romance. Just bl***y hard work, and lots of rain. Grandfather and great uncle joined the Manchester Pals and were at 3rd Ypres (Passchendale). Then NEVER spoke of what they had seen. They both settled in Manchester (police officers). The village which had once held 350 at the turn of the 18/1900, now has six inhabitants, two of whom operate a beautiful B&B, suainaval. dot com if you want some stunning photos||Including, as Amy Liptrot hints, Graun types doing Flight North books.||Really? How is that conclusion reached?||We know all about that in Scotland.
text:
This moving and wonderful journey through both the geography and history of the Hebrides was six years in the writing. Madeleine Bunting wasn’t expecting the Scottish referendum when she began the book, but the independence debate feeds into her aim of using the islands to come to a better understanding of Britain, and the idea of home. She visits the Hebrides many times, inspired by childhood holidays to the Highlands and her own family heritage, as well as by literary precedents from Samuel Johnson and James Boswell to George Orwell.

It’s clear from the start that she recognises the poetic appeal of the isles – “the last volcanic remnant before we tip off the continental shelf, leave Europe and head out into the open ocean for the Americas” – and also that their bleak beauty is accompanied by a history of marginalisation and loss, from the clearances to more recent depopulation. It takes longer for an understanding to be revealed of the Hebrides as modern, working, inhabited places.
title: Love of Country: A Hebridean Journey review – the edge of Europe

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; SM-G900W8 Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.85 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
Get Ye to the high street, though i fear you may be too late, all you can find there is a terrible big-chain-brand coffee and umpteen near-identical italian restaurants... the choice we all demand can't be handled on the high street anymore :(||Given that the vast majority of journeys would be made by single-occupancy car, that would be catastrophic for our hopes of meeting emissions reduction targets.||How would shopping on the high street help Amazon drivers? It would be taking away their business.||There is indeed a disconnect. The clothes we wear, the devices we use, much of the food we consume is rooted in severe human and planetary exploitation. 
Delivery drivers are visible to us but the murdered and virtually enslaved legions who supply what they deliver are hidden behind chains of production and distribution we never see.
Amazon itself is not to blame. Domestic government policy is to blame.
Make pay fair all along the supply chain and these Instances will stop being news.||Right from the start Amazon thrived in large part due to competitive advantage - read about the Quill Corp. v. North Dakota ruling which coincided with its founder setting it up - just as the internet was taking off. The politicians in the UK think bringing Amazon investment to their area is an unalloyed good, but those politicians wouldn't last a week working for Amazon .
text:
How Soon Is Now?, the old Smiths song, could work now as an anthem for high-speed online deliveries, which are, in turn, increasingly raising questions about workers’ rights.

In the same week that the Department for Transport reported a crisis in road congestion, owing primarily to online deliveries – in some parts of Britain, a horse and cart would be faster – an undercover BBC report revealed that Amazon delivery drivers are forced to deliver up to 200 parcels a day, working illegal hours and breaking speed limits.
title: Help an Amazon driver: hotfoot it to the shops

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
It's just so bonkers - and depressing - that people buy into this twaddle.
Also, timely trump gag.||So you didn't like it then?||Sounds like the ideal place to go if you don't really want to eat||I often listen to my inner self and on this occasion it says "Sod that, let's go to Inaho"||Might have been better not to illustrate this with a photo of diners who are clearly not all 'creatures of luminous beauty, long and slender of limb, glowing of skin, sheeny-shiny of hair.'@cwhope
text:
On entering Farmacy in Westbourne Grove, I immediately feel as though I have shrunk and swollen into the incarnation of Roz, my fugly avatar on Twitter. The whole place is populated by creatures of luminous beauty, long and slender of limb, glowing of skin, sheeny-shiny of hair. Here they are, the disciples of “clean eating”.

The clean-eating trend (cult? epidemic?) is spawning temples of worship like kombucha spores. Deliciously Ella with her Mae “delis” (although she has now, in a slightly panicky way, distanced herself from the word “clean”); M Raw, “London’s first 100% gluten-free fine dining restaurant”; Vita Mojo, which promises to “put you in control of your diet”; the Detox Kitchen; Rawligion; and too many more.
title: Farmacy, London W2: ‘I pray I never eat here again’ – restaurant review

text:
On entering Farmacy in Westbourne Grove, I immediately feel as though I have shrunk and swollen into the incarnation of Roz, my fugly avatar on Twitter. The whole place is populated by creatures of luminous beauty, long and slender of limb, glowing of skin, sheeny-shiny of hair. Here they are, the disciples of “clean eating”.

The clean-eating trend (cult? epidemic?) is spawning temples of worship like kombucha spores. Deliciously Ella with her Mae “delis” (although she has now, in a slightly panicky way, distanced herself from the word “clean”); M Raw, “London’s first 100% gluten-free fine dining restaurant”; Vita Mojo, which promises to “put you in control of your diet”; the Detox Kitchen; Rawligion; and too many more.
title: Farmacy, London W2: ‘I pray I never eat here again’ – restaurant review

text:
Prioritise sleep and put it high on the agenda. There’s more packed into our children’s days than ever before, and sleep is simply not recognised with adequate importance.

Researchers at King’s College London have just added more evidence to the pile showing that irregular bedtimes and insufficient sleep in childhood may result in increased calorie consumption and obesity. And there’s more.
title: Lack of sleep is making our children obese – but help is at hand

text:
1 Fantastic Beasts And Where To Find Them (12A)

(David Yates, 2016, UK/US) 133 mins.

This lavishly designed Potter prequel delivers on the promised magical menagerie, as wrangled by Eddie Redmayne’s wizarding wildlife whisperer (think Doctor Who meets David Attenborough). Equally intriguing is the alternative 1920s America he stumbles into: a society beset by segregation, paranoia and witch-hunts. It’s escapist spectacle with a dash of political substance.
title: Five of the best… films out now in the UK

comments:
Tell it to the Nobel Prize for Literature committee.....||Judge Judy says, "No good deed goes unpunished."||This comment is entirely voluntary and totally committed, no cash or gold stars having changed hands. Modestly yet passionately epitomising the article's argument in its own small way, It can't fail to be compelling; even for some, perhaps, touching. As many voluntary recommends will no doubt show.
Any… minute… now… ?||Similar ground is entertainingly covered in this RSA animation of Daniel Pink's thoughts on Drive: the surprising truth about what motivates us:http://www.danpink.com/video/which chimes with psychological research I'm familiar with.||Isn't the issue here how you separate the reward from the task? Nothing can be rewarding for its own sake, all the time. The rewarding aspects of something can appear when a milestone is achieved, or at a completely random point, but the question is do you view them as part of the whole therefore feel positively about the whole, or as somehow separate (thereby perceiving the rest of the activity unrewarding and just a means to an end).
text:
Here’s a story about a man with a machiavellian genius for psychological manipulation. (It comes from the US educator Alfie Kohn, so I’ll Britishise it here.) This man is elderly and lives near a school. Every afternoon a group of pupils subject him to merciless taunts as they walk home. So he approaches them and offers a deal: he’ll give each child £1 if they come back next day to taunt him further. Incredulous but excited, they agree. They return to mock him; he pays as promised, but tells them that the following day, he’ll only be able to afford to pay 25p per person. Still thrilled to be paid at all, the children are there again the next afternoon, whereupon the old man sadly explains that, henceforth, the daily reward for hurling abuse at him will be a mere 1p. “A penny?” The kids are scornful. For such pathetic money, it’s not worth the effort. They stalk off, grumbling, and never bother him again.

The truth being exploited here – that rewards can backfire – isn’t new. Psychologists have studied it for years, and call it the “overjustification effect”. The traditional assumption was always that people worked essentially like BF Skinner’s lab rats: dangle an incentive, and you’ll train them to do what you want. But for humans, in certain conditions, the reward simply reinforces the belief that the task can’t be worth doing for itself. It locates all the pleasure in the future, when the reward will be bestowed, turning the present-moment doing into a grind. From this perspective, rewards aren’t the opposite of punishments, but basically the same thing: a way of pressuring people into performing activities you can’t rely on them wanting to do.
title: Why rewards can backfire

Modestly yet passionately epitomising the article's argument in its own small way, It can't fail to be compelling; even for some, perhaps, touching. As many voluntary recommends will no doubt show.
Any… minute… now… ?||Similar ground is entertainingly covered in this RSA animation of Daniel Pink's thoughts on Drive: the surprising truth about what motivates us:http://www.danpink.com/video/which chimes with psychological research I'm familiar with.||Isn't the issue here how you separate the reward from the task? Nothing can be rewarding for its own sake, all the time. The rewarding aspects of something can appear when a milestone is achieved, or at a completely random point, but the question is do you view them as part of the whole therefore feel positively about the whole, or as somehow separate (thereby perceiving the rest of the activity unrewarding and just a means to an end).
text:
Here’s a story about a man with a machiavellian genius for psychological manipulation. (It comes from the US educator Alfie Kohn, so I’ll Britishise it here.) This man is elderly and lives near a school. Every afternoon a group of pupils subject him to merciless taunts as they walk home. So he approaches them and offers a deal: he’ll give each child £1 if they come back next day to taunt him further. Incredulous but excited, they agree. They return to mock him; he pays as promised, but tells them that the following day, he’ll only be able to afford to pay 25p per person. Still thrilled to be paid at all, the children are there again the next afternoon, whereupon the old man sadly explains that, henceforth, the daily reward for hurling abuse at him will be a mere 1p. “A penny?” The kids are scornful. For such pathetic money, it’s not worth the effort. They stalk off, grumbling, and never bother him again.

The truth being exploited here – that rewards can backfire – isn’t new. Psychologists have studied it for years, and call it the “overjustification effect”. The traditional assumption was always that people worked essentially like BF Skinner’s lab rats: dangle an incentive, and you’ll train them to do what you want. But for humans, in certain conditions, the reward simply reinforces the belief that the task can’t be worth doing for itself. It locates all the pleasure in the future, when the reward will be bestowed, turning the present-moment doing into a grind. From this perspective, rewards aren’t the opposite of punishments, but basically the same thing: a way of pressuring people into performing activities you can’t rely on them wanting to do.
title: Why rewards can backfire

comments:
Tesco has fruit and veg on weekly offer at under £1 a bag -- usually 69p or thereabouts. Of course it is affordable to more than claim it isn't. I accept some will still struggle, and actually I would like to see govt intervention giving fruit and veg to such families. But broadly speaking, you can do it if you can be arsed to prioritise your budget.||She seems to be arguing that we shouldn't give people accurate health advice because it might make them feel bad. This infantilising of people is getting ridiculous. Public health advice should be based on facts.
The bigger problem here is that much of this guidance is already woefully inaccurate. The recommendations for fruit and veg consumption and alcohol guidelines vary wildly by country, for example, when everyone has access to the same research. It is this inconsistency and departure from what the research actually shows that often makes people dismiss it.||It's not expensive just based on flaky science. However, the truth is eating fruits and vegetables is good for health and five a day is a catchy marketing term.
Ditching it will likely cause more harm than good as more people shun healthy food choices.||Also drop "dont run with Scissors". Reduce it to "a light jog with garden shears is fine if you want"||Just give up the booze and fags, plenty of dosh left over for fruit and vegetables ;-)
text:
The new leader of Britain’s 50,000 family doctors says the “five-a-day” target for fruit and vegetable consumption should be revised because it is unaffordable for many Britons.

In her first interview since becoming the chair of the Royal College of GPs, Dr Helen Stokes-Lampard told the Observer: “For people that have got a low income five-a-day is really, really hard. It’s expensive to have five-a-day. I get my five-a-day, no problem, but for many people they can’t afford that five-a-day.” Fruit and vegetables should be reduced in price to encourage greater uptake, she said.
title: New GP leader calls for rethink of ‘expensive’ five-a-day goal

comments:
Not directly responding to this piece, but please, PLEASE, stop covering Nigel Farage's attempts to be Trump's UK fluffer 
Have you learnt nothing from Trump and what happens if you give these people coverage ?
Please confine him to the far right echo chambers where he can do relatively little harm.||They need to focus more on climate change. Leadership from Trump and May on this issue, against the expectations of the extreme right, could give the necessary impetus to the rest of the world.||You dont do self awareness here obviously.I have yet to read a more absurd article anywhere than Paul Masons latest offering and that comes with quite a lot of competition hereabouts.||When they meet I'll be watching out for Trump giving May a big slap on the fanny (US informal). If that happens, her reaction of course should be to punch him in the face, but she'll just have to put up with it as politically she's in desperate need of a "special" relationship.||When will this paper wake up the majority of their readers don't share the same views. No wonder you are begging at every chance for funding to run your biased reporting. The majority of people know what brexit means Cameron and Osborne said enough times its called leaving the single market and controlling immigration. The EU are very quiet atm because they know they will lose out instead of just picking and choosing articles what suit you. The experts in the EU see eurozone and euro as a failure. The poorer countries are holding the richer countries back these are the same countries what need growth and jobs for all the people leaving the poorer EU countries. It's not so shiny on the other side as it was Juncker and Tusk begging for trade deals with the US
text:
It is less than a week since Donald Trump was elected as the next president of the United States. So it is hardly surprising that such an immense shock to the US and to the global political order is still only sinking in. To add to the shock, Mr Trump himself is now making almost daily statements which, in some cases, mark changes of direction or tone, few of which can yet be treated as definitive. The Trump triumph is an immense event, and immensely threatening, but there are still more than two months before his inauguration. It is likely that some of the instant response to his election, however passionately felt, may prove to be ephemeral and in some cases overheated.

That is certainly true in Europe, and it is particularly true in Britain, where reactions have fallen far short. Like so many others, most of Europe’s leaders were caught on the hop by last week’s result. They had expected and wanted Hillary Clinton to prevail. It therefore made sense for European Union foreign ministers to meet on Sunday to discuss the implications of the Trump victory. There was and is use in such exchanges, and the foreign secretary Boris Johnson was wrong to stay away, and especially foolish to patronise other Europeans for what he dubbed an anti-Trump whinge-o-rama.
title: The Guardian view on Theresa May and Donald Trump: questions but no answers

To add to the shock, Mr Trump himself is now making almost daily statements which, in some cases, mark changes of direction or tone, few of which can yet be treated as definitive. The Trump triumph is an immense event, and immensely threatening, but there are still more than two months before his inauguration. It is likely that some of the instant response to his election, however passionately felt, may prove to be ephemeral and in some cases overheated.

That is certainly true in Europe, and it is particularly true in Britain, where reactions have fallen far short. Like so many others, most of Europe’s leaders were caught on the hop by last week’s result. They had expected and wanted Hillary Clinton to prevail. It therefore made sense for European Union foreign ministers to meet on Sunday to discuss the implications of the Trump victory. There was and is use in such exchanges, and the foreign secretary Boris Johnson was wrong to stay away, and especially foolish to patronise other Europeans for what he dubbed an anti-Trump whinge-o-rama.
title: The Guardian view on Theresa May and Donald Trump: questions but no answers

text:
The door opens, and a bullmastiff greets me. “This is Allen,” Matt Healy says. He licks me all over. (Allen, not Healy.) Allen, I say, that’s an unusual name for a dog. “It’s not his full name,” Healy says. Ah, what’s his full name? “Allen Ginsberg.”

Welcome to the world of the 1975, Healy’s chart-topping band. An Olivetti typewriter is perched on the living room table, a series of 20th-century clocks on the wall. It really does feel as if it could be 1975 at Healy’s home in east London.
title: The 1975’s Matt Healy: ‘I am pretentious. And I’m not apologising’

comments:
Thank you.||Admirable.||At a time like this when the whole world feels like a big let down your story inspires hope. Words fail me so I will try,"You have Balls man!"
We need more positive thinking people like you. When is your next article coming?||Great personal achievement. And the job at Southampton Solent is certainly better for the rest of us.||Holy crap dude! There but for the grace of god.....
Congratulations to you and your new wife. May you have a happy life.
text:
In autumn 2006, I’d just returned from a year of travelling after getting a first in economics at the University of Birmingham. I was 21, living back with my parents near Southampton and two weeks into a graduate position at the accountancy firm, KPMG. The future could not have looked brighter.

I went back to Birmingham to catch up with some friends. After a curry, we headed back to the student union for old times’ sake. There had been an open day on campus so the fountain was on. I got the idea to jump in, and tried to persuade everyone to join me. We had had a few beers but we weren’t wrecked – it was just a laugh. At the end of the night, a mate and I decided to go for it. We ran towards it, but while he jumped in, I, for some reason, put my arms over my head and did a racing dive.
title: Experience: I broke my neck on a night out

comments:
Wonder if the lecture is delivered by Slideshow Bob||And that confirms you are indeed having a fucking laugh.
Just as well higher education in Scotland is free, isn't it?||Except the ones who have pointed out we live in an era of low expectations and the Simpsons reflects this.
A British cartoon like Bob and Margaret has far more interesting and less predictable cultural references.||Perhaps Edinburgh ought to offer a course on the psychology of interpersonal relationships, using analysis of "The Big Bang Theory" for much of the course material...||Probably taught alongside 'Carl' Marx.Also ... it's been done in a handy guide ... https://www.amazon.co.uk/Simpsons-Philosophy-Homer-Popular-Culture/dp/0812694333
text:
News that Glasgow University has launched a one-day course named D’oh! The Simpsons Introduce Philosophy should not even raise an eyebrow. For nearly two decades, intellectuals and philosophers have been praising Matt Groening’s brilliant creation. As philosophy tutor John Donaldson, who will teach the new course, explains it, the show is “full of philosophical themes”.

A scepticism persists that those who claim to see philosophical depth in The Simpsons are simply betraying our shallowness or having a laugh. But far from there being anything paradoxical about a cartoon having philosophical substance, cartoons are actually the ideal artistic vehicle for philosophy.
title: Glasgow University offers a Simpsons philosophy class – and it makes perfect sense

For nearly two decades, intellectuals and philosophers have been praising Matt Groening’s brilliant creation. As philosophy tutor John Donaldson, who will teach the new course, explains it, the show is “full of philosophical themes”.

A scepticism persists that those who claim to see philosophical depth in The Simpsons are simply betraying our shallowness or having a laugh. But far from there being anything paradoxical about a cartoon having philosophical substance, cartoons are actually the ideal artistic vehicle for philosophy.
title: Glasgow University offers a Simpsons philosophy class – and it makes perfect sense

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments: Fascinating collection of tips. Thank you all that contributed. I feel inspired to save up for a trip there myself now :-)||Yorkshire||Some good tips here, but make sure you follow the most important tip of all. Never go anywhere near a popular tourist place in Vietnam a) on the weekend b) around Tet and several other national holidays and c) during Chinese holidays (yes, they're invading the place). Best to spend weekends in the cities and weekdays in the countryside and avoid visiting during holiday times.||There's a woman in Ho Chi Minh city who spends all day and night in a hammock rolling the best joints you'll ever smoke.||Totally agree that the countryside around Ninh Binh is a highlight. There are also some fantastic homestays in the area (much better than hotels). I would highly recommend going to the Cathedral in Phát Diệm (closish to Ninh Binh) where part of Grahame Green's The Quiet American is set. It is a really incredible mix of Catholic and Vietnamese architecture.
text:
Winning tip: Ninh Binh countryside

OK, so the town of Ninh Binh (two hours’ drive south of Hanoi) is no looker, but the surrounding countryside will seduce you. Once there I hired a bicycle and set out early morning to explore the karst limestone scenery (think Halong bay with rice paddies replacing the sea). It was a wonderfully peaceful day of exploring villages, and having a picnic by the side of rice fields while watching the locals work. After two weeks in Vietnam, it was the first time I could really listen to the birds and feel at peace. It can be hard to escape the mopeds, but I had found the Vietnam I had hoped for.
Noodlequeen

Hanoi Kids tours

Sign up for a free tour with Hanoi Kids, an organisation that pairs travellers with students learning English. It’s free and you’ll get a local’s perspective on the city, culture and cuisine. They filled us in on Hanoi life, their ambitions and the Korean pop stars they like over lunch in their favourite cafe. At the memorial to Communist leader Ho Chi Minh, we talked about politics and what the place meant to them. You set the pace and they give you tips for making the most of your time in the city. The tour is free apart from any entrance fees – if you give money to the guide they’ll pass it on to the organisation.
• hanoikids.org
ID7529657
title: Things to do in Vietnam: readers’ travel tips

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; SM-G900W8 Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.85 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
£35 per person equates to around €6 per night (I assume you are staying for a week). In any French supermarket that buys a reasonable bottle of wine, per person which ought to be enough to warm up any apres-ski dinner.Perhaps you should ensure that the hotel will allow you to bring your own drinks rather than have to pay probably €20 for the same bottle.||No doubt the hotel changed all the English people's terms considering the shameful amount of alcohol we consume.||You've essentially been given a drinks voucher for £6 per night for drinks with your evening meal. seems a reasonable definition of still providing free drink(s) with your meal, as opposed to free drinks all night while you're sat at your table in the restaurant
but then maybe this is why the original wording was removed||Agree that you can bring your own wine. 
Then bribe a chalet girl with €50, to use the company van to drive into the valley and pick up some wine at carrefour. 
Quids in.||I guess you were expecting unlimited supplies of alcohol! The reality probably would have been only one small glass of wine or beer, and the voucher provided covers that. Just purchase one drink each, ask for a pitcher of water. Then as others have said, buy your own drinks at the local shops (even if they're not big supermarkets, it'll still work out cheaper than buying at the hotel bar) and enjoy in your rooms.
text:
We are a party of 10 who have booked a ski holiday at the end of February. At the time of booking we were told that free drinks were included with evening meals at our hotel and this was key when choosing the best deal.

However, we have now been informed that the hotel has withdrawn the offer. It has offered around £35 compensation per person.
title: Our ski holiday would go downhill without free drinks

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
Because it collectively decided to throw the entire country off a cliff, sentencing us to years of economic chaos, racial division and international exile. It looked at the desecration of its industry due to years of neo-liberal horror and decided; 'refugees did it, howay.' It is a micocosm of the state of the entire country, and so fills us with loathing, for when we look upon the North-East, we truly see the abyss looking back.
And Parmo.||Ha, Gooch.||He presumably lives in Newcastle then...||Because despite having the blue-collar manufacturing jobs they wanted with a bunch of companies that built here because we're in the EU they decided that they wanted to throw everyone under the bus and vote out, laying the groundwork for their own economic misery, wrecking the building and farming sectors, knocking 20% off the value of everyone's savings and making millions of contributing doctors, engineers, scientists and nurses feel unwelcome.
I'd trade fifty people from Sunderland for one Polish builder.||Not sure why they've got a picture of Wayne Bridge playing for Southampton in that painting.
text:
Lynden Gooch sometimes struggles to comprehend just how rapidly his life has changed. “A couple of months ago I don’t think many people knew who I was,” he says, breaking into a high-wattage smile capable of powering a set of floodlights. “No one knew anything much about me but David Moyes has altered everything.”

Related: Ireland v New Zealand, Shohei Ohtani hits the roof and mongoose stops play
title: Sunderland’s Lynden Gooch: ‘People say bad things about the north-east but I don’t know why’

It is a micocosm of the state of the entire country, and so fills us with loathing, for when we look upon the North-East, we truly see the abyss looking back.
And Parmo.||Ha, Gooch.||He presumably lives in Newcastle then...||Because despite having the blue-collar manufacturing jobs they wanted with a bunch of companies that built here because we're in the EU they decided that they wanted to throw everyone under the bus and vote out, laying the groundwork for their own economic misery, wrecking the building and farming sectors, knocking 20% off the value of everyone's savings and making millions of contributing doctors, engineers, scientists and nurses feel unwelcome.
I'd trade fifty people from Sunderland for one Polish builder.||Not sure why they've got a picture of Wayne Bridge playing for Southampton in that painting.
text:
Lynden Gooch sometimes struggles to comprehend just how rapidly his life has changed. “A couple of months ago I don’t think many people knew who I was,” he says, breaking into a high-wattage smile capable of powering a set of floodlights. “No one knew anything much about me but David Moyes has altered everything.”

Related: Ireland v New Zealand, Shohei Ohtani hits the roof and mongoose stops play
title: Sunderland’s Lynden Gooch: ‘People say bad things about the north-east but I don’t know why’

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
Why was there no review of Watch Dogs 2? 
(hey that rhymes)||"£49.99 it’s great value for money" that's if you can get one, Nintendo have once again created an artificial shortage to build hype, it's something they keep doing and it's getting tiresome.||Lets also remember kids, NES games are difficult!||" There’s no way to switch games once you’ve launched one, short of physically resetting the console" ahhh, what a pain... flicking a reset button/on off switch is so much harder than, pause game, select from menu exit....||I don't think I'll chance it with this new NES gadget even if I can get one for £50 as I have still got my NES from way back and the original Super Mario and Duck Hunt still works fine (although Super Mario 3 is a blocky mess no matter how many times I blow on the cartridge). Also I would have wanted Nintendo World Cup to be included.
text:
Nintendo Classic Mini NES

Nintendo, cert: NA
★★★

Retro has reigned supreme lately, and Nintendo’s new microconsole – packing in 30 games from the Nintendo Entertainment System’s glory days – only adds to the momentum.
title: Games reviews roundup: Nintendo Classic Mini NES; Robinson: The Journey; Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; SM-G900W8 Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.85 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
We should have usury laws. A rate of no more than (say) LIBOR + 20. The loan companies would then have to charge a fee for a riskier loan as opposed to wrapping them all up in huge interest rates, knowing there will be a large default rate.
Banning them altogether would be a bad idea - loan sharks still await.||He shouldn't ignore the IVA company, it should be possible to revise his payments to take account of his changed circumstances. But he'll have to own up to the other loan, too. If it gets added to the IVA, at least the interest charges will stop mounting up.||Banks (Barclays & Lloyds are 2 that regularly pester me) have also restarted sending out unsolicited credit card application forms. Lessons have not been learned.||I suggest getting a call/txt blocker app. There's loads of great ones out there which automatically block/reject known telemarketers, spam etc.||Bloody manaces! A lot of the call centre workers at my company resort to these loans as their wages are so low. They give out the switchboard at work as their contact number, and when I work reception sometimes I get several calls a day asking for various call centre workers, some of which have only worked there a few days, or have not worked there for many months. Sometimes they try and get me to give them mobile numbers for these people but of course I refuse, and also I would never put the these calls through even if the person was actually working that day. Annoying for me as they waste time and block the switchboard so clients can't get through, but that is the tip of the iceberg when it comes to these morally bankrupt outfits by the looks of it.
text:
Alex Jones* has to switch his phone off at work so the constant text messages do not distract him. He gets around 20-25 a day from payday lenders and brokers offering high-cost loans of up to £1,000 a time.

“Need cash? We have reviewed your application …” a typical text reads. “A loan of up to £900 is ready to complete,” says another. “We’ve received your loan inquiry. Are you able to take our call? Reply YES …”.
title: 25 texts and emails a day: how payday loan firms hound vulnerable borrowers

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
His stories are like dark but humorous fairy stories. Who could fail to love Tobamory, the talking cat, gossiping about scandalous goings-on in the household?||"People talk vaguely about the innocence of a little child, but they take mighty good care not to let it out of their sight for twenty minutes.” 
Saki||'She is leaving her present home and going to Lower Seymour Street.'
'She certainly will if she lives there long enough.'||I once got into trouble with my sister for reading 'The Storyteller' to her small children.
Thats the one where a 'horribly good' girl was eaten alive by a wolf which heard the medals she had won for being so good clinking as she hid.
The children quite liked the story..........||"It was not her usual day for having a headache, but she was determined to have as much headache as possible." (The Unrest Cure.) Have his stories ever been televised?
text:
If only Saki – the pen name of Hector Hugh Munro – were still alive. The age of Trump needs his brutal dismantling of human stupidities. Despite a coterie of literary fans, Saki’s icy, perfectly constructed short stories have been relatively little read over the past 50 years – years of smug belief in endless progress – but his tales, by turns malevolent and macabre, may be due a revival in our new age of exigency.

Related: George Saunders's funny, sad stories from a divided nation
title: Why Saki’s stories are due a revival

Who could fail to love Tobamory, the talking cat, gossiping about scandalous goings-on in the household?||"People talk vaguely about the innocence of a little child, but they take mighty good care not to let it out of their sight for twenty minutes.” 
Saki||'She is leaving her present home and going to Lower Seymour Street.'
'She certainly will if she lives there long enough.'||I once got into trouble with my sister for reading 'The Storyteller' to her small children.
Thats the one where a 'horribly good' girl was eaten alive by a wolf which heard the medals she had won for being so good clinking as she hid.
The children quite liked the story..........||"It was not her usual day for having a headache, but she was determined to have as much headache as possible." (The Unrest Cure.) Have his stories ever been televised?
text:
If only Saki – the pen name of Hector Hugh Munro – were still alive. The age of Trump needs his brutal dismantling of human stupidities. Despite a coterie of literary fans, Saki’s icy, perfectly constructed short stories have been relatively little read over the past 50 years – years of smug belief in endless progress – but his tales, by turns malevolent and macabre, may be due a revival in our new age of exigency.

Related: George Saunders's funny, sad stories from a divided nation
title: Why Saki’s stories are due a revival

comments: Pisser we'll see how pointless FIFA are||I mean it's not as if they weren't told this exact thing would happen.||what about the 'respect' badge? fifa have no problem with that, presumably because fifa (uefa?) make the teams wear it. but that could be seen as a political message if poppies can: some countries choose not to respect certain types of humans...||Since when was the poppy a political symbol? It's an item which is worn by people of across the political spectrum to remember the consequences of hostile politics. If anything, it's the opposite of a political symbol.||As if FIFA have any moral authority...
text:
Fifa has commenced disciplinary proceedings against England and Scotland for wearing armbands featuring poppies on Armistice Day.

The issue sparked a national debate when Fifa indicated that wearing the symbol would be in contravention of its rules relating to the display of political symbols. The English and Scottish FAs said they planned to wear the armbands regardless for the World Cup qualifier at Wembley last Friday, which England won 3-0.
title: Fifa begins disciplinary proceedings over England and Scotland poppies

comments:
It's the Dafoe show, but the rest of the cast do a fine job. To me it's Schrader's swansong||I've been on the lookout for ages for one of Schrader's films from around 2000, called Affliction. It had Nick Nolte and James Coburn; the latter was nommed for an oscar. Apparently that was a great movie with some fine performances. Also Blue Collar with Richard Pryor, Yaphet Kotto and Harvey Keitel was highly rated. 
Schrader was always a bit leftfield, but the best bad director seems a little harsh given his earlier works.At the very least, he will always be the writer of Taxi Driver.||I don't know who to believe on this- Bradshaw gives it four stars, but Kermode the other day slated it. I am inclined to think the latter can be too easily put off by a rather prudish sensibility when it comes to drugs and swearing. But then much of what I read about this film makes it sound like the worst sub-sub-Tarantino dreck of the kind that people stopped making in about 2003.||Schrader has all the qualifications for being a great director - except actually being a great director.||No reviewer seems able to get past the casting in discussing 'The Canyons'. The film's subject is the death of Hollywood as a place with any kind of creative ambition and its replacement by money-men who only understand making a quick buck out of cheap sensationalism. Schrader's subsequent films sound like they've been designed to illustrate his thesis.
text:
Related: Dog Eat Dog review – Willem Dafoe is magnificently needy in Paul Schrader's tasty thriller

Age is not mellowing 1970s wunderkind writer-director Paul Schrader one bit. Now aged 70 and essentially an outcast in Hollywood, he’s spent the past few years, the sunset of his career, doing what his contemporaries were doing at the dawn of theirs half a century ago for Roger Corman: savouring the untold creative freedoms available to inspired artists on Z-movie budgets. Since The Canyons – in which he cast the most mercurial household name in the States, Lindsay Lohan, and its most famous (and, as it turned out, most creepy) male porn star, James Deen – he’s been making his movies like a film student, improvising, stunt-casting, rewriting on set, filming in friends’ houses. It’s as if he’s living his career in reverse.
title: Dog Eat Dog: is Paul Schrader the world's best bad director?

comments: Nice. Sounds just like me. Five-minute drive to station, an hour and fifteen train journey from Hants to Waterloo, ten-minute tube ride. Get the 5.40am train, at my desk by just after 7, home for 5.20pm for meal with the kids. Deserted(ish) trains. A joy.||"Too many people pulled and pushes around. Too many people looking for a piece of cake "Macca.||Agreed. I used to commute from Tottenham to Esher. The first part of the journey ( Victoria line to Vauxhall ) was no fun at all, but the second part ( slow train from Vauxhall to Esher ) was great. I'd get through a book a week.||While the author may enjoy a long commute by rail i can say that a good deal of people don't, it is a shame that virtually everywhere within 50 miles of London is basically a dormitory for the city and that a lot of people no longer work locally, this has caused most of the south east of England to become famously lacking in community. When will people start campaigning for local work so that they can spend more time with their friends and family?||i can see the upside if you've time to read / work etc. But when it's drive-time, then it sucks. Currently doing a 1:15 each way, and it's just the dead-time that really grates. I can't wait for autonomous cars personally.
text:
Commuting is the worst part of most people’s day. That was certainly the case for me when I was travelling 45 minutes, there and back, across London each day. On packed trains I would close my eyes and wish I was somewhere else. But then I swapped that for a four-and-a-half-hour round trip between Stafford and the capital, and I suddenly began to love my commute.

As someone who travels more than 90 miles to work I’m part of a rising phenomenon of super-commuters. The number of workers who commute daily for two hours or more has increased by a third in five years. As workers are priced out of inner cities, London in particular, those looking for the security of owning their home have had to look further afield.
title: A commute of over two hours each way? Super

comments: Nice. Sounds just like me. Five-minute drive to station, an hour and fifteen train journey from Hants to Waterloo, ten-minute tube ride. Get the 5.40am train, at my desk by just after 7, home for 5.20pm for meal with the kids. Deserted(ish) trains. A joy.||"Too many people pulled and pushes around. Too many people looking for a piece of cake "Macca.||Agreed. I used to commute from Tottenham to Esher. The first part of the journey ( Victoria line to Vauxhall ) was no fun at all, but the second part ( slow train from Vauxhall to Esher ) was great. I'd get through a book a week.||While the author may enjoy a long commute by rail i can say that a good deal of people don't, it is a shame that virtually everywhere within 50 miles of London is basically a dormitory for the city and that a lot of people no longer work locally, this has caused most of the south east of England to become famously lacking in community. When will people start campaigning for local work so that they can spend more time with their friends and family?||i can see the upside if you've time to read / work etc. But when it's drive-time, then it sucks. Currently doing a 1:15 each way, and it's just the dead-time that really grates. I can't wait for autonomous cars personally.
text:
Commuting is the worst part of most people’s day. That was certainly the case for me when I was travelling 45 minutes, there and back, across London each day. On packed trains I would close my eyes and wish I was somewhere else. But then I swapped that for a four-and-a-half-hour round trip between Stafford and the capital, and I suddenly began to love my commute.

As someone who travels more than 90 miles to work I’m part of a rising phenomenon of super-commuters. The number of workers who commute daily for two hours or more has increased by a third in five years. As workers are priced out of inner cities, London in particular, those looking for the security of owning their home have had to look further afield.
title: A commute of over two hours each way? Super

comments:
Kolarov has also improved massively under Pep.||You might as well say the whole Chelsea team had improved. It's a testament to Conte when the 10th best team of last season looks better than never before in such a short space of time. Matic is the beast of his first 18 months again and even David Luiz looks unbeatable.
But the only thing I'm curious is how Raheem Sterling is in the most improved list? He looked awful against Scotland.||Antonio Valencia has drastically improved since Jose arrived. 
Shame about his arm injury.||Wot, no Moussa Sissoko?
A tad surprised that no Spurs players (i.e. Eriksen) are in the "down side XI.||Liverpool should have kept Joe Allen. Much better player than Henderson the backpass merchant.
text:
Jordan Pickford (Sunderland)

Last season, after returning from a loan stint at Preston, the young goalkeeper had to continue learning his trade by sitting on a bench and contemplating how he might displace Vito Mannone. On-field action was restricted to three appearances during which he conceded nine goals and although those goals were not his fault, he began this season still an understudy to the Italian. Mannone’s injury, however, has given the 22-year-old a steady run in the first team and he has grasped his opportunity as convincingly as he claims crosses. Despite committing a costly blunder against Southampton in his first outing of the season, he has been one of Sunderland’s most reliable performers even when left obscenely exposed by his defence. His saves were a big factor in his club’s first Premier League win of the season against Bournemouth and his performance at White Hart Lane in September, when Hugo Lloris hailed him as amazing, was the main reason Sunderland escaped with only a narrow defeat. At a time of gloom at the Stadium of Light, Pickford has managed to confirm he has a very bright future.

Related: Ander Herrera: ‘Spain has the best midfield in the world by a long way’ | Sid Lowe
title: Premier League’s most improved XI: from Pickford to Pedro, a team on the up

text:
They say Canary Islanders are the Brazilians of Spain and when Vitolo was growing up in Gran Canaria his idol was Ronaldo. But he also sought inspiration in a man from Bethnal Green. The Sevilla winger who will play for Spain at Wembley on Tuesday was raised in Las Palmas, played for Unión Deportiva de Las Palmas’s youth team and watched the first team from the stands at the now abandoned, crumbling Estadio Insular – when he didn’t watch them from the touchline, where he was a ballboy.

Related: Ander Herrera: ‘Spain has the best midfield in the world by a long way’ | Sid Lowe
title: Vitolo: ‘Teams in Spain are better tactically – but English ones have power’

comments: "But he said that, since the film came out, he drives past there and he gets a kind of warm feeling. I think that’s kind of beautiful, that the movie could have changed his associations.”Indeed that is beautiful. It's also a sign of healing.||Very good article concerning one of the defining artists of a generation and himself and his wife's attempts to make peace with such a terrible tragedy. A must watch.||he lives down the road from me in sussex square||It's a wonderful, painful film. Beautifully made but unbearably sad. A real achievement.||It's a cruel irony that - despite spending many years bombarding his mind, body and soul with drugs, booze, sex, violence and general bad attitude - it took the needless death of a child for Cave to acquire genuine "tortured artist" status.
text:
By his own admission, director Andrew Dominik’s relationship with Nick Cave did not get off to an auspicious start. It was the late 80s and Dominik was a film student, whose new girlfriend had broken up with Cave “about three months beforehand”. To compound matters, shortly after they began going out, Cave released a single bearing the woman’s name: Deanna, which depicts Cave ejaculating over her clothes and then enticing her to join him in a murder spree inspired by 50s teenage serial killer Charlie Starkweather. “Yeah, it was kind of intimidating,” Dominik says today, over Skype from his LA home. “I was 20 years old or something, and Nick Cave was like the dark prince of Melbourne. I wasn’t predisposed to being a Nick Cave fan, but he’s really good and I reluctantly became one.”

Related: Nick Cave documentary was 'instinct of self-preservation' after death of son
title: Nick Cave documentary director Andrew Dominik: ‘He hated a third of my movie’

comments: "But he said that, since the film came out, he drives past there and he gets a kind of warm feeling. I think that’s kind of beautiful, that the movie could have changed his associations.”Indeed that is beautiful. It's also a sign of healing.||Very good article concerning one of the defining artists of a generation and himself and his wife's attempts to make peace with such a terrible tragedy. A must watch.||he lives down the road from me in sussex square||It's a wonderful, painful film. Beautifully made but unbearably sad. A real achievement.||It's a cruel irony that - despite spending many years bombarding his mind, body and soul with drugs, booze, sex, violence and general bad attitude - it took the needless death of a child for Cave to acquire genuine "tortured artist" status.

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 6.0.1; SM-G900W8 Build/MMB29M) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.85 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments:
Glenda Jackson was for me THE definitive Lear - quite astonishing. I enjoyed the production as a whole, even if I wasn't convinced by everything about it. But Glenda Jackson was breathtaking.||'Celia Imrie and Jane Horrocks, both actors I would travel to see, are strangely underpowered as Goneril and Regan.' Really? On the evidence their performances in this production, I would be travelling in the opposite direction from where they were performing. Throwing Gloucester's eye into the audience, turning one of the most harrowing scenes in world drama into a laughing matter, a pantomime. Really? Which leads me to: 'More than any other director she produces wonderfully good and really duff moments. Sometimes within one production.' Since when has that been a good thing? What happened to a unifying vision realised theatrically that leaves you breathless, as with - off the top of my head - Ivo van Hove's 'A View from the Bridge' at the Young Vic? No, this production is shaming in its incompetence. No wonder some people left at the interval.||SOME duff MOMENTS? Her production of School for Scandal at the Barbican was one entire duff moment - put me off going to see any of her work ever again.||Dissenting voice here I thought the production was a bit rubbish ... incoherent, no attempt at really working with Lear's motivation, most actors' diction was pretty poor, the sexual sub-plot between the ill-chosen Edmond and the two sisters was way beyond any theatrical suspension of disbelief. 
Yes old Glenda was on fine form but this rested solely on being a big star draw. For me it didn't hang together at all. Certainly not worth the entry price. Director totally played it by the numbers, utterly lazy, shallow minimalist staging - utterly default in these days.||I want productions to stretch and challenge me: but to baffle and confuse? I couldn't see, or find, a unifying thread in this production. It seemed to lack an ensemble style in acting or design. I found the acting very uneven, and the huge stage worked against the actors, some of whose voices didn't project. There were powerful moments and Jackson's lower vocal range was extraordinary and compelling (though I found her wheedling high voice offputting).Most of the actors (e.g. Celia Imrie, Simon Manyonda, Harry Melling) didn't convince, or only sporadically. Throwing the gouged eye into the auditorium seemed a horrible misjudgement. The storm scene was powerfully staged, but why was it the only scene to be presented so dramatically? Why a refrigerator in the centre of one scene? I didn't understand so many of the production decisions.Verdict: Miss.
text:
Sandpaper voice; gliding movement; complete, ferocious concentration. Glenda Jackson cleavers her way through the part of King Lear. I was expecting her to be good. I was not prepared for her being one the most powerful Lears I have seen.

It is not simply what Jackson does that makes her so authentic. It is what she does not do. No wavering voice, no rheumy eyes. Command shines out of her. In many productions when the disguised Kent says he sees authority in the old king’s face, it is hard to see what he means through the regal shambles. Not here. This monarch treats even her own emotions as if they were unruly lackeys. Scorn is a strong note. The curses are relished, delivered in a voice that sounds like a football rattle. The steps to madness are precisely marked. Nothing is wasted; nothing is superfluous. Which is one kind of great acting: it’s the economy, stupid.
title: King Lear review – Glenda Jackson is magnificent

comments:
Actually, I agree with this. I was going to bring the family to see this play but after reading this I think I'd be better off spending our money on enabling someone with dwarfism to earn a decent wage in decent conditions.||Peter Dinklage has proven there is opportunity for dwarf actors to transcend the roles we normally associate with them. 
His Tyrion has proven to be one of telly's most memorable characters, inspired by the expert acting chops of Dinklage in a well-written role only party-defined by his dwarfism.
Get yourself a good agent. And if you have the chops, and a bit of luck, you may get more interesting roles.
Politically-correct casting isn't the way forward. People see through that and in the end the art can suffer for it. However I mostly agree with you that, as long as funds & availability permit, traditional dwarf characters are best played by dwarf actors. The physicality of the role is key.||Real dwarf actors are rare and therefore expensive but shouldn't be replaced with special effects of children, sounds rather like a protection racket||I remember watching the primordial dwarf from The Island of Dr Moreau and thinking, "I bet Andre the Giant would have knocked that performance out of the park".||" Other disabilities are also experiencing this; look at Eddie Redmayne cast to portray Stephen Hawking in the recent biopic. "
This notion that only x actors can play x characters, or only y actors can play y characters, is terrible and should be resisted.
text:
“Britain’s panto dwarves are grumpy at being frozen out by average height actors” reported the Telegraph on Monday. At this time of year, newspapers like to trumpet a “dwarf shortage”, or something to similar effect. This year, it has been reported that a pantomime company is choosing to employ taller actors in a production of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs as they charge lower rates than actors with dwarfism.

Related: People with dwarfism deserve respect – not ridicule | Kiruna Stamell
title: I’m an actor with dwarfism, but I can do more than just appear in Snow White
