browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
Well done for highlighting issues with Academy funding, accountability yet again. It shows the nonsense path of privatisation. A shame ministers DfE choose not to see the problems.||‘The DfE has already spent £33.5 million just on buying the site for the school’.  Just to be clear what a huge sum that is, the annual funding of our 800-pupil 11-16 outstanding secondary academy in a Shire county is around £3.8 million. That is our total income from the Government including the DSG, Pupil Premium funding, Educational Services Grant, catch-up funding, rates relief and high- needs top-up funding. The £3.8 million together with around £200k that we make from lettings pays for all teaching resources, all exam fees, all teacher and non-teacher salaries, employers NI contributions, employers pension contributions, all support services, all utilities all insurances, all repairs and maintenance, all ICT costs. Everything in fact.  The Guardian might consider running an article comparing the costs of opening a new free school with the costs of expanding existing provision. Providing a choice of schools is obviously something to aspire to, but is it ethical in these times of austerity?||Bright Tribe should not be involved in the conversion of any more schools to academy status until a full investigation into it's management has been conducted. Also the DfE should absolutely clear as to it's relationship with Bright Tribe including the previous Education secretary.||We have a USSR style form of funding and provision in education. Money should be allocated on a market supply and demand basis with a combination of means tested fees and an education voucher or per capita funding system. The principle should be that money moves around with the pupil rather than simply a top down grant from the exchequer. There are basic standards like safeguarding, transparency, basic curriculum requirements (think 3 Rs), health & safety, equal opportunities etc which should be enforced, but we've also got this top down centralised model in which 'the gentleman in Whitehall knows best' or equally perverse is the situation in which schools simply become political fiefdoms in which exam results become a condition for prize money without any regard for the development of pupils.||Ofsted found safeguarding arrangements at Brookfield were inadequate, the governors had not met since February, that the school had serious teacher recruitment and retention problems, and “systems to hold leaders to account are in disarray”.
Leaving "safeguarding" aside - and we all know that's just a sop to bolting the door at Soham long after the horse had bolted, everything else sounds like the reason for academies, not a criticism of them. Get rid of governors, evade oversight and churn teachers as fast as you can. Next people will be acting all surprised that academy chains suck out vast amounts of money. While the hell would they exist of they couldn't do that?
text:
Ministers approved additional funding for an academy chain last year despite having serious concerns about it, a government investigation has revealed. Last November the then education secretary, Nicky Morgan, awarded Stockport-based Bright Tribe, one of five “top performing academy sponsors”, an undisclosed share of £5m to take on struggling non-academy schools. But an Education Funding Agency report [pdf] last week discloses that as far back as July 2015 the government had received “allegations concerning non-compliance” with the rules on the trust’s contracts with companies and on its interactions with firms connected to trustees.

This initial review in 2015 “highlighted a number of breaches of the [academies financial handbook]”, says the EFA report. After a follow-up investigation this year, Bright Tribe is making changes to the way it operates.
title: Has critical funding report taken shine off Bright Tribe academy chain?

Get rid of governors, evade oversight and churn teachers as fast as you can. Next people will be acting all surprised that academy chains suck out vast amounts of money. While the hell would they exist of they couldn't do that?
text:
Ministers approved additional funding for an academy chain last year despite having serious concerns about it, a government investigation has revealed. Last November the then education secretary, Nicky Morgan, awarded Stockport-based Bright Tribe, one of five “top performing academy sponsors”, an undisclosed share of £5m to take on struggling non-academy schools. But an Education Funding Agency report [pdf] last week discloses that as far back as July 2015 the government had received “allegations concerning non-compliance” with the rules on the trust’s contracts with companies and on its interactions with firms connected to trustees.

This initial review in 2015 “highlighted a number of breaches of the [academies financial handbook]”, says the EFA report. After a follow-up investigation this year, Bright Tribe is making changes to the way it operates.
title: Has critical funding report taken shine off Bright Tribe academy chain?

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments: 5 years out in 2 and a half. That is a joke sentence for killing someone.||Why drag Jeremy Clarkson into this?||The most depressing thing is that these vermin do not receive adequate punishment. Where is the deterrent?||You're one of your own best friends?||Five years for taking a life? Do we wonder at the crime figures in this country.
text:
Punching – it’s what men do to each other isn’t it? When they’re angry, or jealous, or drunk, or they just don’t know the words. It’s just normal animal behaviour, what Jeremy Clarkson does when his dinner’s the wrong temperature. But – as this disturbing documentary, One Killer Punch (Channel 4), demonstrates – it can mean the end of someone’s life.

“I’m not a violent person,” says Ben, before immediately contradicting himself. “After I punched him, you see me on CCTV, I went back to the party, felt really bad.” Ben was involved in a fracas outside a house party. He was about to get stuck into one boy when George intervened – to stop them fighting, say George’s friends. But Ben says George was shoving him in the chest, then clenched his fist, was just about to hit him, and it was only then that Ben punched him, in self-defence.
title: One Killer Punch review: a desperately sad and depressing film

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/54.0.2840.99 Safari/537.36
comments:
It was Toynbee's beloved Gordon Brown who quadrupled house prices in London, pricing ordinary people out of ever owning a home and socially cleansing the city.
She was silent as long as it was the working class who were suffering.||Only an idiot would start a young family if they couldn't be sure of a home for it.
The role of society should not be the mitigation of idiotic choices by individuals.||Theresa May will be popular as long as she continues to issue warm words about governing for all, not just the privileged and supporting `just managing families, but at the same time doing precisely the opposite.
And why will she still be streets ahead of Labour and the Lib Dems? Because, if this year has taught us anything it has been the astonishing gullibility of millions of people who are prepared to believe anything they are told, just as long as it’s what they want to hear.If she insists on hanging on till 2020 her popularity will undoubtedly plummet, she cannot sustain the lies she casually spews out indefinitely.||When their first child was born, 14 years ago, Rob and Emma, who are now both 34, lived above a pub where Rob worked, but children weren’t allowed in staff quarters.
So... they knew that they wouldn't be able to house a child in their current circumstances but went ahead and had one anyway?||"Ignorance is bliss, as Theresa May soars in the polls."
Oh dear PT. This subject transcends politics but still you make this crass statement. About time this organ got real about the lack of housing.
text:
In a world turned upside down, we still know surprisingly little about our government. Ignorance is bliss, as Theresa May soars in the polls. With little to go on, people are free to hope and imagine whatever they like. So far we have only her well-penned good intentions towards “just managing” families. Next week we shall know her better, when the autumn statement unveils her true direction, alongside a white paper on housing. Governments are defined by their taxing and spending, by who gains and who loses.

Related: Crisis, what housing crisis? We just need fresh thinking | Simon Jenkins
title: Only a decrepit society would deprive young families of a home

comments: catwoman.. and it shows.||After that home camera caught that woman putting a cat into a bin, this killer could be someone least expected..||So we know it was a man? That narrows it down.||I'm no fan of cats and the idea that they will roll over and let you stroke their bellies is from experience not always or even often true. They're just crap compared to dogs. However what you say about the clearly very disturbed man (and it is almost certainly a man) torturing and killing the animals is true. He is doing this to inflict pain upon the owners, he is doing it to instil fear in people not animals. At some point it is likely that he'll overcome his obvious fear of directly hurting his victims and will go after the owners themselves.||Very disturbing.This man(and man it surely will be)appears to be doing this not so much because he hates cats,working girls, racial or other minorities,but because he hates people. All people.As a "person"himself he probably self-hates too.That's one helluva sicko.
text:
The cat killer has struck again. It’s a year since the first body was found, head, tail and organs removed, body placed in its owner’s driveway overnight. They called him the Croydon cat killer, but 100 bodies later he’s been renamed to encompass the entire M25, murdering up to six cats a week across London, with beheaded corpses also found in Nottingham, Sheffield, Maidenhead, Wallington and Westerham. As the tiny corpses pile up in their freezers, police are no closer to catching him.

This is the kind of story that burrows into you, and stays there like a tick. It is horrific, obviously – there’s the suggestion that a person who appears to delight not just in mutilating animals but presenting their bodies in children’s playgrounds and on their owners’ doorsteps will one day move on to torturing people. But there’s another level of sinister to it, too – a sort of terrible appreciation of how to really hurt a human. The idea of a cat (rather than any other animal) being lured to its horrible death with a piece of raw chicken and a stroke of its ears is particularly awful for us because isn’t one of the things that makes them lovable that very vulnerability? They invite affection from strangers, they roll on their backs, exposing the softest parts of them.
title: The M25 cat killer’s real target  is our own soft underbellies

However what you say about the clearly very disturbed man (and it is almost certainly a man) torturing and killing the animals is true. He is doing this to inflict pain upon the owners, he is doing it to instil fear in people not animals. At some point it is likely that he'll overcome his obvious fear of directly hurting his victims and will go after the owners themselves.||Very disturbing.This man(and man it surely will be)appears to be doing this not so much because he hates cats,working girls, racial or other minorities,but because he hates people. All people.As a "person"himself he probably self-hates too.That's one helluva sicko.
text:
The cat killer has struck again. It’s a year since the first body was found, head, tail and organs removed, body placed in its owner’s driveway overnight. They called him the Croydon cat killer, but 100 bodies later he’s been renamed to encompass the entire M25, murdering up to six cats a week across London, with beheaded corpses also found in Nottingham, Sheffield, Maidenhead, Wallington and Westerham. As the tiny corpses pile up in their freezers, police are no closer to catching him.

This is the kind of story that burrows into you, and stays there like a tick. It is horrific, obviously – there’s the suggestion that a person who appears to delight not just in mutilating animals but presenting their bodies in children’s playgrounds and on their owners’ doorsteps will one day move on to torturing people. But there’s another level of sinister to it, too – a sort of terrible appreciation of how to really hurt a human. The idea of a cat (rather than any other animal) being lured to its horrible death with a piece of raw chicken and a stroke of its ears is particularly awful for us because isn’t one of the things that makes them lovable that very vulnerability? They invite affection from strangers, they roll on their backs, exposing the softest parts of them.
title: The M25 cat killer’s real target  is our own soft underbellies

The US corporations will make sure that the TPP goes ahead.||Keys, who has presided over a massive increase in the poverty of his people though his neo-liberal ideology, which the current Australian government hopes to emulate, now wants to resurrect a secretive instrument of economic suppression on his people, and ours. Shameful||So... Xi Jinping said Beijing's relationship with Washington was at a "hinge moment" and called for a smooth transition.
Will all the usual Coalition suspects come out and condemn him?
China is prepared to open more doors to the outside world, should the US under Trump interfere with free trade.The entire world will be the losers if Trump goes ahead with his trade war on China.||Why would want to save the TPP. It's a disaster for all involved, except the mega corporations.
text:
The threatened TPP trade pact could be rebadged as the “Trump Pacific Partnership” to satisfy the US president-elect who has vowed to scrap it, New Zealand’s prime minister has said.

John Key suggested “cosmetic changes” to the Trans-Pacific Partnership so that the US could be kept on board under Donald Trump, who has attacked free trade deals.
title: Trump Pacific Partnership? New Zealand PM's idea to save TPP

comments: I absolutely L O V E D this show, I knew Netflix had commissioned a second series but didn't know when it was airing! This news has made my week (even if I preferred 'Scrotal Recall' to 'Lovesick').||Thats Bronns brother?||A little unfair to say in the standfirst that it was the show "no one was surprised to see cancelled" particularly when the article rightly points out how sweet yet funny it was. Devastated when it got cancelled and absolutely DELIGHTED now it's back!||Pleased this is returning. Definitely a cut above the rest. The terrifying bride in one of the early episodes passes through my head from time to time!||Oh good, I liked this. As you say it was quite far away from what I iimagined from the title and seemed to involve real characters just getting through modern life. With funniness.
text:
Related: Scrotal Recall: an infectious and very clever concept

Scrotal Recall: as titles go, it wasn’t everyone’s bag. When the Channel 4 sitcom first aired in 2014, both critics and viewers struggled to get past that name, despite it being an ingenious low-humour wrapper for the show’s high concept. Armed with a list of his past lovers, footloose young romantic Dylan – played with shaggy charm by sometime folk musician Johnny Flynn, half-brother of Jerome – embarked on a quest to inform them of his recent chlamydia diagnosis. Each episode, named for the old flame, then flashed back to their original hook-up. Here was the postmodern sleight of hand of a slick US hit like How I Met Your Mother beefed up with the sexual frankness of post-Skins young-adult Britcoms.
title: A whole new ball game: the unlikely return of STI sitcom Scrotal Recall

comments: WTH & WTF||As the mother of a child with autism it means a lot to me when people as successful and influential in their field as Tommy Hilfiger talk about autism in their lives.||How was he a friend of JFK? Must be childhood friend as the article says he is 65.||John Junior?||"Kunst, als Schein, ist Kleid eines unsichtbaren Körpers. So ist Mode Kleid als Absolutes. Darin verstehen sich beide." - TW Adorno.
text:
I used to adore Mickey Mouse and watching The Mickey Mouse Club. I grew up in Elmira, New York. The house was small, but very pleasant. I had eight brothers and sisters so it was noisy. Our television was black and white and we’d all huddle round to watch.

My relationship with my father in the earlier years was strange. He wanted me to be a grade A student. He wanted me to go to an Ivy League school. I wasn’t great at school. It was only after I became successful that he realised I was more disciplined than he’d thought.
title: Tommy Hilfiger: 'I've been buried under an avalanche in Austria'

Darin verstehen sich beide." - TW Adorno.
text:
I used to adore Mickey Mouse and watching The Mickey Mouse Club. I grew up in Elmira, New York. The house was small, but very pleasant. I had eight brothers and sisters so it was noisy. Our television was black and white and we’d all huddle round to watch.

My relationship with my father in the earlier years was strange. He wanted me to be a grade A student. He wanted me to go to an Ivy League school. I wasn’t great at school. It was only after I became successful that he realised I was more disciplined than he’d thought.
title: Tommy Hilfiger: 'I've been buried under an avalanche in Austria'

text:
It’s a strange day at Q-Tip’s house in suburban New Jersey. It’s the night of the launch party for We Got It from Here … Thank You 4 Your Service, A Tribe Called Quest’s first album in 18 years, and their last. But it’s also less than 24 hours after the shock election of Donald Trump so the excitement is somewhat muted. “Weird day,” mutters Q-Tip, Tribe’s 46-year-old MC, producer and mastermind. “Speechless.”

He was rooting heavily for Trump’s opponent. Hanging on the wall, beneath a photograph of Q-Tip with Harry Belafonte, is a framed letter from Hillary Clinton, congratulating him on his appointment as the Kennedy Center’s first artistic director for hip-hop culture. Q-Tip made a cameo appearance in the leaked John Podesta emails, asking for a meeting with Clinton to help with her campaign. Earlier today, Tribe were rehearsing for the post-election episode of Saturday Night Live. What was expected to be a celebration looks likely to be a wake. That’s going to be a weird gig, I suggest.
title: A Tribe Called Quest return: ‘You fight for what you love – and you go through hell to get it’

comments:
Fizzy hummus: been there||��||Should be April 1st...especially at that price.||"However, the necessity of setting up a personal profile on the app feels, well, nosy. How do someone’s age, job and address affect whether their chicken nuggets are on the turn? Can a 25-year-old mechanic from Prestatyn eat a four-day-old rogan josh? Does lamb stay fresh for longer if you’re an Estuary actuary in her late 50s? It smells fishy to me."
Now, I leave my tinfoil in the cupboard where it belongs, rather than engaging in millinery; but that's nailed it. Why is data harvesting necessary in this instance?||..but did it work?
text:
What?

The Food Sniffer (£105, myfoodsniffer.com): organic chemical sensors housed in a plastic baton. Detects molecular decomposition in meat and fish.

Why?

What the nose knows isn’t good enough.
title: Kitchen gadgets review: Food Sniffer – ‘It smells fishy to me’

comments:
This sounds wonderful!||I saw Peter Pan at the RSC as a child - Peter was a very young Mark Rylance. It was probably the first full-length play I ever went to. Can still remember bits of it vividly from 35-odd years ago.||This sounds awful 
Why is there such a need to chip away at stuff that many of us have so many happy memories of, first ghostbusters now this
I'd have more respect if these people had their own ideas rather than poorly chip away at better ideas from others||I always thought it was about Wendy anyway...
Does this make me a feminist?! The chaps at the golf club will be furious...||If she wishes to turn the usual productions of Peter Pan on their heads... wouldn't Wendy be a bloke ? Just as Peter is usually played by a female in theatre productions !
text:
“I have vivid memories of my son at about four months old, sitting in a cardboard box in my sitting room while a friend and I were having a meeting about a show.” Sally Cookson is recalling what it was like, 20 years ago, to manage a new career as an actor-turned-director with two young children, Arthur and Nell. “We were setting up our next production and doing it with Arthur in this box, stuffing things in it so that he wouldn’t fall over, trying to get the show on the road. It was that endless juggling.”

Now her children – Nell, 19, a student, and Arthur, 22, a jazz musician – are grown-up and Cookson has quietly become known as one of the UK’s most innovative directors, especially in family theatre. She is married to the composer John O’Hara and the two often collaborate on projects.
title: How I made Wendy the real star of Peter Pan

text:
For patrons missing their darlings, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, this final week of the tennis season in London has opened a window on the future and the view through the winter mist is somewhere between encouraging and uncertain.

The seats at the O2 Arena in Greenwich are still amply occupied but there is no escaping the fact the veteran Swiss and his faltering Spanish rival would have lent the ATP World Tour Finals their seasonal magic.
title: Dominic Thiem gives glimpse of future in victory over Gaël Monfils

text:
Spoiler alert: this article, out of necessity, refers to the plot of I, Daniel Blake frequently.

Ken Loach’s brilliant film, I, Daniel Blake, is a highly realistic portrayal of many of the problems with the UK benefits system. We at the Zacchaeus 2000 Trust (Z2K) – a charity addressing poverty issues caused by unfairness in the law, legal and benefits system – were deeply moved by how it showed the day-to-day reality of poverty and trying to access welfare benefit.
title: Are you Daniel Blake? Here’s a guide to using our nightmarish benefits system

comments:
Women are disproportionately affected by austerity, climate change and anti-EU manoeuvres. The right wing conspiracy helps no-one, but its misogynistic links help maintain an unfair pay disparity, which also affects Scotland to an unacceptable amount. Neocons have unfortunately taken the lead on this and the average man and especially woman in the street is unable to fight back.||Teresa May doesn't give a shit about this - mind you she doesn't have a clue about much either. The worst PM the UK has had - as far back as I can remember.||Tax credits are a scam designed to give HMRC something to do. Far better to take the low-paid out of the tax system altogether.||Another way of looking at this is that "women have over recent years disproportionately been the beneficiaries of a large and growing benefits bill"||I love the way that the two embedded links on the word 'women' take you to The Guardian's section on 'women', Just in case you had forgotten what a woman was.
Quite frankly, I don't believe a word of this story, which takes statements by a single-issue pressure group at face value without any attempt to explore the data (assuming there are any to explore). I'm quite prepared to believe that there is a gender disparity among people with low incomes, but the figures quoted are so dramatic as to be dubious. I suspect some statistical sleight-of-hand going on.
text:
Women will have shouldered 85% of the burden of the government’s changes to the tax and benefits system by 2020, according to figures published ahead of next week’s autumn statement.

The analysis, by independent thinktank the Women’s Budget Group, shows that tax and benefit changes since 2010 will have hit women’s incomes twice as hard as men by 2020. Women will be £1,003 a year worse off by 2020 on average; for men, this figure is £555.
title: Austerity effect hits women ‘twice as hard as it does men’

comments:
“Being one year short at the end of your working life could cost nearly £5,000 in missing state pension rights through the course of a typical retirement,”
I may be finding it hard to feel sympathy for these women. They're now unable to receive child benefit because their husband is earning at least £60k, so we're not talking people on the breadline, but they're potentially missing out on a State Pension altogether because they're unable to accrue 10 qualifying years between leaving education and reading State Pension Age - we're talking between 18/21 and 65/66 so at least 44 years. The plight of the ladies who lunch.||If the income is £60,000 plus they have to actually make a decision as to whether to receive the child benefit payments or not then surely someone in the household has the intelligence to check all the implications and they did not check why not? Being one year short could mean the loss of £5000, from where does the figure come? It is all very strange, everyone I know and some of them not highly educated knew to check all implications when it came to any benefits.||The child benefit system needs changing. Currently a couple both earning £45k each (total £90k) could receive the full child benefit per month. However another household could receive Mr £65k and Mrs on £15k (Total £80k) and receive no child benefit. How is this fair?....||The pension minister who rolled out the new system and roundly rejected by the electorate is happy to carp and criticise from the sidelines - typical LibDem.||The irony - childless pensioners tucking into the private property of people whose parents will be getting less
text:
Tens of thousands of new mothers could each end up losing almost £5,000 of state pension when they are older due to an unintended quirk in the rules surrounding child benefit, according to a former government minister.

Steve Webb, ex-pensions minister, said the women, currently totalling around 50,000 but with the number rising every year, may have lost out on more than half a billion pounds in state pension rights over the past three years as a result of a wider clampdown on entitlement to child benefit. Webb makes the claim in a new report published by mutual insurer Royal London, which concludes that urgent action needs to be taken to deal with this problem “before a whole generation of women reach pension age with incomplete pension records”.
title: Refusing child benefit payments could see new mums take a state pension hit

The plight of the ladies who lunch.||If the income is £60,000 plus they have to actually make a decision as to whether to receive the child benefit payments or not then surely someone in the household has the intelligence to check all the implications and they did not check why not? Being one year short could mean the loss of £5000, from where does the figure come? It is all very strange, everyone I know and some of them not highly educated knew to check all implications when it came to any benefits.||The child benefit system needs changing. Currently a couple both earning £45k each (total £90k) could receive the full child benefit per month. However another household could receive Mr £65k and Mrs on £15k (Total £80k) and receive no child benefit. How is this fair?....||The pension minister who rolled out the new system and roundly rejected by the electorate is happy to carp and criticise from the sidelines - typical LibDem.||The irony - childless pensioners tucking into the private property of people whose parents will be getting less
text:
Tens of thousands of new mothers could each end up losing almost £5,000 of state pension when they are older due to an unintended quirk in the rules surrounding child benefit, according to a former government minister.

Steve Webb, ex-pensions minister, said the women, currently totalling around 50,000 but with the number rising every year, may have lost out on more than half a billion pounds in state pension rights over the past three years as a result of a wider clampdown on entitlement to child benefit. Webb makes the claim in a new report published by mutual insurer Royal London, which concludes that urgent action needs to be taken to deal with this problem “before a whole generation of women reach pension age with incomplete pension records”.
title: Refusing child benefit payments could see new mums take a state pension hit

comments:
Easy to criticise, but what exactly should Pelley's strategy be, given that (1) golfers are free agents & the best players are in such demand that they can pick & choose where & when they play and (2) the European Tour has vastly fewer resources than the USPGA Tour & so will alwyas be a poor relation?||Spiralling wages in football and big U.S team sports can at least be rationalised by the massive global interest in the game.
Professional golf and F1 seem to exist simply as a display of ostentatious wealth.||Golf is too expensive to attend and play. It is the victim of out of control executives taking all of the cash for themselves out of the salary bill of pretty much all companies across western europe, leaving ordinary people unable to afford golf memberships or to attend events. Golf needs large numbers of attendees at events. It does not have them for these reasons||Pelley is a clown. He even wears clown glasses. Anyone who talks about floodlit golf without collapsing into laughter really needs his head testing.||If it was sold to the public as a good thing, which it is, then that would be ok. However, it is being sold as a panacea for European Tour golf, the most exciting development in golf etc. Its not as exciting as the Zurich Championship becoming a pairs comp. 
I like Pelley, he seems to be forward thinking and want to make things happen, but as your headline states, this is Emporers New Clothes thinking.
text:
It took a dozen questions and an abundance of platitudes for a key detail of the European Tour’s Rolex Series to be revealed. Keith Pelley, the tour’s chief executive, was asked precisely where a total shortfall of about $7.7m in prize money for three 2017 events alone would come from.

“We, along with Rolex, are bringing them [each] up to $7m,” said Pelley of the purses for the BMW Championship, the Irish Open and the Scottish Open. Therefore, a much-heralded European Tour project actually looks like costing the body – who announced a 2015 loss of nearly £8m – money. With more tournaments to be added, that subsidy will grow, dependent on precisely how much Rolex are putting into this.
title: European Tour needs to watch its wallet over Rolex Series gamble

comments:
They are silent because they realise that only morons take their political advice from sports men/women/coaches.||Politics and religion should keep out of sport. And vice versa.
What a sportsman's political or religious opinions are is nobody's business.
Here in the UK we had the ludicrous situation of an athlete being hounded by his athletic organisation because he took the piss out of a religion.||How often does the Guardian sneer at sports people who come out as right wing? You can't have it both ways.||Sports stars are ruled by their sponsors, but yes they should be more vocal. Some of th arent vecause their politucal views are actually not that attractive. Its also probable that many sports people are so wrapped up.in training and their personal goals that they have very little to say on politics because they are ill informed and have no idea what's really going on.||Maybe it would be good if sportspeople spoke out more on politics, but it doesn't seem to have occurred to the author that this might mean influential figures and role models endorsing Donald Trump.
text:
Gregg Popovich began with an apology. “I don’t think my voice is that important,” replied the San Antonio Spurs coach when asked his views on the US election. But then, over the course of six impassioned minutes, one of the greatest coaches in the NBA history sank the verbal equivalent of multiple three-pointers from mid-court. “I’m sick to my stomach,” he sighed, his voice now quivering with anger and a deepening anguish. “Not because the Republicans won but the disgusting tenor and tone and all of the comments that have been xenophobic, homophobic, racist and misogynistic.”

The beat reporter tried to change tack. “I’m not done,” Popovich replied, politely but firmly. And he wasn’t. He attacked Trump supporters, pondered how “disenfranchised” women, gay and disabled people, Muslims and other minorities would be feeling, called Trump an “eighth-grade bully” and expressed his fears for America’s future in historical-lyrical terms. “My final conclusion is, my big fear is – we are Rome.”
title: Gregg Popovich sets example but silence of British sport stars speaks volumes

Its also probable that many sports people are so wrapped up.in training and their personal goals that they have very little to say on politics because they are ill informed and have no idea what's really going on.||Maybe it would be good if sportspeople spoke out more on politics, but it doesn't seem to have occurred to the author that this might mean influential figures and role models endorsing Donald Trump.
text:
Gregg Popovich began with an apology. “I don’t think my voice is that important,” replied the San Antonio Spurs coach when asked his views on the US election. But then, over the course of six impassioned minutes, one of the greatest coaches in the NBA history sank the verbal equivalent of multiple three-pointers from mid-court. “I’m sick to my stomach,” he sighed, his voice now quivering with anger and a deepening anguish. “Not because the Republicans won but the disgusting tenor and tone and all of the comments that have been xenophobic, homophobic, racist and misogynistic.”

The beat reporter tried to change tack. “I’m not done,” Popovich replied, politely but firmly. And he wasn’t. He attacked Trump supporters, pondered how “disenfranchised” women, gay and disabled people, Muslims and other minorities would be feeling, called Trump an “eighth-grade bully” and expressed his fears for America’s future in historical-lyrical terms. “My final conclusion is, my big fear is – we are Rome.”
title: Gregg Popovich sets example but silence of British sport stars speaks volumes

comments: Im a 53 year old straight guy. *bounces* slowly till friday. Shut up cynics.||Why would someone who hadn't seen the original show even want to review this? This revival is for the fans! If you don't get the in-jokes then go watch the rest of the show and leave us all to our joy.||My friend asked why I enjoyed it so much and I had to say that it was because it was just as much a fantasy world as Battlestar Galactica....and that I just want to see Lorelai happy....but she makes me soooo angry at times....make better choices Lorelai...MAKE BETTER CHOICES!!!||Never seen it, along with Buffy as mentioned in the piece. What does that make me?||Whats the point of having something review something if they have never watched it. Gilmore Girls along with West Wing is one of the greatest tv shows ever.
text:
Related: 'It's sunny and safe': why Gilmore Girls is perfect comfort TV

There are 153 episodes of the Gilmore Girls and it is time to confess that, until this point, I had never seen a single one. Such is its place in recent TV history, particularly to people who were teenage enough to grow up with it in the early 00s, that admitting to skipping this portrait of small-town mother-daughter bonding feels akin to having missed out on Friends or Buffy. Thanks to the many Buzzfeed quizzes that determine which of the show’s characters I might be based on via my food preferences, though, much of it has sunk in by osmosis. Expectations were high. I got ready for sharp dialogue, warmth that was profound but not cutesy, incisive pop-cultural references that might put peak Community to shame. But while the Gilmore army will doubtless find plenty to love and gif, for new viewers Gilmore Girls: A Year In The Life feels like a relic from an entirely different era.
title: I watched Gilmore Girls for the first time – what's all the fuss about?

comments: It is fair to say that Ukip and Trump have a necromantic obsession with golden past that never really existed. 'Make America Great Again' looks back to an era before Roe v Wade and of Jim Crow laws on the understanding that they represent a 'greatness' that needs to be restored.||What's wrong with wanting to go back to pre-Trump and pre-Brexit and (if only!) pre-Thatcher?||Bake Off and Strictly both get criticism for being diverse in ethnicity, gender and sexuality. It seems unfair to lump them into a sterile nostalgia for the past when they are both a glorious celebration of how we all get on together now.||The people like "nostalgia " not because it's avoiding issues but because it makes us feel safe and warm inside. There is a reason the 'I love the 1980s/90c etc" talking heads series was so popular, and i think it's this; we all yearn to be young again, to have the energies and mobilities we no longer possess, or certainly have less of. That's the reason, we want what makes us secure inside.||It is and yet it is less dangerous than the passion for an idealised future aka naive utopian ideals. Bernie Sanders' absurd campaign against Hillary Clinton probably cost her dearly and she was targeted for being a pragmatic centrist who had no truck with the infantile idealism proposed by Sanders.
text:
As susceptible as anyone else is to the charms of Ed Balls, I nevertheless had an eerie feeling watching Strictly Come Dancing. In the 90s, we used to talk a lot about the primacy of the retro, whether or not constantly referring back to the past meant that our innovative spirit was spent. But the reference was always knowing, and partial; you wouldn’t hark back to the 1960s without putting a fresh spin on it. You wouldn’t create a TV show that could literally have been made in the 1960s.

Related: Nostalgic for the 50s? Let me give you a history lesson | Catherine Bennett
title: An obsession with nostalgia offers us only political poison

comments: 'Fixing your mortgage rate and leveraging your assets to succeed in the real estate business' could have been the title of the first module in the Donald Trump University Course referred to elsewhere in the Grauniad ....||I completed on my house the week Trump manifested to top boy. 5 year fixed rate on a 5 year mortgage (yes, just 5 years, I live in the North!). Really glad I went with the fixed rate now.||The current low rate is not normal. It is a sign that there are problems with economy.It will be a sign of improved economy when the rates would go to pre-financial crisis of 2008 levels.||Not sure about this, it seems conflicting to have an article saying that Italian banks are likely to go down the pan and the implications on financial market and then one saying that the trump effect will cause rates to increase. Would have thought that the chaos with brexit and trump and the recession that never seems to end would mean that interest rates would remain low but I'm no financial advisor so.....||I've got 1 year left on a 5 year fix. What are the chances that my bank will let me do a new 5 or even 10 year fix without paying the bloody exit fee? I did the calculations just before the referendum - whether it was worth switching to a *different* bank which was offering the cheapest fix - and with the exit fee plus new valuation etc fees, it didn't seem worth it. I thought I'd just coast along on the SVR in a year's time (it would have been cheaper not to fix in 2012!). But now we have Brexit and Trump... and I was wondering about trying to re-fix early with my current lender.
text:
Good news: figures issued this week revealed that mortgages are more affordable than they have ever been. Bad news: Donald Trump’s US election win is set to push up the cost of new fixed-rate mortgages on this side of the pond.

So if you are thinking about signing up for one of the cheap fixed-rate deals on offer, act now to avoid paying more than you need to.
title: Fix your mortgage rate now if you’re worried about Trump and Brexit

Good news: figures issued this week revealed that mortgages are more affordable than they have ever been. Bad news: Donald Trump’s US election win is set to push up the cost of new fixed-rate mortgages on this side of the pond.

So if you are thinking about signing up for one of the cheap fixed-rate deals on offer, act now to avoid paying more than you need to.
title: Fix your mortgage rate now if you’re worried about Trump and Brexit

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Linux; Android 4.4.4; ADR6425LVW Build/IML74K) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.18 Mobile Safari/537.36
comments: 'Fixing your mortgage rate and leveraging your assets to succeed in the real estate business' could have been the title of the first module in the Donald Trump University Course referred to elsewhere in the Grauniad ....||I completed on my house the week Trump manifested to top boy. 5 year fixed rate on a 5 year mortgage (yes, just 5 years, I live in the North!). Really glad I went with the fixed rate now.||The current low rate is not normal. It is a sign that there are problems with economy.It will be a sign of improved economy when the rates would go to pre-financial crisis of 2008 levels.||Not sure about this, it seems conflicting to have an article saying that Italian banks are likely to go down the pan and the implications on financial market and then one saying that the trump effect will cause rates to increase. Would have thought that the chaos with brexit and trump and the recession that never seems to end would mean that interest rates would remain low but I'm no financial advisor so.....||I've got 1 year left on a 5 year fix. What are the chances that my bank will let me do a new 5 or even 10 year fix without paying the bloody exit fee? I did the calculations just before the referendum - whether it was worth switching to a *different* bank which was offering the cheapest fix - and with the exit fee plus new valuation etc fees, it didn't seem worth it. I thought I'd just coast along on the SVR in a year's time (it would have been cheaper not to fix in 2012!). But now we have Brexit and Trump... and I was wondering about trying to re-fix early with my current lender.

browser: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36
comments:
Probably the best bit of advice from this website all year.||I have just worked out that if we had spent the same amount ,£59 per month for the whole of our married life - 40 years- it would have cost us £28300 to have this "protection". This would have covered the cost of all of the white goods we have ever bought several times over and all of the repair bills we have ever paid. And we have had none of the hassle. Good choice never to fall for it!||If you can afford it but a Siemens or AEG with a proper 5 year warranty - it'll work out cheaper than paying the D&G premiums. 
I inherited one of their plans and naively kept it on for a few years. D&G are hopeless - misses appointments and awful phone help. Got rid of that machine and spent the money I would've spent on a good one with 5 year warranty. As it's a good machine it's not even gone wrong so not had to mess around with it either. Time is money too.||I currently pay £59 a month. Over £700 a year for repair contracts on 5 items with individual replacement costs of what about £500 each?
They must love customers like you.||What an outrageous waste of money. They've probably spent close to 5k over the course of the last 8 years on a product that is almost worthless. Everyone should avoid D&G and similar like the plague.
text:
Since 2008 I have had five insurance policies with Domestic & General to cover all my kitchen appliances.

I currently pay £59 a month. In September I reported that my frost-free integrated freezer was faulty, and six days later an engineer called.
title: Domestic & General’s customer service is beyond repair
